Forum Post: 
Post title: Only first module attempt being recorded
Post description: Hi folks, I'm having some issues with moodle 2.6.2+. I upgraded from 2.6.2 yesterday, on which everything was running fine, in terms of launching and tracking module attempts. However, since upgrading, only the first attempt is being tracked. You can launch and attempt the module as many times as you like, but it will only record that first attempt score. In the module settings, there is no restriction on the number of attempts that can be made, there are no restrictions in place that lock the module off once it has been completed (whether they pass or fail the module on their first attempt, it doesn't record anything after) and there are no restrictions in the SCORM package itself (created using Articulate Storyline). I followed the upgrade instructions on the moodle site word for word and as i said, everything else seems to look and function as it did when running 2.6.2, its just the attempt recording that doesn't. Im testing this in chrome, and i'm not sure if it will help at all, but i used a web debugging proxy tool to monitor the traffic going out and have attached a couple of images (in the attached zip) that show the output of a successful attempt and an unsuccessful attempt (both from datamodel.php). EDIT: In addition to the above, every now and then, when relaunching a module (selecting 'Start new attempt' or not) I get an 'Unable to acquire LMS API' error (image and error log in zip attached). Not sure if these are related. Any help would be greatly appreciated. Thanks in advance, Andy
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: I had a similar problem, using another publishing tool. To solve it, we had to take some steps: 1) In the publishing tool (in your case Articulate) make sure you have the COMPLETE/INCOMPLETE option and not PASS/FAIL. 2) In Moodle, check the 'force new attempt' option 3) Avoid loading the scorm in another page. You need to set this both in Moodle AND in Articulate.  You´ll probably have problems fitting the scorm object in the screen. To make room, we hid the all blocks, including navigation, in the Scorm player page. This needed to be done for each activity. Good luck!

Forum Post: 
Post title: Moodle not adding cumulative scores with SCORM package
Post description: Hello, Our Server Environment and other information: The version of Moodle running  is Moodle 1.5.3, it is running on Windows 2003 IIS 6, running php 4.3.11. In order to make SCORM courses run on IIS, the isapirewrite program was used ( available here http://www.isapirewrite.com/download/isapi_rwl_0056.msi < http://www.isapirewrite.com/download/isapi_rwl_0056.msi >  ) The neccesary configuration for isapirewrite is contained in its 'httpd.ini' file. The line below was added to this file: RewriteRule (.*?\.php)(\/.+) $1\?file=$2 [N,I]. So, we have Moodle 'up and running' and working fine generally. Problem with a third-party package we received: Courseware includes a test (already tested and compliant within a proprietary CLIX environment) I set it up in Moodle and set the grading method to: 'Set to Scoes Situation'. (Have also tested it with 'Highest Grade' and 'Average Grade'. Same result as described below). Upon selecting the zipped scorm-compliant package for this SCORM Module, I get an error-message dialog Box: 'WARNING: The Tracking Data of this Package will be lost!' When I do the course, it works fine - if I do all of the test in one sitting . However, if I exit the course and go back in to complete anther section , Moodle does not retain/aggregate my score from the previous visit(s). Begins again at zero every time I re-enter. So, does not add cumulative scores/not aggregating properly. Can anyone suggest a fix for this? Do I need to post the mainfest file? Thank you, Colmán
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: If the students score is recorded in the LMS using cmi.core.score it is entered as a single element in the scoes_tracking table so essentially gets overwritten every time. If you want highest lowest scores you need to have your courseware write the score to cmi.score.min, cmi.score.max. Alternatively if the courseware is writing each question out as an interaction cmi.interactions.n.id the index of the interaction is restarted from zero every instantiation. So Question 1 might have been stored as cmi.interactions.0."Q_1" and all the Q1 students results as cmi.interactions.0.learner_response, cmi.interactions.0.type etc. On reentry the student results for the scorm will start at index 0 and overwrite them. What we do is store the attempts in cmi.suspend_data and increment the index on each entry and only write out index values in the current session.
Comment 2: Andrew, Many thanks for the reply and pardon my stupidity as I'm new to Moodle and have, as yet, a very limited understanding of its functionality. If you could spare a few moments to answer the questions below, that would great: So, practically, what do I do; what changes do I need to make; what files do I need to edit to make this package work? Colmán
Comment 3: I don't believe this is a moodle issue but rather it's the courseware and the way it sends requests to moodle and the scorm api. We had similar issues moving scorm across to moodle as we were using a pre-scorm 1.2 data element to store attempts, the courseware was scorm compliant when it was written just not with the SCORM 1.2. Do you have access to the source code of your SCORM?

Comment 7: Easy parts first, Attempt count is correct because this is the admin/teacher view and attemp number refers to all user attempts, a class view if you like not individual attempts - this is under activity reports for user. There is no cmi.suspend_data in your detailed reports though the scorm.js seems to have the code to write it. This suspend data looks like it should append the previous session data to the current suspend data in scormSetSuspendData() at line 150 when the user exits and the SCO Status is incomplete. cmi.core.exit is being set correctly to "suspend" so the failure seems to be in this function scormSetSuspendData. Have you also set SCORM "Grading Method" to Sum?

Forum Post: 
Post title: Creating a new Activity type based on the SCORM Activity
Post description: All: I have a rather unique issue that's painted me into a corner, and I'm not sure if the solution I have in mind is even possible, which is why I'm asking you all. I have several courses that have a great many SCORM activities in them - some of them very large activities at that. These courses are built upon existing documentation that our customer wants us to mirror in an interactive way, so we don't have much flexibility when it comes to the contents of the course, unfortunately. Because of this, the increasing file sizes of our SCORM lessons (built in Captivate) as they're fleshed out and completed have led to our courses' becoming bloated and large to the point where we can no longer create course backup files and/or restore from them. Changing the max_upload_size and max_file_size in php settings isn't enough. We've hit some kind of threshold that is limiting us from performing backups on our courses, and I've thus far been unable to determine the cause. ( Moodle in English: What is the max allowable size for course backups? ) That being said, I've been told to find a workaround. I'm wondering if it would be possible for me to find a way to create a new type of activity which, instead of containing the SCORM package within the activity, links to it in the file system instead, and unpacks it in real time. A predecessor of mine created a new activity type that allowed us to treat Unity executables as SCORM lessons by wrapping them in a sort of dummy SCORM package that allowed us to link to the executable and run it locally on the student machine, through clever use of registry keys and database manipulation. However, that was before my time, and I'm not quite sure how they did it. Do any of you know how to create a new activity type, based on an existing one? I'd feel better if I at least knew which part of the moodle code I should be looking at, and maybe any sort of pitfalls I should look out for. I want it to receive grades as the regular SCORM activity does too, which is another difficulty, I think.
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: I had similar problem - couldn't upload SCORM packages because they were too big. I might have a simple solution for you: file system repository . By default, when you create SCORM activity, it actually takes more than twice of disk space actually needed. It's because you upload SCORM ZIP package and then Moodle unzips it. So you end up with zipped and unzipped version of the package taking the disk at the same time. When using file system repository, you upload SCORM ZIP to the file system repository by FTP protocol using some of the simple free FTP upload tools such as Filezilla. SCORM ZIP is outside of the course files and you can use reference to the SCORM ZIP instead of copying SCORM ZIP to the course. So, in actual course you only have unzipped version of the SCORM package. This could save you up to 50% (a little bit less actually, depending of the SCORM content) of the disk space for each SCORM activity. This is far more simple to setup than it sounds. Another, better, but more complicated solution is to setup separate content server . When you create SCORM files with Captivate, it includes content and metadata (imsmanifest. xml , xsd - xml schema definition files, etc...). You can actually simply modify the package to include metadata only and have content in another place (content server). Actually, you move content form SCORM ZIP to another dir and modify URL 's in imsmanifest.xml. Since you don't want unauthorized users to access the content, you can't just move it to another http dir, you need some kind of security. And, if it's on different domain than Moodle, than you need some kind of reverse proxy or similar solution that will solve the crossserver scripting security challenge. I hope I gave you some ideas. Have fun!

If yes, what are plans to deal with this issue and is there any quick solution available? Warm regards, Mahtab Hussain
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Hi everyone, I am wondering if there is someone who has something to say in this matter. Regards, Mahtab Hussain
Comment 2: What I had to say about this is unpostable and uncomplimentary towards Google. That said, I talked to the IT staff who know what all this means and they had some thoughts about publishing with a button that reports data on select instead of reporting automatically on close. This is easy if you use something with super granular control, like Lectora, but harder with Captivate. I was looking at Captivate settings and I'm not sure what triggers completion on it --there is a send tracking detail at end setting but I don't use that one.

Comment 4: So far in my testing, I think Moodle might not actually be affected? I used Chrome Dev channel ( https://www.chromium.org/getting-involved/dev-channel ) and used Version 81.0.4021.2 (Official Build) dev (64-bit) of Chrome to test this on our Moodle site, version 3.5.9, Build 20191122. I turned on SCORM API debugging and entered SCORM modules we have created both with Lectora and Storyline that open both within the window and in a new window. I then went a few screens into the module and closed the scorm window or navigated away by copying/pasting a new URL in the bar. In my testing, it looked like the progress data was written properly back to Moodle and when I went back to the modules, they resumed where I had left of. If we're lucky, we might not have to do anything? I didn't play around with the flag in it, so it's possible it is still disabled by default in 81 and we just have an issue later on.

Forum Post: 
Post title: Long loading of articulate content
Post description: Some students are unable to view my Moodle content (by Articulate) properly. They've got white screen instead of content progress bar. Progress bar appears only after 1,5-2 minutes instead of usual few seconds. Some of them have got high internet speed (30+ Mb/s by speedtest.net). The same content created for web delivery (not for LMS) doesn't create any problems. Articulate support offered solution. But there's no reason to publish content if a lot of students have to execute seven points below. What can I did wrong? Are they able to view other Moodle content quickly? Are you able to replicate the issue on your computer if you login as a regular user? If the issue is specific to your users' computers only, I would recommend forwarding them the steps below: 1) Upgrade Adobe Flash Player here: http://www.adobe.com/go/getflash 2) If your LMS requires Java to be installed on the client computers, be sure the correct version of Java is installed and enabled for your browser. Java can be downloaded and installed here: http://java.com 3) Clear your browser cache. You can do this in Internet Explorer by going to Tools > Internet Options > General > Temporary Internet Files. Select Delete Cookies and Delete Files. 4) Also in Internet Options, on the Security, Privacy, and Advanced tabs, reset everything to its default settings. There is a button on each tab to reset defaults. 5) In Windows Vista / 7, go to Start > All Programs > Accessories > Run. In Windows XP, go to Start > Run. 6) Copy / paste the following line of text (depending on your operating system) into the Run dialog box. Click OK, and delete the entire contents of the window (folder) that opens. Windows Vista / 7:"C:\Users\%username%\AppData\Roaming\Macromedia\Flash Player\#SharedObjects"
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: That's a pretty good response from Articulate - they've given you an extensive list of things that could potentially cause the problems - Top of my list would be to check which Flash player and Javascript version your students are using. Try sending the checklist to one of the students that is struggling - they may respond saying "step 1 was all I needed" - that way if other users have the same problem you can say - "try step 1" - this will probably resolve your issue, otherwise try a few of the other steps below. My guess is that if they have decent broadband access - they shouldn't really have that much difficulty following the steps as provided from Articulate.

Post title: Captivate 4, SCORM, Firefox reporting quiz grades as 0.
Post description: So here's my problem. We have a series of SCORM 1.2 packages created in Captivate 4. Each one has some kind of video, text, or audio in the beginning and usually ends with a quiz. We are using moodle 1.9.5. We upload the zipped SCORM using moodle into a course. When we try to test the SCORM activity in Firefox , the activity reports a 0 to the gradebook. No matter what we score in the quiz, it's always a zero. For the longest time, we thought that the grades weren't reporting at all, but I recently discovered that the problem is only in Firefox. When we tested the SCORM in Safari, the test reported the correct score to the grade book. I then checked that score in a Firefox window. Sure enough, the grade for the activity was updated with the correct score. When I took the quiz again in Firefox, the score was overwritten to a zero even though that was the wrong score. More interestingly, when I checked the file in Safari, the grade for that score was updated to zero which means that the activity is reporting a "0" to the gradebook when taken in Firefox, specifically. Now, currently I haven't checked what happens in IE but I should also not that both Firefox and Safari were on Mac 10.5.6. Anyone know how to fix this issue with Firefox? I've never heard of Firefox glitching before Safari or IE. Creating the quizzes in Moodle isn't the route we want to take. We are looking to keep the quizzes in Captivate.
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: I'm having the same problem with quiz grades in Firefox when I run moodle through my shared linux server with godaddy. I'm using Adobe Presenter 7 to create the SCORM 1.2 packages. Firefox records a grade of 0 and a strange alphanumeric code in the time details. I tested these browsers on Vista. The strange thing is grading works fine in Firefox when I run moodle from my local apache server.
Comment 2: Snap. same problem also. Havnt found a fix as yet.
Comment 3: Hmm...This is interesting. Everything seems to be working in Firefox today. I honestly didn't change a thing and now my test scores are reporting. I guess for today, the issue is resolved but I don't like the idea of Moodle potentially not working for some users some of the time. This could be a huge issue in whether we continue considering opening up our courses to the public like we are. Has anyone found a cause or solution the problem yet?
Comment 4: Hi, I am having a very similar problem, but mine is in Internet Explorer. It has appeared in the grades results from the assessments.  I have noted 5 separate incidences, 5 different students on various days and various quizzes (so no similarity or reasoning why) apart from it hasnt happened to the additional Quizzes that are Moodle created only on the Captivate quizzes. The problem.  assessment results are appearing as 0 (and of course this comes up as failed), but when I went in to decide if the student actual did in fact get all the questiions incorrect or for whatever reason maybe didnt answer any of the questions. But, what i found was that in the 5 instances, the student had in fact answered all the questions and had in fact gotten one or more questions correct, however these correct responses have not been registered. For the validity of our data.  I am going to get the students to re-do those quizzes in question.
Comment 5: Make sure you're using a supported version: http://docs.moodle.org/en/SCORM_FAQ#Supported_Versions (in future please include your Moodle version in your post) then check these out: http://docs.moodle.org/en/SCORM_FAQ#SCORM_and_the_Gradebook http://docs.moodle.org/en/SCORM_FAQ#Handling_of_Multiple_Attempts
Comment 6: Interesting, I have done some troubleshooting with the students.  Seems, they are accessing a quiz and (this is a very possible reason), when the school networked workstations come up with the pop-up blocker, they have 200 clicks of the mouse in a frenzy of impaitence.  So, what looks to be happening, they end up with the quiz in a suspended state at the rear, and they click click and end up with another of the quiz windows opened (remembering we have them set at 1 attempt), they go through and do the quiz, then the 1st attempt window gets force quit and loses the data. I will certainly keep an eye on this.
Comment 7: I got a similar problem... Cp opening in a new window and loading slowly is definately a problem for my users to...
Comment 8: newer versions of Moodle (1.9.10+ from memory) remove the "click here to open a window" link and force the user to disable their pop-up blocker - this should help prevent double windows and some other issues with browsers not allowing js communication for manually generated pop-up windows.
Comment 9: You're right Dan... Our use of Moodle 1.9.4 is definetly not the better news for the use of SCORM module. You have done a great job in the latest versions of the system... It will be nice to jump to the 2.0 version...

Forum Post: 
Post title: Best solution for responsive SCORMs in Moodle
Post description: Hi, I'm Andrea. I'm searching viable solutions for loading SCORM projects in Moodle, under the requirement of a good responsive support on mobile devices. I read SCORM FAQs and I've found some potential problems and headaches. I'm totally free on choosing the SCORM authoring platform. Is there any product of these that can bypass responsive problems in a satisfatory manner, with little or no effort? What about Captivate? Thanks, Andrea
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: What's the reason for choosing "SCORM" - it's an old outdated technology that was never really designed for using on mobile devices (let alone wifi!) You could just create your content directly in the LMS using standard tools, but if you're wanting an external authoring tool that doesn't tie you to a specific LMS, then you should be looking at h5p.org (which is also supported in Moodle.)
Comment 2: Thanks, Dan. We are considering SCORM because we have used it some years ago and we have some experience about. If today SCORM is not the best choice on implementing mobile-aware e-learning solutions, we can evaluate more modern alternatives.
Comment 3: To answer your question about tools...it really depends on what you are building. Captivate is considered a good choice if you do software tutorials. And it can do really nice software 'assessments' where the user has to perform the action to complete.  But I cannot say whether the software tutorials are especially responsive, I have my doubts about accessibility of software tutorials and building responsive anything in Captivate is kind of a pain in the behind. It is what I use (we are currently at war). Mostly we do software stuff. If you have a bunch of powerpoints you want to convert, Captivate is bad at this. It turns your slides into images. Lectora is an excellent tool if you don't want software assessments. They have a new-ish screen recorder that I know nothing about. If you have some mad skills you might be able to manually create assessments. They include responsive design stuff and if you are converting powerpoints to something interactive, the import is easy and good. Love Lectora. Is very expensive. Storyline/Articulate has a pretty good rep. I haven't used it but they have a great community. I use their community for ideas, even if I don't use their product. Rumor has it they are/can be responsive.  Some of their stuff actually works with powerpoint, looks cool. I think they are less expensive than Lectora, more expensive than Captivate (though Captivate is getting pricier). Everything I've heard is they are really easy to use. I've used other SCORM stuff, like iSpring(freeware) and eXe (now eXeLearning?--this was a long time ago, used to be in core...ish) and Camtasia. For SCORM, not especially impressed, but Camtasia has improved. Still not awesome, has some weird things, but functions. I'd only use Camtasia if you plan to do a lot of video based stuff and need reporting. If you don't need reporting, H5P does some really cool stuff with video and can interact with YouTube. If you use interactive video with YouTube, you lose the YouTube captioning, if that matters to you. Addressing what Dan was talking about...yeah, SCORM is old. They've been saying SCORM was dying for as long as I've been using it...unlike flash, it seems to still be running around and functional. There are some upsides to SCORM, but also downsides. If you are not interested in documenting results, H5P is terrific. It has so many cool features. But reporting is not good. SCORM reporting is decent, unless your user has an unstable internet connection OR times out, then it gets frustrating. H5P can't really do software assessment; other than just video demo, it wouldn't be great for tutorials. I think about trying to do something like that for a minute or two, my brain starts bleeding, I stop. But it does have some super cool branching options and, other than poor reporting and no software assessment, definitely worth it, if you don't need reporting. Reporting is why I use SCORM. Figure out what you really want/need. Choose your tool based on that. I'm keeping my eye on H5P because I really want to love it. They're talking about making the score interface better with Moodle...when that happens, I'll re-evaluate.
Comment 4: Thanks Melanie, very useful guidelines. We don't have use cases using special features (like software tutorials needs), for now. Text, images, some multiple choice test. And some navigation logic, maybe. We could implement them using standard editing moodle functions, but we potentially have a great number of "pages" to build and maintain. So, we are considering an external authoring tool for faster and easier editing. Reporting could be an issue, but is not a fundamental feature.  "Poor" reporting  could not be a problem, "totally absent", could.
Comment 5: If you haven't started using a SCORM tool yet, the learning curve can be steep. If you have a multiple choice test, I would build that directly in Moodle vs. the SCORM content using the delivered, core Moodle reporting. Less headaches around. So, if I was going to use the Moodle quiz activity, I would just build the content in native Moodle activities . External authoring tool is not necessarily faster and easier to edit. Read down through this Forum's threads to get a full picture of other problems with SCORM.
Comment 6: Thanks. We will consider using pure Moodle solutions, too.
Comment 7: I agree with Shirley. I would always prefer a Moodle quiz to anything built in SCORM. So much flexibility, excellent reporting. If the only reason to use SCORM is to get something pretty...go for H5P and use quiz for testing. As I mentioned, we use it for a lot of software tutorial stuff...but we're trying to find ways to get away from it...which is why I am aware of the ups and downs of H5P.  H5P lets you set backgrounds, switch between, add all sorts of stuff. Super functional.
Comment 8: Hello Andrea, ADAPT is a truly responsive authoring tool, based totally on HTML5. But regarding effort, I guess at the beginning it is not easy. There is the authoring tool you can install in your server , but the learning curve is steep. There are a bunch of ADAPT developers that can help, though.
Comment 9: Thanks Beatriz
Comment 10: ADAPT is a great tool, but I also want to note it's not going to help in dealing with some of the issues you may run into with SCORM, particularly in terms of mobile device intermittent connectivity. SCORM assumes an uninterrupted internet connection, so unless you are using the Moodle app to have offline data handling, you'll run into issues with intermittent wireless connectivity. Take a look at https://h5p.org/presentation if your requirements for the learning modules aren't complex in terms of variables and other things.
Comment 11: Hi, thanks to this point. It seems another important aspect.

Forum Post: 
Post title: No Scorm in Modules
Post description: Hello everybody, I hope someone can help. In our Moodle (1.6.3) SCORM does not exist under : Configuration, Modules. Neither can we choose SCORM in the Add-an-activity menu. I'm sure it was there before. Now how to get it back? Peter Plasmans.
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: is the "scorm" directory present at /mod/scorm/ ? Do you have the SCORM tables in the Moodle db?. Probably it was deleted by accident?.
Comment 2: Probably someone turned it off. Do you have an admin account on your Moodle installation? Then go to the Admin page, and there select Modules . You should see by then a list of installed modules on your Moodle, and although a module might be installed, it could be hidden (with the open/closed eyes set of icons we all know). If there is no SCORM entry, you have to install it. See this page of the Moodle documentation as a reference how to do this. http://docs.moodle.org/en/Non-standard_modules#Module_installation Good luck, Timo

Forum Post: 
Post title: Review Mode is overwriting existing status
Post description: Hi everyone, I have been struggling with the following problem for a while. When completing a SCORM package students get green mark and "completed" status. When the same students review or views part of the SCORM package again, Moodle removes all previous status settings, and new settings are set according to the new entry. Students get incomplete (orange cross) even though the student has already viewed all material in the package before. I have uploaded a very short video showing the problem I am experiencing together with the scorn package at the following url: http://lms.jsc.no/ReviewMode/ReviewMode.html Hope you can help! Kind regards, Tobias
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: I think I might be having the same problem. My post is here: https://moodle.org/mod/forum/discuss.php?d=217790 I searched on Google for 'Review Mode' and found this "After digging through Moodle forums I discovered that "Review Mode" kicks in after the user has received a "Passing Score" on the course." Is that correct? It's a 2010 blog post that mentions changings grading settings to avoid the "Review Mode". Don't know about that. Blog post here: http://joedeegan.blogspot.it/2010/03/scorm-problems-caused-by-moodle-review.html To me it looks like Moodle resets the value mdl_scorm_scoes_track each time the user clicks on the link, but I can't look into it more just now. Anyone else having this problem? Please help or at least explain. I'll let you know if I find out something.
Comment 2: This problem has already been tagged as a bug in Moodle http://tracker.moodle.org/browse/MDL-35363 The bug is in the SCORM API module. It's not setting the "cmi.mode" flag to "review", so the content is assuming that a new attempt is being made, and it overwrites the data of the previous attempt. The best solution (workaround) to this issue is to completely disable the "review" mode by setting the "Maximum number of attempts" and checking the "Force new attempt" AND "Lock after final attempt" in the SCORM package settings. Hope this helps.
Comment 3: Hi Kinan, Thanks for the suggestion, however I am using moodle 1.9.5+ and here I do not have the option to "Force new attempt" AND "Lock after final attempt". I have also read that the bug you mentioned did not come about before moodle 2.3.
Comment 4: Hi, Same issue, moodle 2.5. I really want to disable review mode. I do not have options "Force new attempt" AND "Lock after final attempt" (Scorm from captivate 5 or storyline) Thanks.
Comment 5: ...I found "Force new attempt" AND "Lock after final attempt" in the SCORM parameter page (moodle). Maybe a bug corrected in 2.5.3 (2.6) is related. See you soon.
Comment 6: Hi Sophie, read more about my lovely experience with Moodle Review Mode in MDL-21353 . Depending on your final goal, this could help you: http://joedeegan.blogspot.it/2010/03/scorm-problems-caused-by-moodle-review.html . HTH , Matteo
Comment 7: Dear Matteo, Thank you very much. Such a lovely experience indeed ! It's very tricky for teachers. Even defining passing score changes nothing about review mode : it's written review mode, but scores changes after all... I'll make them wait until I can update moodle : https://tracker.moodle.org/browse/MDL-37524 Have a nice day, Sophie

Forum Post: 
Post title: Way to prevent SCORM packages from appearing in the gradebook?
Post description: I've got a teacher that would like the SCORM LO's to be viewed by the learner, but not appear in the gradebook.   I understand hiding them from the student - but the teacher side becomes very messy with many unessesary columns. These are primarily Camtasia screencasts, but could be others as well. When you create or import,  Is there a way to prevent SCORM packages from creating a column and appearing in the gradebook? Moodle v2.2
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Hi!

You can publish the .zip file as an IMS content
Comment 2: Hi Ron, I upload the .zip files as a "file" resource rather than as a SCORM when I don't need to track grades. Unlike when you use the SCORM activity, you have to unzip the package once you have it uploaded to the resource. Once unzipped, then right click the HTML file and choose "set main file". This will ensure that the file launches properly when the learner clicks. Finally, I find it works best to open these in a pop-up rather than in the same window. I find it helps with getting the sizing right. Leah
Comment 3: Thanks to each of you.  That seems like a very good solution to the problem.  I appreciate you taking the time to help.

Post title: Scorm tracking doubt
Post description: Hi Team , I am using Moodle latest version . I am using a Scorm activity inside my course. It contains 10 slides ( in Scorm ). Suppose when a student seen 5 slides from it and closed. Then can I calculate the % of viewing ? ( here it is 50% ) . Is it possible ? Is there any data saved in database related to it ? Please guide me . Thanks in advance. Regards , Jerin
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Hi Jerin, it actually depends on the content: the content could use the SCORM score to map the percentage of progress - you can use a basic report to view such "progress" the content could use the SCORM bookmark to register the last slide seen by the user  - you should develop a custom report to map the name of the slide with its ordering number, to get a progress view for that SCORM activity HTH , Matteo
Comment 2: To elaborate a bit more on Matteo's reply, it depends on how your SCORM package is setup to report things. If you can set it to report it as Matteo suggest in his reply, it would work. If you are stuck with what the package reports as is, and can't modify the SCORM, take a look at what it data reports in the SCORM Reports tab: https://docs.moodle.org/35/en/Using_SCORM#SCORM_reports and the specific details of an attempt to get an idea of what data you have to work with.
Comment 3: Hello Jerin, What authoring solution are you using? if it's Storyline, you might find useful my last reply in this thread: https://moodle.org/mod/forum/discuss.php?d=371722

Post title: scorm html5 and mobile
Post description: Hello, I have an issue about tracking scorm objects on mobile. I have read many posts around without finding any solution. I made some contents using Articulate Storyline, I want them to be visible on mobile devices (iphone and ipad) and tracked in Moodle (2.6). Anyone can explain me if is possible and how to do? If I create "normal" scorm packages (even publishing from articulate with "html5 export" checked) and upload them in Moodle I can't see anything (scorm oblects load without end and nothing is show)... Later I succeed in VIEW contents (just upload content to web server and in Moodle I served links to story.html, for iphone, and launch_ios.html, for ipad ), but of course, as I didn't use scorm activity but only a simple link to an external file, I had not any kind of tracking of the contents. For ipad I think I understand the only way is to export to for articulate mobile application and use tin can api, thing that cut off Moodle as it doesn't have tincan api tracking (yet, I hope). But for html5? I think is correct to say that for mobile it's necessary to pick html5 file of the content (that, in fact is properly viewed by mobile device) but how to tell Moodle to take it when it is inside the zip file of scorm object? Articulate support say to serve contents on mobile by serving link to html... ok, but this means you can't track them or i'm wrong, as in Moodle you can't link to a specific file inside a zip? So, how to make Moodle track scorm objects on mobile devices? And, first of all, html5 support scorm tracking? Thank you and sorry for the bad english.
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Helen your message is kind of difficult to understand. I´ve read two times and still dont understand what´s is your problem. I have publish more than 200 courses in our Moodle LMS and that´s all HTML5 generated from Captivate 7.0.1, and all the users access the content from ipads. We use system simulations, wit a lot of click boxes, text entry boxes, etc... And it´s all working on mobile devices. Tchau.
Comment 2: Hi Andre, and thank you for your reply. My problem is that if I publish a Scorm content by zipping it and uploading as scorm activity in Moodle (as I do for many other scorms stuff that work perfectly browsing from desktop computers), my safari browser (using both iphone and ipad) can't load them. Guys from Articulate say to "provide a link to the .html file" to make them work in mobile, but I suppose this means that I couldn't use a scorm activity mod, as there's no way to point a file (the .html) within a zip. And, if I use a URL activity of moodle, contents are loaded and work on mobile browsers but I can't obviously have a tracking on them. can you please provide the description of the steps you follow to publish your contents on Moodle?
Comment 3: Well if the content is working on desktop, that means that the content is already Scorm 1.2. You dont have a link to the course, so we can check it out, it´s on a local server?
Comment 4: Hello Helen. I used Articulate for a while, but gave it up about a year ago because of the restrictions on mobile. As far as I know, you can´t publish in Scorm and use the content on mobile devices. That´s a known restriction, and it´s informed on articulate´s website. The only way that you can use articulate content on Moodle and mobile is using Tin Can. Consider switching to Adobe Captivate or Trivantis Lectora. Good luck!
Comment 5: Thank you Rudy, I put the question as Articulate support keep saying some users have been able to use scorm on mobile devices from Moodle, but, asked on that, guys from support can't really explain how they did... it's quite strange thing... Do you suggest to pass to Captivate? Can you tell something more, if possible... ? If nobody has more to add to discussion, the only thing left for Articulate users is to hope that Tin can can develop a little faster and that open source LSR will be a reality soon.
Comment 6: Hello. I gave Captivate a good try. At first I was really impressed, but after a while I gave it up. The main reason is that I´m looking for a single tool in which we can create activities both for web and mobile. And the activities range from simple instructional courses to more sophisticated gamified activities. And Adobe has several tools for these different jobs, so to get the job done we would need several tools, including some not so friendly ones (such as Adoge Gaming). And adobe Is still a bit attached to flash… Both Articulate and Captivate claim to export in HTML5, but in my experience both these outputs are much inferior to their corresponding flash outputs in both programs. Unfortunately they are more appropriate for desktops and notebooks. To create good html5 with Adobe you would need to combine tools like Dreamweaver, Adobe Edge Animate and Adobe Reflow. And the whole idea of ‘rapid development’ just gets lost… I want to create both mobile friendly activities and mobile apps. That is: activities to be run on the user´s browser (such as a Scorm package in an LMS or as a regular webpage) AND activities that can be converted to specific Android and IOS apps with PhoneGap. I found that the best way to test for the quality of the HTML5 output is to publish the output to a web server and access it with an Android device, using the native browser (WebKit). Than you can have a glance of the true mobile experience of the learners. And both with Articulate and Captivate this test was a big failure. And this exactly what the app would be like if created with PhoneGap. I still haven´t found the perfect tool for the job. Lectora has a few great advantages: it´s HTML at its core: there´s no Flash output (unless you include flash objects in the project). And it´s a much more powerful tool with many built in functions that require a lot of work in the other platforms (like a timer, recurring actions, a table of content, progress bars, etc). But it has some major drawbacks (the output is always fixed sized with absolute positioning, so it doesn´t have any responsive capabilities. Also the animations and transitions are really lame, although I´ve heard that the newer versions show improvement in this area). There´s really no reason why an html output wouldn’t work on Scorm in mobile devices. And for us this limitation was a deal breaker, so we ditched Articulate. If you already work with the Adobe suite and you have an adobe creative cloud subscription, it might be a way to go. But if you´re looking for a single tool for desktop and mobile development, Captivate will frustrate you. Good luck and let us know what works out for you. Cheers
Comment 7: Thank you Rudy for your exhaustive reply. I think anyway I'll hold for a while, looking for some changes from Tin Can that, in my opinion, will change the way to approach mobile tracking too. For SCORM: can you provide the way you exported and loaded articulate objects in moodle? You did so: - exported for LMS in Scorm 1.2, with html5 export box checked; - loaded in Moodle as zip file using SCOM activity mod; - simply access to this file from your mobile device?
Comment 8: Hi Helen. Yep, that´s how I did it. There´s really no other straightforward way to publish Scorm activities in Moodle. But it just wouldn´t work as desired, the user experience was terrible and in many cases just impossible (objects didn´t load, couldn´t turn pages...).  The problem is not the Scorm or Moodle, it’s the HTML5 output. But I haven´t tested it in a while, I believe Articulate released some major updates and perhaps there´s improvement. Do you have the latest version of Storyline? If so, try and do the test I told you.  Publish any project in a webserver (can you do this? If not, let me know) and access the project using and Android´s native browser. See if it works. When you publish in Articulate, chose HTML5 output but make sure you DON´T choose the ‘Articulate App Viewer’ option. Good luck!
Comment 9: If you're looking for a new authoring tool that works well on mobile/tablet, try gomo ( http://www.gomolearning.com/ ). We regularly put gomo content on Moodle.
Comment 10: Hi Helen, Are you publishing to SCORM 1.2 standards?  Current versions of Moodle do not support SCORM 2004.
Comment 11: Hi, I'm trying brand new Captivate 8, and its html5 seems to works like a charme on Moodle (and to be more powerfull). I'll defenitely drop down Storyline and its html5 problems on ipad!

Forum Post: 
Post title: Grading problem in Moodle
Post description: Hi, everyone. Currently I am using Moodle 1.9.9 to run a couple of SCORM activities , the Learning Objects developed in Lectora. I realize that Moodle allows to me to limit the “Number of attempts” of using the Learning object in the setting for each Learning Object. However, it seems like that a user can play the Learning object many times even within one attempt. The score for the attempt is the last score before a user clicks “Start a new attempt”. Does anyone know how to force Moodle to take the first score as the final score of the attempt? And for some reason, the status of the learning object is never marked as “passed” or “failed” even if the user has finished it. The status is always marked as “incomplete”. I have seen similar complaints in some old posts but without clear solutions. I would like to know if anyone has seen these two problems and what the solutions are. Thanks.
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: I would like to know the definition of "attempt" of a SCORM activity. Does it mean a user can only take the SCORM activity one time in one "attempt"?
Comment 2: Hello Zy, Attempts handling depends a great deal on what your SCORM package is doing, what data it is sending to the LMS. We have documented the general rules for handling of multiple attempts here: http://docs.moodle.org/en/SCORM_FAQ#Handling_of_Multiple_Attempts There is also an option on Attempts Grading to count only the first attempt... but, as I said above, what is registered as an attempt will depend upon what your SCO is reporting to the LMS. Hopefully this information will get your started in determining what's going on between your particular SCO and Moodle. I recommend running through an attempt with debugging on to see what's being passed through the API during the session:
Comment 3: Thanks you very much, Amy. It seems like that the SCORM package created by Lectora only reports the raw score to Moodle regardless of the status.
Comment 4: If that is the case, then an option to start a new attempt will never be offered to the learner. The learner will just modify the score of the first attempt over and over. The option to start a new attempt is not presented until cmi.core.lesson_status is set to "completed" or "passed". -A

Comment 1: Hi Barbara, If you're getting a not initialized error, that's because calls are being made when the API is not initialized. Post title: SCORM package packed with XML files
Post description: Hello all, I have a SCORM package packed with XML files  .I can upload the package successfuly . And i can view the content preview of the course . Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: I think the problem is generated because a file that is part of the content was not packaged into the ZIP before importing it into Moodle. You can see which link in your content is generating that error, and take the missing file and add it to your ZIP file, and upload it again. This will correct the issue and make the SCORM package a correct package. Another workaround is to upload the missing files to the folder where files were extracted at import time. This can be done through the course file manager Eduardo

Post title: Scorm Help
Post description: Hello i have a Scorm module and i am trying to delete a page in the scorm. Problem is no matter if i delete the html page, or if i delete the following line in the course . xml file </Page> <Page Name="P29" Text="RCOv_Quest6.html" Title="Question #6"/> </Page> when i upload the course back into moodle i get an error on the page. I just want to know how to not make the page show up in the list among this paticular course. Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Hi - in the imsmanifest.xml file there is more than one reference to a resource - they are associated by the resource identifier, so deleting one entry isn't necessarily going to solve your problem. You also need to be sure that the package is being updated, and that your browser cache is clear. Try creating a new SCOR/AICC activity, when you add the package next time - see if that changes things. Cheers.

Forum Post: 
Post title: Need the SCORM to pass all grades
Post description: Hello, this is the problem I'm having. I'm using a scorm to set the grade for a class. After student passes class, he/she has to "recertificate" in a couple of years Student would unenroll from class and retake scorm. Sounds easy, but it is not. Moodles keeps your grade history (even after you unenroll) and does not let failing grades override passing ones. So, if I pass the first time with a 85%, unenroll, take the scorm again and obtain a failing grade of 40%, the grade book still says 85%!!!!! I've fudged with the settings a lot. Scorm only passes: Highest grade (which is logical) Avg Sum Latest Attempt (the problem is that it is the latest PASSING attemp). Anyone knows how to fix this, so the scorm passes the latest attempt regardless of pass/fail status? Many thanks! Luis P.
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Moodle is designed to pass a course once, and it never expires. What we have done, is have the year after the course name. Each year, we create a new course, with the same content, and archive the old one. This way, they actually complete a new course each year. We even have a report which shows when someone is due to "Expire" due to the date they last completed it, and do a CSV enrol on the new course, which sends them an email stating they need to do the new course. A little ugly on the back end, however it works well for the students. Cheers Peter

Forum Post: 
Post title: Moodle 2.2.1 and SCORM with IE9
Post description: I have several SCORM packagesfrom FUSE, Content Generator and HotPotatoes.  All worked fine with M1.9.  I have uploaded to Moodle 2.2 and Moodle fails to record the activity and report grades.  I have tried checking all permissions etc. on tracking but all OK.  They work on Firefox 12.  Assume this is an IE9 problem rather than Moodle.  Any ideas for a school that defaults to IE ?
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: From what I understand the Hot potatoes does not work with 2.2
Comment 2: Roger, This is clearly an IE 9 issue, you can google all over the place about this issue.  SCORMs will just not record. I put in an .htaccess setting for my apache, I'm assuming you are using linux. Below is what is in my .htaccess file ---------------------- BrowserMatch MSIE best-standards-support Header set X-UA-Compatible IE=8 env=best-standards-support ---------------------- I put mine in my moodle root folder. Take a look at the following links: http://moodle.org/mod/forum/discuss.php?d=189298 http://moodle.org/mod/forum/discuss.php?d=181721 http://evolpin.wordpress.com/2011/02/25/ie9-compatibility-and-the-meta-tag/ You test by pressing F12 in IE to see if it shows IE8 Compat Mode I hope this helps. Forrest Gaston
Comment 3: Hi, Just done another test with Moddle 2.2.1 & Firefox - HotPot 6.3 SCORM works fine and records data to gradebook. Nothing works with IE9 even with IE8 compatibility switched on via F12 I think I will just stick to Firefox!  Thanks for useful comments and links - will follow up. Roger

Forum Post: 
Post title: Shared SCORM Package From Center Storage
Post description: Hi, I have 3 moodle deployement on version 3.5. Server / VM runs on nginx, PHP7.0 mysql ver-8, debian 9. Server01|HV-01 School 1 (Having schoole1data) - VM-01 School 2 (Having schoole2data) - VM-02 School 3 (Having schoole3data) - VM-03 NAS-01 NFS Storage (Moodle resource files) - Centralized storage Every school have their own schooldata as local storage. NAS-01 are used for all the resource file, uploaded by contributor. Now I want to use the file from NAS in all three schools. What I can do is create VM-04 as owncloud server, and add webdav repo instance in each moodle/school under course repo. By doing this, all the file will be copied over and saved in each school, whenever course creator added resource from the webdav repo. Or mount the NFS as /var/www/schooldata/repository/centrelizeddata to all the three school and add local file repo instance in each school. What I want to achieve is, to avoid duplication of the files in that schools, under the school data local storage. So if I want to use scorm zip file from webdav repo, the zip file wont be copied over to school local storage. Can I achieve this using different repo instead of webdav. Is there any better ways to do it?  Is it possible. Thank you.
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Ok, I got some of that, but not all.  If you wanted to point to one location for course files, you could set your SCORM activities to load an external manifest.  Then point to a URL location where the unzipped folder with the imsmanifest. xml resides.  Just make sure, in your SCORM activity settings, that you also turn on Compatibility Settings -> Auto-commit -> Yes.  Essentially that enables an auto-save to ensure that progress is being saved regularly. That is a simple way to allow multiple instances to point to the same course files.
Comment 2: Hi Ershad, Yes it is possible in an extremely elegant way. I was looking for it for several years and just figured out how to do it. It is described in detail in the discussion after this link: https://moodle.org/mod/forum/discuss.php?d=353825 Wat you need is: A central folder on the server. This folder can even be a webdav In the Moodledata of each moodle a dir repository. In these repositories Symlinks to the central folder. If you now browse for your package file the central folder and his content will show up. You can even make an alias to the imsmanifest.xml of the unzipped scorm instead of to the zipfile.

Post title: interaction between jquery quiz and Moodle scorm1.2
Post description: Hi All, I am basically a newbie to moodle. I am currently developing an SCO (an quiz) using html, css and jquery. I want this quiz to be added as a scorm 1.2 content so that it can interact with moodle. The objective is to create a quiz in jquery and the results of the jquery quiz should be stored in moodle and graded by moodle. Hoow can I achieve this ? I have a few basic ideasas listed below but basically seems to be struck ! 1. Create a SCO (quiz created using html, jquery and css) in scorm 1.2 format and upload that sco to moodle. But How can i create a SCO in scorm 1.2 ? 2. or use jquery in blocks or themes as per moodle docs . I will basically create a quiz in jquery and add this as a block/theme plugin to moodle ! But how do I get the results of the quiz passed to moodle and get them graded by moodle ? Which is the best approach ? I am kinda struck here. please help !
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: I have done both. Both work fine, so long as you properly encapsulate jQuery and initialize it with noConflict(). If you really just want SCORM content, then package your jQuery in the SCORM package. That is loaded in an iframe and won't be impacted by libs in the parent page.
Comment 2: Hi, Thank you for your response. 1. So, as for your reply above, I can package Jquery into a scorm package and load it into an iframe. But How do I package Jquery Code ( html , css and js files ) into Scorm content. i am relatively new to Scorm 1.2. So, I assume we need to use a SCorm 1.2 wrapper for javascript ? Could you guide me with more information on this please ? 2. I will basically create a quiz in jquery and add this as a block/theme plugin to moodle ! But how do I get the results of the quiz passed to moodle and get them graded by moodle ? How do i really pass the information from a jquery quiz to moodle so that I can grade them in moodle ? Any help on this is much much appreciated ! Thank you Vishz
Comment 3: Unfortunately, external time constraints prevent me from instructing you on how to build SCORM content. Have a look at the resources here to get an idea of how JavaScript is packaged in SCORM packages: http://pipwerks.com/laboratory/scorm/api-wrapper-javascript/
Comment 4: Thank you ! This definitely was helpful Also I would greatly appreciate if you can shed some light on my second doubt : "But how do I get the results of the quiz created in jquery & Html passed to moodle and get them graded by moodle ? " Any ideas that I can actually look deeper into ? This would be beneficial rather than packaging my hquery code into scorm package. Also , while searching for above query I came across these block of lines from https://github.com/jewlofthelotus/SlickQuiz/blob/master/README.md : Want to manage your quizzes in a content management system? Simply translate your CMS quiz data into a JSON object formatted like "quizJSON" in js/slickQuiz-config.js. Then assign it as the quizJSON variable instead of loading js/slickQuiz-config.js. Would be glad if you can elaborate on this idead too , please...
Comment 5: Look at the same examples I referred you to before. The SCORM object uses a JavaScript wrapper to send data through the SCORM API. This is true whether the SCORM content is Flash-driven, JavaScript-driven, whatever. This resource (view the 1.2 version) will show you the data elements available to you via the SCORM API. The Pipwerks wrapper is a stable library with which to access that API. So you use your jQuery however you want to present content in the page, and when you want to save data, you just make a call using your wrapper of choice. http://scorm.com/scorm-explained/technical-scorm/run-time/run-time-reference/ To watch the API at work, you can turn on SCORM debugging in Moodle and watch the API log. I would recommend doing that with the Pipwerks samples.
Comment 6: Thank you Much. I will take deep dive and go through the wrapper !

Forum Post: 
Post title: importing a scorm module into moodle
Post description: Hi. I've installed moodle and I'm trying to import a scorm module. Moodle asks me for a moodle. xml file. The manifest file I have in the scorm module is imsmanifest.xml. Why doesnt it import. Im running moodle1.8 Thanks for any help... Luke
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: I'm having exactly the same problem with Moodle 1.8.2. Any suggestions would be gratefully received, please. Lynne
Comment 2: i thought you have to import a scorm package. moodle will unzip it and choose the imsmanifest by itself
Comment 3: That's what I thought too.  However, when I choose my SCORM zip file to upload , I get the attached message as soon as I click 'Save Changes'. (see attachment) I have checked the .xml file and it is as it should be, ImsManiFest.xml Any ideas?
Comment 4: The usual reason for getting this error is that you (or the app that created your SCORM package) has zipped the folder containing all the files as well as the files inside that folder. For Moodle to find the imsmanifest.xml file it must be inside the zip file at the root level, i.e. not down another level inside a folder. If it unzips the SCORM and all it finds is a folder, it doesn't then know to look inside this folder for the manifest. It just tells you it can't find what it's looking for. So if this turns out to be the reason for your error, you can do one of two things: Unzip the SCORM package yourself somewhere and then dive inside the folder (to the level where you should be able to see the imsmanifest.xml), select all, and then create another zip archive to upload to Moodle. If the imsmanifest is at the root level, Moodle should be happy. Alternatively, you can use Moodle to unzip the SCORM package you have currently uploaded to your Course Files, and then just choose the imsmanifest.xml file directly. Either way it should work. If for any reason it still doesn't work, check the forum archives for threads about early versions of Moodle 1.7 and 1.8 that had a code bug preventing imsmanifest.xml from being found. However, if you are using the latest version of Moodle (1.8.3) I believe this has long since been fixed.
Comment 5: Don't know whether this is relevant, but I opened my .xml file and found the following <schema> ADL SCORM </schema> <schemaversion> 1.0 </schemaversion> Not speaking coding, I'm hazarding a guess that this means that my zip file is SCORM 1.0, whereas the SCORM Activity Module recognises only SCORM 1.2 and AICC (according to http://moodle.org/mod/data/view.php?d=13&mode=single&page=191 ) Just a thought.  I might be on completely the wrong track, though! Lynne
Comment 6: i think that's only the schema version, not the scorm version. scorm versions differentiate by the way they call the interface, name of the functions called, and also the name of the variables stored. try to create the package with reload . works for me. you can also check if your scorm package is valid using the adl testing packages (they require java)

Forum Post: 
Post title: Updating a SCORM module why do learners still end up using the old one?
Post description: Hi I've recently started to manage the Moodle for our organisation so apologies if this is a simple thing - We have a fire refresher course which our staff have to refresh yearly. Earlier this year the old Moodle administrator replaced the existing fire course with an amended version. This has meant that learners who took the course last year and who are now taking it this year as part of their refresher are only seeing the old version? Would we need to reset the course or can force users to access the latest version?
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: When you revise a course that all students need to review, you need to create a "new" course and not just replace the existing content file. Managing content of revisions and annual training requirements for students is not a SCORM specific problem. In any LMS students that have an existing completion record for a course are not "required" by the LMS to retake a course. You could using a recomplete plug-in for your annual training requirements. I have not installed the plug-in, I does look very promising, however I have a basic old-school process I have been using: Back-up the current course. Restore the course as of the current date (not a day in the past) with a slightly different Short Name and Course ID (Fire Safety Training V1.1 or V2.0) - deselect retaining the student's current completions. If you need to pull grades or completion records in the future from the retired course, you cannot delete the course. Hide the superseded course and change the End Date to the date before the start date of the new course (yesterday). Consider moving it to another category (Retired courses) I normally remove all of the enrolled students and keep a log of the courses and date ranges - if I need to generate a grade report for a retired courses.

Forum Post: 
Post title: SCORM doesn't find API
Post description: Hi there, I've recently installed moodle 1.6, all things seems to run properly except for the SCORM, which displays an alert where it's said that API can't be found... This moodle runs on an Apache2 with MySQL 5. Any ideas 'bout what can it be? Thanks in Advance P.S. - register_globals are on! Hélio Rocha
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Found an answer: It seems that the player only loads the API when the SCO type is sco... Hope it helps someone.. Hélio Rocha
Comment 2: Hi, I am facing the same problem. Can you clarify by what you mean the SCO type is sco? Thanks!
Comment 3: Hi, every resource in a scorm package could be an asset (a resource without tracking interaction) or a sco (a resouce that get and set element from the LMS). In the imsmanifest. xml file in you scorm package every resource must defined as asset or sco. If you don't define your resources types, the SCORM Module set them as assets. Here you find two examples. 
```text
 



    <resource identifier='delta1' type="webcontent" adlcp:scormtype="sco" href="delta01.html">



    </resource>







    <resource identifier='gamma2' type="webcontent" adlcp:scormtype="asset" href="gamma02.html">



    </resource>
```
 Probably in your package some resources types are not defined or they are defined as assets. Please check the manifest file. Bobo.
Comment 4: Hi, but what is the right naming? In loadsco.php it is written "$sco = current ($scoes)" and in imsmanifest.xml I read "adlcp:scormtype="sco">" Cheers, Martin.
Comment 5: hi, i'm facing the same problem too. I have to carry out the update of version 1.5.3 to 1.6.2. There isn't problem, except the module scorm. When I try to visualize a package scorm the errors appear: - Unable to API find to adapt - Unable to locate the LMS' S API implemantation. LMS Initialize No successfull. if I replace the "asset" type by "sco" in the imsmanifest.xml file, there is no more this error but there is no more information of the "course made", or "partially made" or "finished" How to solve the problem???!! Thank you in advance for your assistance.
Comment 6: If you use 1.5.x and you get error about API you must edit the imsmanifest.xml file in your package in the way I said in http://moodle.org/mod/forum/discuss.php?d=49530#234691 post. If you use 1.6.x you still need to change your manifest file but you need to use 1.6.2+ or better 1.6.3 because in prior release there was a bug in scoring reporting. If you intend "completed", "incomplete", "passed" or "failed" for "course made", or "partially made" or "finished" this depends on what the SCO passes to Moodle SCORM Module. If no lesson status is passed you can't see it anywhere. If you can run a scorm package as administrator and with the Moodle debug mode enabled the SCORM Module will show you all the successful communication between SCO and SCORM Module. NOTE that administrator activities will tracked but not saved so you can see communication (in debug mode) but you can't see changes in SCORM module pages. Bobo.
Comment 7: Hi, I'm pretty new to Moodle, but I have been using Blackboard and some other LMS's with Flash and Captivate for awhile. If you are using Captivate, I've found that you need to change how SCORM looks for the API.  By default, it looks from the "Bottom Up".  You need to change the value.  After publishing a SCORM package using Captivate, open the HTML file that is created and look for the following line of code.  It should be somewhere in the first 30 lines: var g_intAPIOrder = 0; Change this value to a 1 and then try uploading it again.  This will cause SCORM to look for the API starting at the top.  This has almost always fixed the problem for me. Steve
Comment 8: Looking for the API from the top down is definitely not SCORM conformant. In addition, it guarantees that your SCO will not be compatible with any wrapper that might be necessary in the future to adapt it without recoding to work with SCORM 2004, for example. That setting in Captivate should be looked at as a desperate measure to deal with a particular nonconformant LMS. Moodle should not need it--look at the other hints earlier in the thread.
Comment 9: Hi, I know that top down is not SCORM conformant.  I am using Moodle without making any changes.  It was just a recommendation as something to try. I have used other LMS systems like Blackboard and WebCT that in "some" cases, the SCO package wasn't working properly and this change was a short-term work around until we could get the LMS to look at the package correctly. In an active semester, you don't always have time to work out LMS issues when you have upset professors and students that can't access their content, so you do something that gets the ball rolling until you can work out the details in your LMS. My post was not intended to be misleading, but just something to try.

Post title: replacing a scorm package when completion status required is enabled
Post description: When I try to replace (re- upload ) a new version of our scorm package, moodle throws a "error writing to database " error. Turning on php debug messages shows this: Debug info: Incorrect integer value: '' for column 'completionstatusrequired' at row 1 It's doing an update statement, in which I've identified the main problem - it's trying to insert an array as a single value... Here's the sql statement and it's matching parameters, in which i've highlighted the problematic fields. UPDATE mdl_scorm SET name = ?,scormtype = ?,updatefreq = ?,popup = ?,width = ?,height = ?,skipview = ?,hidebrowse = ?,displaycoursestructure = ?,hidetoc = ?,hidenav = ?,displayattemptstatus = ?,timeopen = ?,timeclose = ?,grademethod = ?,maxgrade = ?,maxattempt = ?,whatgrade = ?,forcenewattempt = ?,lastattemptlock = ?,forcecompleted = ?,auto = ?,launch = ?, completionstatusrequired = ? ,course = ?,intro = ?,introformat = ?,reference = ?,options = ?,timemodified = ? WHERE id=? [array ( 0 => 'Course Material', 1 => 'local', 2 => 0, 3 => '0', 4 => 100, 5 => 500, 6 => '2', 7 => '1', 8 => '0', 9 => '1', 10 => '1', The help associated with this item in the scorm package upload screen says: Checking one or more statuses will require a user to achieve at least one of the checked statuses in order to be marked complete in this SCORM activity, as well as any other Activity Completion requirements which confirms that I should be able to tick more than one status, however it's obvious that the field only accepts a single value. Is there a way to change the database to accept this value so that I don't have to keep turning off the completion status, then uploading, then re-enabling the settings?
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Hi Tim, it's a known issue: MDL-40095 . Please, update your installation. HTH , Matteo

Post title: SCORM activity is not "completed" but others are...
Post description: Hello everyone.  I’m
having a SCORM issue – completion status is not being captured by Moodle. I am not sure if Moodle is the problem or if the software I
use to create SCORM 1.2 lessons is the problem. 
I am using iSpring Presenter (latest version).  I am using 3.2 (Build: 20161205). When an activity is properly “completed”, I noticed in the
Moodle Log that there is an Event Name “ Submitted
SCORM status ” with the description “ The
user with the id ‘6’ submitted the element ‘cmi.core.lesson_status’ with the
value of ‘completed’ for the attempt with the id “1’ for a scorm activity with
the course module id ‘62’. ”. However, when a lesson is not shown as “completed”, this
statement does not appear in the logs. I have read about all the other possibilities where SCORM
results are not logged in Moodle but they do not resolve my issue.  I have tried the following: Making sure CRON jobs are running.  CRON seems to be doing its job because other
lessons work just fine. I checked the Save Tracks (mod/scorm:savetrack)
is set to Allow or Not Allow.  It doesn’t
seem to make a difference in my case since the log is showing some kind of increasing
score being passed along.  Also, student
roles do not have this permission Allowed yet they can complete SCORM lessons.  My admin account does have it enabled and I
can complete most lessons, except for this one. I checked the SCORM module “Compatibility
Settings” section and “Auto-commit” is Enabled. 
(it’s enabled by default on my lessons with the intent that a user can
continue where they left off). Then, in the SCORM module’s “Activity Completion”,
the following options are configured: Completion tracking:  Show activity as complete when conditions are
met. Require status: 
Completed (checked). I’m really at a loss why this lesson’s completion is not being
logged in Moodle since all my lessons are basically created with the same
template, and the same defaults are configured for all Activities in
Moodle.  Is the lesson somehow not
passing the completion flag to the LMS or is the SCORM LMS system buggy? Thanks!
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: For the benefit of everyone, I fixed my own problem, but this may come up again for someone else... The issue was not with Moodle.  I am using iSpring Presenter to create SCORM objects.  The software works great but if you have PowerPoint content, make sure you do not leave hidden slides in the presentation as doing so will never allow a student to "view all slides" to trigger a SCORM completion message.

Forum Post: 
Post title: Handling Multiple SCORM Quiz Attempts
Post description: We are using Moodle 2.7 and Storyline 2 for our SCORM authoring. What we want to achieve is the following: -- The student is presented a course that consists of two topics: 1) a SCORM-based quiz and 2) a certificate of completion. -- They can attempt the quiz no more than twice. -- If they pass it on one of their two attempts, the student can go to the next topic, which is the certificate of completion. -- If they fail both attempts, they do not get a certificate, and must instead take an entirely different course. We've tried to handle the limit of two attempts within the SCORM file by having the SCORM keep track of the number of failed attempts. If it is two, the SCORM does not allow the user to retry the quiz again. However, when the user exits the course after two failures and returns to it, they are dumped back into the course at the beginning of the quiz again. This isn't what we want. Instead, we'd like the user to be given a message about not being allowed to attempt the quiz again after failing twice. I'm beginning to wonder whether it would be better to handle the attempts within the SCORM or within Moodle.
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Don't really know storyline 2 but that all sounds like your scorm communication is not working at all or not set up correctly. Check settings at both ends (moodle and storyline) and make sure they match. Test by just moving on a couple of slides and then exiting and going back in. If it resumes from the same place then it is working. All possible as we do something similar (although with captivate). Scorm activity with only a set number of attempts in quiz. Passing that unlocks a certificate activity.
Comment 2: Hi Steve, as Sam mentions most of that should be possible. If you want to limit the number of attempts then you are better controlling this via Moodle (number of attempts allowed is an option in the SCORM settings). Resuming should work fine with Storyline (make ensure you have the resume where left off option on, which is my default). I've never been 100% sure that resuming part way through a quiz works (it's been hit and miss in previous versions of SL for me; maybe fixed in SL2, but it could be Moodle causing the issue too!). I prefer telling users to complete a quiz once they have started. Vispi.

Post title: Seeing Student Quizzes
Post description: I cant figure out how to access the students actual quiz after they attempt it. I can get report information but can the actual quiz be viewed? I created the Scorm in Adobe Captivate. Thanks, Andrew
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: SCORM results don't usually work this way - all that the SCORM report usually shows is a score/final grade - you can modify your SCORM object to report individual answers into the LMS (Moodle), but understanding that in the Moodle SCORM report - or setting your SCORM package to do this is rather difficult. The Quiz module in Moodle does a much better job of this and the reporting will do exactly what you need. I'd try putting your quiz there instead of your SCORM if possible!
Comment 2: Thanks Dan, I was thinking that putting it in Moodle was going to be the solution. I did do that for my last quiz and it went pretty well. My only issue is that there was an essay question at the end of the quiz and it was not too straightforward to see those answers either. It's a little awkward but still much better than grading by hand. Andrew

Forum Post: 
Post title: SCORM Exit Activity v 2.33
Post description: I've been scanning many of the posts here and don't see anything like my question... I'm currently running 1.9 but am working on an upgrade to 2.4/2.5 (if it is released in time) and have noticed differences I'm not sure represent proper behavior. In general, I find the SCORM functionality much improved in 2.33, which is the version I'm testing but there are a couple things that don't scan for me.  I'll start by describing 1.9 behavior and then describe what 2.33 does with the same scenario. In 1.9, I set all my modules to open in a new window.  I click the activity and get a the summary and an Enter button.  When you click the Enter button on a SCORM Activity, it changes the page to one when recommends turning off a pop-up blocker if a window doesn't open and includes an Exit Activity link AND opens the SCORM in a new window.  I added some custom text to the pop-up blocker page to provide extra stuff my users need, particularly if they have blockers on.  Users know to click Exit Activity or the course shortname in the breadcrumbs to get back to the course navigation page when they close the SCORM window. In 2.33, I also set all my modules to open in a new window.  When I click the activity, it provides the activity summary and a participation summary (like this: Number of attempts allowed: Unlimited; Number of attempts you have made: 0, Grading method: Highest attempt, Grade reported: None) with the Enter button.  I click Enter, the summary page doesn't change and the SCORM opens.  When I complete the SCORM and close, I'm still on the introductory SCORM screen but it still says I have no attempts, a score of 0, etc.  And (other than the course main page breadcrumb) there is no way to get back to course navigation.  If I refresh the page, it updates the information (still now way back to course nav). That's fine for me, I get what's going on.  Not so much for less computer skilled users. Some of my users really struggle to understand the breadcrumbs philosophy and need alternate navigation.  These same users will be confused and upset because they believe the module is not reporting (even though it is) and I envision chaos and craziness for months to come (I'm not sure how that's different from my current state but maybe just different chaos and crazy).  I could add information to address the discrepancy, but many users don't actually read the directions and that may be of limited value. Is there something I need to set to change the behavior?  Is it different in 2.4/2.5?  Ideas?

Post title: Moodle 2.5.1+  stopped recording SCORM progress
Post description: Everything was working fine and progress for students was being recorded, and now it sopped. The only change i can think of, was that we had to move the install from one account to another on the same dedicated hosting.  So, basically a new cPanel account on the same server , so all the installed software is the same. Steps we did: Moved Moodle folder and changed ownership (user/group) and permissions:  Folders 755 - Files 644 Also moved data folder and changed permissions:  to 777 (outside public_html) Lastly moved DB to new cPanel account and modified moodle config file. I can access the SCORM sessions but result is not recorded. Any hints on where I can look to try to fix this? Thanks
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: With the new account has your database name, configuration, username or password changed? I had a similar problem when I created a test environment, and I had to remove the Scorm Activity (not just the scorm package) and re-add it, and then everything tracked fine. That was on V2.6 btw . Hugh.
Comment 2: Thank you Hugh.  Yes, DB name and DB user changed. I ended up updating Moodle to 2.6.1+ and that did the trick.

Forum Post: 
Post title: Does SCORM allow branching scenarios?
Post description: I'm currently using Articulate to publish PowerPoint into flash/SCORM files. I have a large project that has some sophisticated requirements that are not possible with Articulate. I have a several-module course with between-module quizzes. Each quiz must be passed to advance to the next module. At the end of all of the modules there is a 20 question final assessment made up of questions from the different modules. A learner must earn at least 80 percent on the final assessment to complete the program. If a student scores 80 percent or better on the final assessment the course should be recognized as complete. If the student earns less than 80 percent, the student should be told how many were answered incorrectly and must be required to view the modules related to the questions that were missed. The modules in which the learner missed final assessment questions will be marked as incomplete and the student must fully complete these modules again before attempting another version of the final assessment. The student should only be required to re-take questions from the section in which they did not answer questions correctly. Learners do not need to be tested on the sections they have already completed successfully. The learner must retake the exam until a combined score of 80 percent is earned. For example, if the student answers 11 questions correctly and 9 incorrectly on the final assessment, he or she only needs to answer 5 of 9 questions correctly on the second version of the final assessment to demonstrate comprehension of the material. Learners will be allowed as many attempts as necessary to achieve an 80 percent score. Multiple versions of the final assessment will be used to pull new questions from the sections in which the student is answering questions incorrectly. Does SCORM permit this level of sophistication? If yes, do you know of any authoring tools that have these features? If SCORM is the limitation, rather than the authoring tool, can you recommend another route for me to solve this problem?
