Forum Post: 
Post title: Macromedia Authorware SCORM content - path issues
Post description: Hi, This is an issue with a potential customer who is using Moodle. We've had no problem uploading and running a SCORM course. However, this relies on a full set of Authorware runtime files being present on the workstation. If these files are not present, the Authorware Web Player starts throwing up file not found errors when attempting to download from withing the Moodle environment. From previous experience this is a problem with file.php generating the correct path. I've forwarded everthing I've found in the FAQ regarding file.php and paths (that is, the settings to change in Apache and IIS ) but I'd really like to hear of any similar experiences other users have had with Authorware and Moodle - and especially if this is resolvable. Thanks in advance, Alistair
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: As the potential customer we have found that disabling the Add-on in Explorer, then reloading the course, prompts for the download from the Macromedia website, which if followed, re-installs the Add-on, which requires re-enabling. Without restarting Explorer, the course then loads up correctly. As soon as the Explorer window is closed however, the error re-occurs. So it would seem that the problem is with the add-on from Macromedia or in Explorer - it seems to be only valid for the current open Explorer window! So file.php is not the problem...it's the add-on and browser! Macromedia may have the answer..... (Tried with Firefox and the course does not load at all - is this expected?) Peter Duncliffe
Comment 2: OK, I've sussed this one. The problem was actually a very simple one. The Authorware runtime file list can be specified in two separate files (for logistical reasons). Once I'd changed the extension of one of those files - all started to work fine. I'm guessing that its original .txt extension was in some way preventing the contents from either being served or processed properly. I'm still at a loss to explain why all worked fine when the Web Player installer window was still open. I guess some things are just meant to be left unexplained! I did have a previous report (from over a year ago) that the file.php/Authorware combination was causing some of the runtimes to fail to download. However, I really can't say if that was a red herring or perhaps a separate, since resolved, issue. I just wanted to say that that's where I got the idea that somehow file.php was involved. Alistair PS Just out of interest, how many Moodlers are using Authorware to deliver content?
Comment 3: I'm linking to my Authorware pieces but they will not run when embedded.
Comment 4: I'm able to embed my authorware pieces but not if they are uploaded to the moodledata folder

Forum Post: 
Post title: Why no SCORM generation plugin?
Post description: Why is there no plugin that generates SCORMs? Or is there one?
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Ummm...that would be an authoring software. Or H5P, which isn't SCORM but does a lot of the similar things. There was a plugin in the dark ages call eXe that was sort of SCORM that you would build directly into Moodle. Originally created in NZ and being GPU, it was free and since there was a lot of NZ interest in Moodle, it plugged in and worked...okay.  It was fine and lots of people liked it. Don't really know what happened but it lost its dev support ~'10 (maybe, possibly earlier) and kinda died in NZ. It was adopted by an organization (in maybe Spain? I thought maybe South America but I think the documentation implies Spain and most of the documentation is in Spanish) later on and was renamed eXeLearning. The name causes all sorts of red flags for security types. I looked at their site and saw activity as recently as last year. It says only publishes as SCORM 2004 or epub. Since Moodle isn't SCORM 2004 compliant, could be a problem. That said it also says for Moodle they recommend 1.2, so maybe if you look harder than I did, you'll find it does publish to 1.2. I don't find it in the Moodle plugins database . There is some talk on their support forums about integration with Moodle in 2020-early 2021. A couple of their FAQ's refer to moodle as examples but it no longer looks like it is possible to use is as an in-site dev tool. It looks pretty good though, if you're looking for something low-cost. I think it is still free. edit: when I say dark ages...I mean Moodle 1.9 and earlier. I don't know that I saw anything moodle specific on eXe since before I upgraded to 2.X...
Comment 2: Because nobody has created one, probably because there are so many stand alone SCORM tools. The future for similar functionality is probably H5p.
Comment 3: What standalone SCORM creation tool would you recommend? I tried ScormHero and it was limited. And Articulate is very expensive. Ideally I would like something that generates a SCORM from what we have in Moodle.
Comment 4: I don't think you'll find people (here) recommending SCORM authoring tools other than Articulate - I have a recent article about this here which shares my thoughts in a little more detail too: https://www.catalyst.net.nz/blog/scorm-expert-stop-publishing-new-scorm-content but high level - don't do it... use H5P or native tools within the LMS instead - especially if you already have Moodle as your LMS.
Comment 5: Our content is licensed to companies for installation in their LMS. That's why we package the content as SCORM. We use Moodle for our own trainees because it is far more powerful and feature-rich than Articulate. But we have been using Articulate merely to generate SCORMs. Seems like a waste to pay for Articulate just to do that.
Comment 6: so.... you have clients that still pay you for SCORM packages that have already developed in articulate? - in that case just build it into your pricing - longer term you could start moving clients away from SCORM and to LTI (where their LMS supports it.) - that way you can make Moodle the content provider and just expose the content using LTI instead - Moodle is also putting a lot of effort into improving LTI at the moment, so it will give you a lot of flexibility.
Comment 7: This is the first I have heard of LTI! Thanks for mentioning it! To be clear, we develop the content in Powerpoint, but for our own learning students we use Moodle as the LMS. But we have external clients who want to license our content: for those, we use Articulate to package the content into SCORMs. What kind of workflow would you recommend?
Comment 8: LTI is a very good standard and the powers that be at Moodle HQ are going to continue to work on improving it.
Comment 9: I really like Lectora. But it is expensive too (though the web version is less so, but is a somewhat different product than the desktop, but good, I use it). I use camtasia when I have video that I want to track people completing. It isn't brilliant SCORM but it's okay. Reporting can be a little glitchy. I have historically used Captivate for software tutorials. But 1) I HATE Captivate, 2) I don't need the mouse movements and scrolly stuff--I just need them to see what they should do. Unless I want them to actually do the things to practice, I can just use static images and make H5P. The only thing I like about captivate is the ability to make things do stuff on the screen. Which I can do to a certain extent in Lectora, not a flash (not like the program, just, you know, fancy) but still serviceable and less irritating. And H5P isn't just Moodle. It can be developed on the H5P site and used in other LMS products. The H5P site might not be free but it is substantially less expensive, I suspect. One advantage on H5P is the ease of editing. you don't have to republish--you change, save and it's done. And it isn't taking up space in your computer--just the server where it is hosted/lives/was developed. I'm not saying I'm switching to H5P exclusively but I'll switch where I can.
Comment 10: I just had a thought. I think...for what you want, iSpring might be a good option. In the dark ages, there was a free version. The website looks like it is still free. Maybe. There is also a paid version, which is not as expensive as the other mentioned products ($700-$800/year) but still $$. The free version lets you publish ppts to scorm and has limited adding questions features. Pretty rudimentary but if that's all you want, it works. I don't remember how reliable the modules were for reporting.

Post title: PHP files not parsing when loaded by file.php
Post description: I am experiencing a problem with a SCORM course that uses .php scripts. When the course is launched from the LMS, it is opened by file.php. When file.php sends the .php file to the browser it doesn't parse the .php scripts. Depending on how I set up the files it will either display them as text or try to download them. Has anyone ever experienced this problem before, or do you have any helpful suggestions? I have scoured the Moodle docs , forums and Google and haven't been able to find anything about this.
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: I am facing the same problem and I would appreciate if anyone could give us a solution or suggestion. Thanks in advance.
Comment 2: Hi, this is a protection in Moodle to not execute malicious php code, Moodle just pass the requested file to the browser. An other thing is that SCORM packages can't contains server side scripting code because they must be also view offline. HTH , Roberto
Comment 3: hello! at the first sorry for my english I have the same problem, what can i do for integrate quiz (qcm) with a script php in a package scorm; I want to create evaluations in a package scorm, and recover the results to authorize the passage towards the following chapter if student had a note more than 50%, he passes in the following chapter else he takes again the current chapter please, what can i do ? thank's cheers
Comment 4: Roberto already answered the question. A SCORM package cannot contain a php script. Here is Claude Ostyn's explanation in his book In the Eye of the SCORM Server-dependent content Many content developers would like to be able to claim SCORM conformance for content that is delivered through an active server, such as .php, .asp or .jsp pages. Obviously these are not files that can be included in the package, since they are generated on the fly. ... Since such content is not self-contained, it cannot be reliably archived or transported and it cannot be used offline without recreating the server functionality on the client machine. The content does not conform to the spirit of the SCORM because it is not portable and cannot be delivered by generic Web servers without installing some specific active components on the server. There is currently no standard way to specify such an installation.
Comment 5: hello! thank you very much john! for your answer and your orientation. but please what can i do to make my course adaptive, i.e the passage of a chapter to the following will be conditioned in an automatic way. " student cannot study chapter 2 without it being good in chapter 1 " thank's best regards
Comment 6: You can't control the sequence in SCORM 1.2. Sequence control is one of the main new features in SCORM 2004. According to MDL-7098 , sequencing is partially implemented in Moodle 1.8. However I don't think it is activated. You will have to research this further.
Comment 7: ok thank's john received message! best regards

Forum Post: 
Post title: SCORM Launch – Force IE 10 Browser Mode (Not Compatibility)
Post description: Hello, and thanks in advance for any insight anyone can
provide! Issue/Question: How can I force IE 10 Browser mode (not compatibility
view) when a SCORM course is launched? Background: I have a course that works perfectly in
IE9.  We recently upgraded to IE10.  The course navigation buttons do not work in
IE10 compatibility mode.  I did some
troubleshooting with a Trivantis tech rep (it is a Lectora title) who stated
the course will work properly if the LMS will run it in regular IE 10 mode.  When I change the browser setting from IE
10 Compat View to IE 10 , the
settings do not remain intact when the course launches in a new window.  The window which displays the course
defaults back to IE Compat View.  When I
try to change the setting in the new window (which isn’t the ideal solution
anyway) it gives me an error ‘A required (scoid) was missing. Any and all assistance is greatly appreciated! Pam
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Hello Pam, You did not mention which version of Moodle you are using or if you are using a custom theme.  Based on your description it sounds like the theme may be forcing IE 10 into compatibility mode.  I recommend first trying the clean Theme to see if this helps. Another possibility is that the browser itself is set to display the site in compatibility mode.  Check the "Compatibility View Settings" in IE. If nothing else helps you can customize the theme you are using to force IE to display in one of the modes.  To do this you will first need to identify the theme you are using, and how you are launching the course; Embedded or New Window.    If you are using "Embedded" then locate the embedded.php layout file for your them and modify it.  If you are using "New Window" then locate the "popup.php" layout for your theme. One you have identified the correct layout file, open it and add the following line in the <head> section: <meta http-equiv="X-UA-Compatible" content="IE=Edge" /> This will tell IE to operate in it's normal version unless it is over-ridden with an IE setting.  You can also change Edge to a version number.  However, setting the version number to say IE=10 will not make IE 9 act like 10, it will still only be IE 9.
Comment 2: Ron, Thank you so much for taking the time to respond.  Your guidance helped solve my issue. Although IE was not set to run in compatibility mode, the
site which our Moodle is hosted from was unknowingly set to do so as a Group
Policy Object.  We removed from one machine
to test and IE stayed in normal mode when the SCORM was launched in a new
window. We will this update org wide soon.  In the meantime, I added the line you
provided to the popup.php layout file. 
That worked perfectly! Thanks again for your help; I really appreciate you taking
the time to assist!

Post title: Moodle 2 SCORM bug with subdirectories in zip
Post description: Hi, I was just testing our SCORM module with your new Moodle 2 at demo. moodle.net . There have been no problems with the previous Moodle 1.6. In the new version however, it seems that Moodle 2 is unable to use any files from the uploaded SCORM zip package if they are under a subdirectory. The files that are located in the root of the zip file are accessible and can be loaded, but most of our study material is in a data -subfolder and now all of that data is inaccessible. If you wish, I can upload a demo scorm package - the size is 1,5 MB though.
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: subdirectories should work ok - it's possible you have a corrupt zip that works by "fluke" on 1.9 installs - please create a tracker issue and e-mail me a copy of your scorm object (my e-mail is listed on my Tracker profile.) - please include complete details in the tracker of the issue you have (including screenshot if poss) and what product you used to generate your SCORM
Comment 2: I use Classic RELOAD Editor found at http://www.reload.ac.uk/new/editor.html .

My SCORM package has a tree structure of items, that is,
in RELOAD Editor Content Package pane, there is a tree structure like
Organizations/Organization/Item1/Item2.

Moodle 2 SCORM player doesn't play Item2.
When I remove Item1 and place Item2 on the top of the Organization, that is,
I change the structure into Organizations/Organization/Item2, it works.
Comment 3: "please .... provide a scorm object that allows us to reproduce your issues." also - makes sure you are using SCORM 1.2 and not 2004
Comment 4: Hi, I have uploaded a SCORM package that I used for testing on friday to: http://download.typingmaster.com/misc/TMSCORM-eng-TouchTyping.zip We have created the SCORM package ourselves as part of a product that allows customers to create typing courses that can be loaded into SCORM conformant LMSs. This package has been verified to be SCORM 1.2 conformant with the ADL test suite. It also unzips fine with the unzip command on an Ubuntu Linux box as well as in Windows. BTW : The file upload limits have become stricter now on http://demo.moodle.net (1 meg?) and because of this, it is no longer possible to upload this file for testing.
Comment 5: that Zip file is corrupt - it uses slashes in the filenames instead of valid directories. it will unzip fine on windows, but on linux machines it unzips with slashes in the filename - which confuses Moodle 2.0 file handling processes. Unzip the file on windows(which will work for some reason) - then re-zip on windows and upload the newly zipped file and it will probably work fine. Moodle 1.9 worked by "fluke" on linux machines due to theway the old file handling worked, but 2.0 requires your zip to use valid directories. here's another post with the same issue: http://moodle.org/mod/forum/discuss.php?d=158881 what did you use to generate the zip?
Comment 6: Ah! That was it. Thanks so much! I was generating the files on a Windows machine where it added the backslashes, on the linux production server the files worked. We just use the built in java .util.zip classes to generate the zip. I'll fix it to always use forward slashes in filenames.

Comment 3: The ad-hoc contributed reports are available as a plugin, which I believe Moodle Cloud users do not have access to. Also, the SCORM reports posted on the site, are old and the tables have changed. I briefly explored the Custom Reports on the " orange demo " site and I don't believe SCORM attempts are supported at this think. Comment 4: Did you try to download the report and work with it in Excel?
Comment 5: Scorm is simply an API - it offers a way to interact with the php databases of Moodle. You are asking too much.
Comment 6: No it's not. It is a e-learning standard. Actually, the most popular one. Besides API, it has very large data model that is used to collect and transfer data such as time spent, score, lesson status, lesson location, etc.... The real reason why we don't see the scorm data in course reports very often is it's complexity. Each course can have multiple scorm activities , each scorm can have multiple attempts recorded for each user. Each attempt can be used for multiple days when user is accessing the same scorm activity multiple times within the same attempt. Each scorm can have multiple SCOs - something like lessons within scorm activitiy. Each SCO has it's own set of data recorded in the database , such as time spent, score, lesson status, etc... I also use custom reporting for this kind of things, but different plugin - more advanced and feature-rich Configurable Reports. I know that some people don't like that this plugin loads the complete recordset initially before you can apply any filters to narrow down the results, but I also have SQL solution for this and it doesn't need any plugin or Moodle code modification (no php or js coding needed).
Comment 7: @Zoran, I'd love to see the SQL queries you are using for this if you are able to share. I recently perfected my own SQL query to summarize the time difference between time stamps in the prefix_logstore_standard_log table, based on the 'User's accumulative time spent in course" query in ad-hoc contributed reports . But I am only using it for non- SCORM activities since it wasn't giving me accurate times for SCORM activities. Andy

I have posted this path issue in a seperate topic.

Forum Post: 
Post title: SCORM 3.3 and screen readers...
Post description: So, I'm testing a SCORM with a screen reader, which is a horrible thing.  Here are some things I'm seeing.  If I have the scorm open in the current window (which is preferred by my agency), the screen reader seems to have trouble reading the content--It wants to read everything but the package slides.  We're currently using Boost and I'm starting to hate the collapsible thing on the left that is supposed to replace blocks.  Even when minimized it wants to read all of it. So my real question...What are the best SCORM settings to use to get screen readers to read scorm content?  I know there is a lot of stuff I need to do inside my module (Captivate does NOT make it easy) but the settings and theme seem just as important.  Anyone else trying to make scorm accessibility compliant modules? What do you do?
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: If your goal is to develop content that is accessible your first mistake is probably trying to do this in SCORM. You would likely get a much better result using a different tool - like the lesson activity in Moodle. SCORM is heavily geared towards javascript , the authoring tools are heavily geared towards "visual display" - you have a lot more control over the accessibility of your content in the lesson module - and it's often much faster to develop the content in Lesson that it is in something like articulate.
Comment 2: Thanks, Dan.  I know Lesson is more likely to not cause those sorts of problems...and how to build in it, etc. Sigh.  But if the push is to do it in Captivate...are there particular settings that work best?
Comment 3: I would say you would definitely want to open the scorm package in it's own window then atleast, but I don't have direct experience with this myself.
Comment 4: Is it NOT possible to make SCORM ACCESSIBILITY FRIENDLY? Today it is imperative to follow the standards of Universal Design for Learning (UDL).
Comment 5: The latest versions of Articulate/Captivate do this better than they used to, but SCORM is still SCORM. As mentioned, it would be better to use the built in content authoring tools within Moodle (like Lesson/Quiz etc.) - but another good alternative is H5P

Forum Post: 
Post title: scorm settings - adjusting suspend_data
Post description: Can anyone advise me how I would check and amend the suspend data configuration in moodle  ? I'm having issues with resume from where left off, when you log back on with my course Understand that scorm 1.2 supports 4096 characters . How do I check to see if my moodle site is configured to this ? version : Moodle 3.1.6 (Build: 20170508)
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Go to: Admin > plugins > activities > SCORM find the setting called SCORM standards mode.
Comment 2: I don't suppose there are any plans to make moodle support scorm 2004 ?
Comment 3: we tried.. no-one cared about it enough to fund the development effort required. more info: https://moodle.org/mod/forum/discuss.php?d=227906 https://danmarsden.com/blog/2013/05/06/stopping-work-on-scorm-2004
Comment 4: Hi Dan Thank you for taking time out to reply I found the setting , its a case of ticking or un ticking the box " Enable SCORM 1.2 standard mode " is it not ? If I tick the box, I assume it permits resume from where left off and if its left un ticked it doesn't resume at all, is that correct ( that seems to be how it is behaving ? ) ? It doesnt really help me with the resume issue as it;s not resuming exactly from where it left off, is there any solution to that problem ? Thanks
Comment 5: "ticked" - it follows the SCORM spec which restricts the amount of data that can be stored in suspend_data. "unticked" - it lets the SCORM package store more than is usually allowed by SCORM 1.2. Obviously that will also only work for "new" attempts. If leaving it unticked doesn't help you with resume issues it's likely the SCORM package you are using doesn't support resuming in the way you want it to.
Comment 6: Thanks Dan for advising on this and the scorm 2004 support issue.
Comment 7: Hi Dan I tested my file on scorm cloud and I had the same issue, with resume. I was just wondering if there is anything obvious in the second debug report that would indicate why it doesnt resume almost at all in scorm cloud

Forum Post: 
Post title: Regression in latest stables preventing some teachers from updating/creating scorm
Post description: The security fix for MSA-24-0001 (Denial of service risk in file picker unzip functionality) which was included in 4.3.3, 4.2.6 and 4.1.9 now means that the "private files space" or userquota setting is now also used when a teacher tries to update a scorm package. Depending on what your debugging levels are set to, you may see errors like: " Exception - array_keys(): Argument #1 ($array) must be of type array, null given" Or entry to your updated SCORM package may just show an empty box instead of the SCORM package you are expecting. More information on this is here (and some of the related bugs) https://tracker.moodle.org/browse/MDL-81060 In the meantime, if you are affected by this bug, you may need to increase your private files limits for teachers so they can upload or update existing SCORM packages. Moodle's SCORM code basically only tries to unzip the package again if it sees the file is different from the one it already has - so if you have a teacher that has broken their SCORM activity due to this bug, you need to modify the scorm zip slightly (I added a text file called 0.txt to some packages I was fixing this week.) then get someone that doesn't have that userquota limit to upload the new scorm (or increase the userquota limit to get around it.)

Forum Post: 
Post title: Does review mode work? (In Moodle 2.8)
Post description: Hello (Dan), I have tried several SCORM packages (famous Golf example, some latest Articulate 2 packages, some samples from the internet, some samples that I accumulated from the tracker) And although I am seeing "review mode" on the SCORM player screen, I never seem to get the package to display my attempt's choices. btw , I always "complete" the package and make sure all the data is saved in Moodle (using the API debugger and viewing the report tab). Do you (anyone) have a package I can test?
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Hi Nadav, I don't personally have any packages that do this - I know that this is tested in the SCORM ADL 1.2 compliance tests which Moodle passed last time I checked them (which was a while ago) and that it's completely up to the SCORM package itself what to do when Moodle passes the review mode flag. Some SCORM packages will allow a new score to be written and others will just show a read-only view of the SCORM package and exclude the users prior responses. Review mode is basically just a "flag" that Moodle passes to the SCORM package to signify that a previous attempt was completed and the user has not elected to generate a new attempt.
Comment 2: Hi Dan, Thank you very much for your detailed response. It confirmed my understanding while examining the code. but I was a little unsure after reading through some of the closed and open issues in the Tracker that were related to mode review.
Comment 3: BTW, Storyline (v2) display a notice after I re-enter a previous finished or unfinished attempt (Moodle display a "review mode" when the attempt was "completed") and ask me if "I want to continue that last attempt", which can act like a "review mode" but if I say NO it reset that attempt and I can never "review" or "continue were I left" anymore. Not sure if this is Storyline's way of displaying "review mode".
Comment 4: FYI : A link to a discussion (" Storyline review mode not being evaluated properly ") I am having with Articulate's support team, about this issue in Storyline 2.
Comment 5: After discussion with Jastin from Articulate, which showed me that the Storyline 2 publishes SCORM 1.2 packages that support REVIEW mode with out any issues. I can sum up this discussion with the conclusion that Moodle 2.8 together with Storyline 2 have no bugs related to the review mode.
Comment 6: Hi Nadav, thanks for the update! BTW, if you want to play with Moodle and SCORM for general deep investigations, please use the Diagnostic SCO for SCORM runtime by Claude Ostyn : you can create your own SCORM scripts as a set of API calls and see how Moodle reacts on those calls. HTH , Matteo
Comment 7: I'm finding I'm having the same issue with moodle 2.7 and 2.8.5.  You upload a SCORM 1.2 package, take it and suspend.  But on re-launch it is in 'review' mode and is no longer allowing the student to continue the attempt.  This is also true if you launch in 'browse' mode.  The Runtime will no longer allow LMSSetValue calls (typically).  Seems like Moodle still does. Review mode means the student is reviewing their work or the teacher is reviewing the students work. "review”: The SCO has previously recorded information about the learner attempt and is presented without the intent of updating this information with data from the current learner session. cmi.core.lesson_status 'completed' doesn't coorilate to the student being done.  cmi.exit of any other type than 'suspend' designates the end of the attempt.  I've seen other posts claiming that if the score is set (mine is 11%) it will launch in review mode. I cannot locate a solution for this, but I believe Moodle is serving the Runtime up incorrectly in this situation or there is a parameter hidden in the structure to stop it from doing this.
Comment 8: Seems like after further review SCORM 1.2 didn't do a great job of dictating the behavior and this was corrected in SCORM 2004. As it stands, it looks like moodle will allow you to keep calling LMSSetValue in review mode.  So your SCO now has to effictively manage different LMS behavior too.
Comment 9: Yes - Moodle is operating as per the SCORM specification. with SCORM 1.2 the LMS is responsible for setting the mode but the SCORM package is responsible for deciding what to do when that flag is set.

Forum Post: 
Post title: Generating / inserting SCORM objects created by other Moodle components
Post description: Hello, I've written a little Flash-based applet to do on-screen jigsaw puzzles. This hooks up with a bit of PHP / Moodle server -based code that gets the original image off the (teacher) user, chops it up into several pieces, each in a new sperate image file, and shoves the whole lot in a Zip file. I'd like to add SCORM tracking facilities to the client-side part of this utility, then I could use SCORM to store state information about the jigsaw, i.e. use an XML string to store the position of each jigsaw piece so that the (pupil) user can leave off doing a jigsaw part-way through and come back to it later without having to completly restart. So, I've done SCORM-based stuff before, that's no problem, and it should be easy enough to add a few JavaScript files to the Zip file my utility generates and tada, I've got a SCORM-complient jigsaw utility. However, for a (teacher) user in Moodle to use this Zip file as a SCORM object in their course they'll have to download the generated Zip file, then create a new SCORM object in their course and upload that Zip file again. This is rather fiddly and introduces more steps than the average teacher has the patience for. What I would like is for my utility to be able to generate a SCORM-complient Zip archive, then have it insert this archive into a course as a SCORM object. Then, the (teacher) user just sees a nice two-or-three-step wizard type of interface where they add a picture, enter a few details, and their jigsaw appears as an object in their Moodle course. They don't even have to know it uses SCORM, there'll just a be a "Download a SCORM archive of this jigsaw" link on the setup page. One way for me to implement this would be to clone the existing SCORM module, adding a few bits to the setup form relevant to my jigsaw utility. This, however, seems rather a duff way of going about it - is there a more sensible way? --

Comment 1: Moodle is missing the tracking and control mechanism you need for a SCORM flow. Why not create small exercises or complete SCORM courses in editors like Reload/CP and then import them as SCORM-modul (for the small exercise) or for the big ones as a complete course (available in Moodle 1.6) ? Forum Post: 
Post title: Increasing CHECKNET SCORM alerts
Post description: I'm trying to implement increasing 'checknet' scorm alert time from 2 seconds to 10 seconds and 5 seconds to 30 seconds by replacing the values in the below lines. https://github.com/andrewnicols/moodle/compare/9b8555f...MDL-28261-master#diff-36c25f107c03eedc54bad515788e3bffR150 https://github.com/andrewnicols/moodle/compare/9b8555f...MDL-28261-master#diff-36c25f107c03eedc54bad515788e3bffR163 I have tested it in my local machine both in debug and live environments. While on debug environment I've tested it by updating the values in 'moodle-core-checknet-debug.js' file and on live environment 'moodle-core-checknet-min.js' (timeout:{value:10e3},frequency:{value:30e3}). I'm aware that, it is not recommended to update any of the core files as it will get overwritten in the system update. I also understand from the documents/discussions that it may affect the usage tracking. Request your valuable inputs on this: Any safety measure which I could take, to avoid and issues Any suggestions you may have I think earlier, I had posted under a wrong category, https://moodle.org/mod/forum/discuss.php?d=331583 Thank you in advance.
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Hi Valshak, I've had these tweaked in our installation to actually be a 10 second timeout and checked every 90 seconds. With the default values we had lots of students reporting these messages even when tracking was working fine. We also had one issue where an organization that uses our system had bandwidth limitation issues, which is why we ended up at a 10 second timeout. I think this is basically a test and see case, where you have to tweak things to suit your specific audience/system.
Comment 2: Dear Mathew, Thank you for your reply. From different user's experience increasing the time delay has not affected the usage tracking unless they have a 'REAL' network access. Let me try it out and experiment.
Comment 3: I'm surprised to see you saying it is currently set to 2 seconds in your installation - we increased it a while ago: https://git.moodle.org/gw?p=moodle.git;a=commitdiff;h=552281e461e440a1df59c7ecae313d46fe35f3c3;hp=06122e46fd16891787a08e9e3125465bea83eaf5 you probably want to upgrade your site to a more recent stable supported version of Moodle.
Comment 4: Hi, Has anyone tried it for 10 sec and >100 sec respectively? Just to add to my knowledge base, I would like to hear your view points on this. Thanks.
Comment 5: Thank you Dan, sorry for the late reply. I just want to confirm, what are the precautions I should take before making these change live?
Comment 6: I'm surprised to see so much effort put into this... upgrading your site would increase the timeout values (and we haven't had the same number of false-positives with the higher values) - If you have upgraded and are still getting these pop-up warnings you should really focus on what is causing the problem at your server (rather than hiding the problem by increasing the values.) SCORM requires a stable/reliable internet connection. If your server doesn't provide this you should fix it or find another hosting solution. If your users need offline-access to SCORM packages or in areas where internet connectivity is not good you should look at using the Moodle mobile app which provides offline support for SCORM. Whenever you change Moodle code files you should perform appropriate testing to ensure it works as expected - yes you should clear the cache. Yes you should implement some form of backup procedure.. If these things are difficult you should probably not be changing the code.
Comment 7: Thank you. I understand the risk of increasing the time, and as of now we are not looking for offline access. In terms of backup procedure, what are the files/directories we should be taking the backup of? Ones I think are, The files changed (checknet files changed here ) Moodle data directory (Does replacing this directory post purging cache help?) Any other file/directory should I backup? Please let me know.
Comment 8: If you are only changing the files related to checknet timings the changed files are probably the only ones you really need to backup but you should really be running some form of regular off-site backup of your database and moodledata.
Comment 9: Hi Vaishak, purging the cache only effects the caching part of the moodledata directory, which is meant to be disposable anyways. When I was doing this, I can confirm all I did was update the files as you mention in part 1, and purge the cache via the Moodle admin interface. In terms of restoring from this, you would only need to restore the changed files you mention in part 1, and re-purge the cache. Seperately as Dan said, you should be backing up moodledata regularly, 3,2,1 backup methodology recommended. Veeam has a good post about this, you don't need to be using their software to do it though: https://www.veeam.com/blog/how-to-follow-the-3-2-1-backup-rule-with-veeam-backup-replication.html We rsync to a secondary server daily, and then do a tape backup of that periodically. So we have 3 locations (tape backup, backup server and live), two media (server hdd and tape) and one copy stored offsite (tape).

Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Joaquín, I have not had a chance to play with the prerequisites yet.  However I have been meaning to. As for your issue about the multiple organizations.  They do work. The key though for now is making sure you identify a default in the <organizations> element. See the last couple of entries in this thread for further info - http://moodle.org/mod/forum/discuss.php?d=7951 Before I share my multiple organization sample I have to make some changes.  Maybe I will incorporate the prerequisites in it and see if I can get those to work. Hope this helps. Chris
Comment 2: Joaquín, Sorry it's been a few days.  I did modify one of my test courses to use prerequisites and the are not adhered to by the moodle SCORM mod.  I am not sure if Bobo has any plans to further the code to handle this part of the spec.  But if he does I am sure he will comment. How has your luck been with multiple organizations?
Comment 3: Hello!!! I understand u when u say that with a default organization you can access it. But my question is that when i have different students accesing to different organizations, how can i decide to which of these courses (organization) they can access. If this is not posible, how can i do this without "making" two courses separatedly, better if is using the same SCORM package or some of this. Have you tried this? Another thing is that seeing the pics in the SCORM module of Moodle, I see that there is a lot of pics, the name of this are Completed, Passed, etc. the same that the prerequisite rules, this suggest something, no? Thanks a lot, Joaquín
Comment 4: Your question is actually an LMS functionality issue.  The SCORM spec only provides the means for identifying multiple organizations.  The LMS developer would have to provide the ability to lock a learner into a specific organization structure.  There are LMSs out there that does this in different manners.  Some allow the learner to choose the organization and then lock them into that choice, others allow the instructor to choose the prefered structure. With moodle-SCORM mod the multiple organizations functionality is still new and with time it may grow to accomodate different scenerios. As for your question on the Completed, Passed, etc. - yes this does get used if the LMS developer plans to handle prerequisites.  However, the support for prerequisites in not a mandatory requirement that LMSs must provide support for. Hope this helps. Also, here is my multi organization example as promised in prior post.

Post description: Hello everybody! I'm trying to put some SCORM activities in my class, published from CourseLab. Everything is doing well. I tried to change the grading method but nothing helped. Is there a way to change this? Or at least, to show a message, instead of Score:0? Thank you in advance for your help.
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Hi Ilona, There has to be a single score coming out of the SCORM activity so it can get into the gradebook. The way that that score is calculated is documented here: http://docs.moodle.org/en/SCORM_FAQ#SCORM_and_the_Gradebook If you need more information on what data elements are utilized for those calculations: http://www.scorm.com/scorm-explained/technical-scorm/run-time/run-time-reference/ http://docs.moodle.org/en/SCORM_FAQ#SCORM_Information

Post title: Resizing of screens for SCORM activities
Post description: I'm very new to Moodle 1.9 and having problems getting my SCORM activities created in Atlantic Link software to display on screen correctly. I have set the course resolution at 1024x768. When I open the activity in Moodle the screen is too big, so I have to scroll around to reach the navigation buttons at the bottom. The guys at Atlantic Link think it might be possible for Moodle to automatically resize to the correct resolution, but are not sure how. I can't see anything in the activity settings that might do it. Can you help? Jane Hall
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Hi Jane, You can set the size of the new window a sco opens in (in pixels). But making calculations based on screen resolution is something that the Moodle activity will not do. There are scorm activities I've seen (Articulate comes to mind) where the new window is resized via JavaScript once the scorm content starts to load. But that would be precipitated by the SCORM files (HTML, JS, SWF) and not by Moodle. Best, -A
Comment 2: dear all, i have the same problem with jane, so is there any solution that can help me get through this problem? how to configure the SCORM files maybe? regards,
Comment 3: I'm so glad I'm not the only one struggling with this! Did you see Amy's original reply (below)? Subsequent to that I've asked the question elsewhere and am waiting to hear back with a possible solution. If I get one, I'll pass it on to you. Forum Post: 
Post title: IMS export-import
Post description: I did not find IMS subforum, so I post here. I got an e-book resource on one Moodle site and I can export it to IMS. Then I want to import it in another site. But, the format I exported (and downloaded)  is folder with manifest and stuff. And when I want to add an IMS and upload a proper file (on another site), what format am I supposed to give it? I got folder and I need a file. I tried to zip it, but it wont take it.
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: the imsmanifest. xml needs to be immediately inside the zip directory, NOT inside a directory inside of that. So if the zipped package is package.zip, the unzipped package directory should contain immediately inside of it the imsmanifest.xml. This is a common mistake and normally occurs when you select the root folder to compress. This places the content folder inside of another folder, The imsmanifest.xml is there, but it is 2 directories deep. To avoid this problem when zipping, go INSIDE of the exported folder, select all files inside, and compress them while all are selected. The resultant compressed directory has the imsmanifest.xml file in the first directory. (copied partially from the SCORM FAQ) - but this also applies to loading IMSResource packages which are structured similarly

Forum Post: 
Post title: Display item status to user - multi part SCO
Post description: Hi, I am new to both SCORM and Moodle, so please bear with me. Moodle 1.9.9+ installed in a WAMP enviroment. I have successfully created and uploaded a multi part SCO and it all works great, I can view the attempt reports as the administrator and see that part 1 is incomplete and part 2 is complete. However logged in as the end user, I can only see that the asset has been viewed (green A graphic), I would like the user to be able to see different statuses for the different parts, to let them know they have completed or not certain parts. Any assistance would be greatly appreciated. Thanks,
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Hi Dave, A couple of things you might look at here. One thing is that you might just need to rename some icons in your icon set. The other possibility is that your scos might be designated as assets in your manifest file. The asset icons are for assets only. They won't be used for resources in your scorm package that are packaged as scos. If the resource is given the attribute  adlcp:scormtype="asset" in the imsmanifest.xml, it will be treated as an asset by Moodle. If you want to track completion status, score, any more complex data, you should be using the sco type for those resources. If you want the icons associated with a sco, indicating lesson_status of "incomplete", "completed" and so forth, you need to use adlcp:scormtype="sco" instead. Look for resource nodes that look like this: <resource identifier="R_A3" type="webcontent" adlcp:scormtype="asset" href="assets/being_towed_alongside.jpg"> The resource node would need to begin like this: <resource identifier="R_A1" type="webcontent" adlcp:scormtype="sco" href="scos/sco01.htm"> I'm attaching ADL's sample manifest for multiple sco content.
Comment 2: Hi Amy, Thanks for your quick response. You are spot on - actually, I has not specified the adlcp:scormtype attrib at all. I changed it to sco and this is now working. Thanks again for your help! Dave

Forum Post: 
Post title: Closing SCORM page direct settings - Moodle or Storyline?
Post description: Hi All, Another quick question. Does anyone know if it's
possible to set which page the user is directed to when they close a
SCORM pop up window - via Moodle? Or can this only be set when you're
publishing from Storyline? Again, any help is greatly appreciated! Thanks,
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Moving to SCORM forum...
Comment 2: Jeyda, Storyline does not know anything about the structure or pages of your Moodle site because the Storyline project is created outside of the Moodle learning management system, and is designed to be independent of any LMS configuration. So there is no way for Storyline to know where to redirect the user. The file just closes and the user is returned to the Moodle page. It is possible to control redirection inside Moodle, depending on how you display the Storyline module. If you display the Storyline module in a new window, when you close that window you go back to the same Moodle window where you started. If you display the Storyline module in the current window, the course breadcrumb trail will be at the top of the screen and the user can navigate using that. If you know the exact URL to which you want to redirect the student when a Storyline module is closed, you can create a button in your Storyline project with that URL as the trigger link (e.g. you want to redirect the student to a Moodle Quiz or Forum).  That will take the student directly to the linked activity, but it will open in a new window. This can create a situation in which multiple Moodle windows are open at the same time. There is another possibility... You can create a Moodle HTML block in your course with links to the destination to which you want to send the student. You must set the HTML block display option to 'Any page'. The block will then display on the Storyline module page, if you open the Storyline module in the current window. You could then have your Storyline file display a message for the user to click the link in the HTML block on the page. One final thought. The above comments apply if the Storyline project is published as a SCORM package. If you don't need the Storyline project to communicate back to Moodle (e.g. a quiz score or completion results), then the Storyline project can be published as HTML. Then you have many more options for redirection. So, this has been quite long. There are many options, but no option is optimal. I would have to know more about your course and Storyline project to come up with other ideas. Floyd
Comment 3: this has come up a few times - Ideally I'd like to provide a setting to allow the teacher to control this - I thought we had an open tracker issue that was related to this but didn't see one so have created: MDL-61677 - feel free to vote/watch that issue for updates. It's not something I'll probably have time to work on as a volunteer but someone else might do some development and submit a patch? You may also consider contracting a Moodle Partner to develop the feature and submit it to core for you.

Forum Post: 
Post title: No videos or audio playing
Post description: I've uploaded an Adobe Captivate 8 SCORM file into Moodle 2.9.1. Videos (flv files) are showing a black screen and no audio is playing. How can I fix this? Thank you!
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Hi Losira, did you ever upload a SCORM package before? It looks like your server doesn't support the Moodle Slash arguments : https://docs.moodle.org/29/en/Using_slash_arguments . Are you on a shared hosting? HTH , Matteo
Comment 2: Hello Matteo, Thank you for your help. I have uploaded SCROM files before. Others have no problem playing. In this case I uploaded the .flv video separately and it is playing , so it has something to do with the SCROM file from Captivate 8 integrating with Moodle. I just can't figure out what! Losira
Comment 3: Hi Losira, unfortunately the problem could be as simple as complex (!). Slash arguments support is required for SCORM while it is not strictly required to serve single self-contained binary assets like media. Let's start testing your site; log into your Moodle instance as administrator and copy&paste the following URL in your browser: http://hostname/path/to/moodle/admin/phpinfo.php/test%20slash%20arguments%20support (change here the hostname and the path to your Moodle instance). A page should appear showing several info about the PHP configuration of your instance including a special line line telling something like below: 
```text
PATH_INFO
    
/test slash arguments support
```
 You need to read the exact text above, blank spaces included: if yes, we'll need to do some more tests; otherwise, you need to fix the Slash arguments support. The second test will be to open the Dev Tools on your browser (e.g. in Chrome it means pressing <F12> ) and look at the Network tab to see what is the Response about the FLV file Request . It could be also possible that the FLV file is packaged within the ZIP file using a file name that differs from the one you see in the URL for some upper/lower case chars. HTH, Matteo

Post title: Marking scorm course complete using web service
Post description: In my application, I want to use 'Force start new attempt' under certain condition. I understand that Moodle will start a new attempt only if the previous attempt is complete. For this I want to forcefully mark the previous attempt as complete using moodle web service. I tried using 'core_completion_override_activity_completion_status' which marks the activity as complete but does not update the status of scorm sco tracks. Is there a way to mark scorm sco tracks state as 'complete' using moodle web service?
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: the SCORM webservice "insert_scorm_tracks" should allow you to do this - you'll want to pass a cmi.core.lesson_status var with one of the values completed,finished or passed - take a look at whatever your SCORM is showing for that value on completed attempts for other existing users and you should see which value you should be using. Good luck!
Comment 2: Thank you for the quick reply Dan! That helped!

Post title: RFC: SCORM Structure + Object Repositories + Best Practices
Post description: Hello everyone, I am adapting several pre-created lessons to SCORM compliant packages (via. Reload) for importing into an LMS such as moodle.  Although I have found lots of reference on how to accomplish individual aspects of the task, such as meta-data, javascript additions that are required, etc.  I am lacking a resource that can help me achieve an epiphany on the "bigger picture".  Considering the example.... 3 lessons each of which has it's own custom navigation and features to browse the varying page(s) of each lesson .  (i.e. lesson 1: All about widgets has 6 pages). Each lesson has several images, applets, etc. The goal is that all applets, and several of the more important images are to be search-able Assets for use by teachers in creating future content (whether it be in Moodle or some object repository). Although I can individually tag each asset properly, and create scorm compliant assets, I will eventually be dealing with approximately 500 of these lessons.  Here are some questions I have had turning over in my brain... if anyone out there has some experience in doing something similar to this, input would be greatly appreciated! 1. Should each Lesson be a SCO and will I add up to 500 lessons individually to Moodle then structure the course or should I create the "course" with individual lessons structured in reload? 2. A lot of my applets share common files, or images may be shared between lessons.  Is there a way to maintain that sharing, or will I need to create multiple copies of these common files to enforce the modularity of each lesson? 3. To implement the assets as their own search-able objects in an object repository (am i correct in thinking that moodle will implement a search-able OR for a not-so-distant release?), do I have to individually create each asset as it's own SCORM package, or can I simply tag assets with proper meta-data and will an O.R. be smart enough to do a subset search and return the proper files from the bigger package? 4. Not withstanding #3, if I was to tag an applet /image as a asset, is it customary to include a stub HTML page that is the main point of the asset so that the image (or more importantly) applet can be utilized properly?

Forum Post: 
Post title: Admin settings - "Enable SCORM 1.2 standard mode" definite meaning
Post description: Hi all, As many of you know, there are some known bugs with SCORM. I was looking to overcome issues such as SCORM internet connection breaks, resume behaviour errors, and incomplete retrieved tracking data to name a few by altering configurations. It is my belief that the authoring tool we use - in cases where the courses built and compiled to SCORM contain a lot of data; potentially exceed the threshold of the suspend_data field... which may therefor be a cause of issues users have reported for example the "resume behaviour error" where the user would return to the course at a different point to where they had left off. So to the point of the discussion, I've come across this admin setting "Enable SCORM 1.2 standard mode"... @Site administration > Plugins > Activity modules > learning module. Where it enabled by default (ticked), it states the following.. " Disabling this setting allows Moodle to store more data than the SCORM 1.2 specification allows. If your SCORM packages allow users to enter large amounts of text or if your package tries to store large amounts of data in the suspend_data field disable this." In the Moodle SCORM 2.7 documentation is expands with: " If this setting is disabled, then it will be possible to exceed the allowed amount of stored data for SCORM 1.2 packages. Many SCORM packages go over the 4096 characters limit and while SCORM 2004 allows a higher number of characters, it is not supported. This setting will mean users can allow their 1.2 packages to store more data." Am I correct in saying my Moodle 2.7 site, where I run only SCORM 1.2 packages, that it would be wise to untick the box and (therefore would disable it?)? This has been a controversial topic at my workplace, as a specialist of Moodle advised us to keep it ticked (enabled) as "It only applies to SCORM 2004". Many thanks, Alex
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Bump (if allowed)...
Comment 2: The SCORM 1.2 specification sets some limits on the amount of data that different variables can store. This means that when complying with the standards if a SCORM package tries to store more than the allowed amount of data the LMS must return an error. Good examples of this are "suspend_data" and student responses to quiz questions. These bits of data can often go over the limit that the SCORM 1.2 spec defines and this often occurs with packages developed by the major well-known authoring tools. The biggest issue when this occurs with "suspend_data" is that when a student returns to a previous attempt it can't resume where they left off last as the suspend_data is not complete. When this occurs with student responses, the data is not stored. Sometimes these errors can cause other failures within the SCORM package as they do not always have good error handling implemented within the packages. Many people publish their basic SCORM packages as SCORM 2004 to get around these limits because the SCORM 2004 standard has much higher data limits on the same variables, but Moodle doesn't provide full support for SCORM 2004 (particularly the sequencing and navigation component of SCORM 2004) By un-ticking this box Moodle won't return an error state when your SCORM package tries to store more data than the 1.2 spec allows, it will accept the data and allow your SCORM to function as you expected it to in the first place. This setting affects SCORM 1.2 packages and allows them to work as expected by the teacher - I tend to disable standards mode on all our clients sites, I think the only reason I would enable standards mode would be to allow us to run Moodle through the official ADL compliance tests. It's possible that in a future version of Moodle we might have it disabled by default. Hopefully that helps?
Comment 3: Hi Dan I've just stumbled across this setting and it sounds extremely useful, particularly for people who feel the need to have very lengthy courses in Articulate/Storyline/Captivate as such modules can easily be made to exceed the standard 4096bytes of storage that the SCORM 1.2 spec allows. My question is: when this option is unchecked, what is the new upper limit on suspend_data storage? Is there any hidden setting for controlling what that is or is it simply the limit set on whatever field in the database the suspend_data is stored in?
Comment 4: it extends the items restricted to 256 and 4096 by the SCORM 1.2 spec to 64000 (the highest value allowed in the SCORM 2004 spec) https://github.com/moodle/moodle/blob/master/mod/scorm/datamodels/scorm_12.php#L45 at some point we should probably make the default value for that set to "off" for new installs - the only reason I can think of for it to be turned on is if you are running the ADL SCORM compliance tests.
Comment 5: Thanks Dan, that's very useful info. My colleague must have created a truly enormous course because he said he had exceeded even that limit..!

Post title: scorm conversion and uplinking of flash files , avi files
Post description: i want to upload flash files, cbt packages, pdf files and files with .avi extension.....is it possible in moodle and if so how........also can i disable the copy option using right click of mouse in moodle........any help suggestion regarding scorm conversion of flash files,cbt packages and .avi files are also welcome.......
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: you can upload all those files into Moodle fine, using the drop down "add a resource > link to a file or website". and there may be some patches around to disable right click in some browsers - but this isn't foolproof and isn't ever going to be. A range of browsers handle this sort of thing differently, so if a user wants to save a copy of the object then they will find a way around it. If all you want to do is upload files to a site for sharing with other users, Moodle may be overkill for what you need. As far as converting the files into SCORM files - this won't provide any further "protection" from allowing users to download /save them, there are a range of SCORM authoring tools listed here: http://docs.moodle.org/en/Tools_for_creating_SCORM_content

Forum Post: 
Post title: SCORM Version Update
Post description: I work in an establishment which currently uses Moodle 3.5. The following information was passed out to us: SCORM 1.3 incompatibility. In late 2020 SCORM will update to version 1.3. This version is built around the current SCORM 2004 and is therefore incompatible. We are a bit confused by the above statement, we cannot find anything online about this update, has anyone else heard about this?
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: I'm not surprised you're confused - the statement you pasted above doesn't make any sense. Prior to its release, SCORM 2004 was called SCORM 1.3, but the name "SCORM 1.3" is no longer in official use. Moodle does not provide full support for the SCORM 2004 specification (it's a massive spec and it didn't really get a lot of use.) There's a good doc that explains the different SCORM versions here: https://scorm.com/scorm-explained/business-of-scorm/scorm-versions/ There are some newer specs around like Xapi and CMI 5 but none of those have been as widely adopted as SCORM 1.2/2004 - In terms of Moodle I see a lot more people moving to H5P than the newer versions of the SCORM spec. Can you give some more context on who provided this statement?
Comment 2: Thanks for the reply Dan, That statement was sent out from the team that provides the support for the Learning Platform (Moodle) that we use in our training establishment. Now we have some clarification that the statement is confusing, we make some enquires with the support team to find out what they are going on about. Thanks again.
Comment 3: I wonder if they were confused about the Flash Apocalypse? A lot of SCORM 1.2 content was created using Flash, and most browsers are planning to drop support for Flash so many of these older SCORM 1.2 packages will stop working. For organisations that have lost access to the original source files for these old SCORM packages we usually highly recommend they investigate replacing them with H5P based packages instead of re-creating them again in SCORM. (do a search for SCORM Flash Apocalypse to find out a bit more)
Comment 4: But does Moodle support H5P, Dan? Cheers!
Comment 5: In order to use H5P in Moodle, you need to install an external plugin: https://moodle.org/plugins/mod_hvp However, the Moodle community is working hard on integrating H5P in Moodle core. See more information about it here: https://moodle.org/mod/forum/discuss.php?d=390359 Please note that there is a new forum dedicated only to "H5P", so you can ask questions there: https://moodle.org/mod/forum/view.php?id=8603

Forum Post: 
Post title: This forum post has been removed
Post description: The content of this forum post has been removed and can no longer be accessed.
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Scorm is a particular piece of code which has specific rules governing completion, and much of this is done when the scorm object is created. It is entirely possible that you've got a scorm object which requires all pages to be viewed before completion is reported to Moodle, but you've also got it allowing users to skip pages in the navigation. In such a case a user will only complete if they view all pages, but could also achieve a score from the scorm object of 100% and still not be reported as complete, if they can skip ahead to the 'test' section in the scorm. When testing, try to skip pages, or fail to open some hot spots (or reveals... whatever you like to call them), and see if you get a score... AND a completed status. Try turning on the scorm debug mode in the site administration, and setting your username as the only person who sees it. When you then access a scorm object a new window will pop open - it's the scorm API showing you exactly what is written back to Moodle and what isn't. But to answer your other point, yes, it is entirely possible that a network glitch is happening. It is also possible for you to open the scorm object on the same page as the moodle course, or in a new window. It can make a difference as to which you choose... BUT, if your scorm object is created to ALSO open in a new window, you'll get two pop ups appearing. If your users don't like the 'clutter' on their page, and decide to close the one without the content, then all progress will NOT be reported to moodle - this is the scorm player window and must remain open. Try using moodle to not open in a new window and see if the scorm pops out in a new window anyway - if it does then the scorm has been authored to do so, and can only be changed by re-authoring the scorm.

Post title: some questions about the implementation of the RTE in moodle
Post description: I have this problem of not being able to GetValue("cmi.interactions.0.student_response"). Using GetLastError the error code I get is 404. Looking up the Scorm RTE document (2004), I found that 404 is a "read-only" error. I couldnt find any reference to cmi.interactions.n.student_response, but there's one on cmi.interactions.n.learner_response, and the document says this should be read and write enabled. Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Hi, all cmi.interactions in SCORM 1.2 are write only elements. The cmi.interactions.n.learner_response is a SCORM 2004 element. In SCORM 2004 the interactions elements are also readable. You must use scorm 2004 if you want use it. Bobo.

Post title: Articulate Quiz freezing on submitting results
Post description: Hello, I am hoping to find help here as Articulate says my issue is a moodle issue, not an Articulate one. I initially posted on this forum thread on Articulate's website. Was on Moodle 3.0 and just upgraded to 3.1 hoping the following problem would get fixed with a moodle upgrade. Without success. The problem: Posting several 20-question quizzes made with Articulate Quizmaker 13,
publishing in Scorm 1.2. Our new quizzes contain pictures on the slide
masters (without the pictures, the problem seems not to happen). Once the last question of a quiz is answered, the
quiz seems to freeze (on the result slide for the question, after clicking contine) for about 20-30 seconds. Then, the question result slide goes away and it goes back to the last question instead of showing the full quiz result slide (which has the button to review the quiz)... nothing
happens if you click on submit... but if you use the "question list" to
go back a few questions and hit next to get to the last question, then
the quiz result slide comes up... If I cut the quiz to be much shorter (like 3-4 questions), there is a little freeze but we do get to the quiz result slide as expected. I have the latest Adobe Flash player on my PC. Tried with Firefox and Chrome. Same issue. Articulate tested one of our quizzes on Scorm Cloud. It works like a charm there. I really hope someone can help. We have quite a few frustrated students waiting for us to fix this bug! Thanks a lot! Julien
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Hi everyone, seems like I found the issue! It was so simple actually. I
had "Passed/Failed" in the publish settings. Changing it to "Passed
Incomplete" made it all work. I wish I had known that from the get go!
Julien
Comment 2: I take that back. The above solution only fixes the issue when the user fails the quiz. When he/she passes the quiz, there is still the freeze. I tried also "Complete/Incomplete", "Passed, Failed", etc... still the frezze on a passed quiz. Any idea? I am really desperate for help!
Comment 3: BTW ... I still have some quizzes made with Quizmaker 09 and these do not freeze on the last question. Only those made with Quizmaker 13. So there must be something on the quiz submission that Quizmaker 13 is doing differently compared to 09. In case this helps nail down the issue...

Forum Post: 
Post title: Sometimes no elements in xxx_scorm_scoes_track are populated except x.start.time
Post description: Hi, We have a transient issue with SCORM 1.2 and Moodle 2.x. On some occasions, but not always, in the DB, table xxx_scorm_scoes_track, the only element that is stored for the attempt is x.start.time. The effects of this inconsistency are the following: 1. When the user returns to the activity, nothing is stored anymore 2. When the user creates a new attempt, this is allowed, but only data pertinent to that new attempt are stored (the attempt records are overwritten) We also tried to "repair" the DB by eliminating attempts with too few elements stored, but this does not solve properly the problem, especially when there were created another attempt. Anyway, the root cause is that originally no elements were stored except x.start.time. Apparently, the problem is on the client side ( JavaScript ). We tried to track down outgoing requests via tcpdump and have found that sometimes they are silently lost on the client side instead of being sent to the server . Apparently, the issue is more probable to occur having bad network connection. The issue applies to any kind of course generated by Articulate as well as to custom-made material produced by using a SCORM wrapper. Our server platform is Centos 5.6 with PHP 5.2.x and MySQL 5.0. Can anyone help us out please?
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: saw your post on articulate forums too... taking a guess that you're using IE check these 2 out: MDL-28295 (fixed in 2.0.5+ and 2.1.2+) MDL-29213 (not fixed yet but workaround listed in the comments)

Forum Post: Post title: SCORM_12.js.php changing the cmi.interactions? Post description: I have been looking for an improved report feature that organizes the cmi.objectives and cmi.interactions data. While reviewing the output in Moodle I noticed that for some reason the code in the function LMSSetValue is altering the element namea and replacing the "." with "_" cmi.objecitves.0.id became cmi.objecitves_0.id At the top of the function element is correctly passed in as: cmi.objecitves.0.id but when saved at the bottom and in the debug it has become cmi.objecitves_0.id the debug output shows: : LMSSetValue("cmi.objectives.0.id", "Grade2")  (added a call at top of function to show what I passed in) : LMSSetValue("cmi.objectives_0.id", "Grade2") => 0 This code is changing the element? if (elementIndexes[i+1].match(/^\d+$/)) { if ((typeof eval(subelement+'.'+elementIndex)) == "undefined") { eval(subelement+'.'+elementIndex+' = new Object();'); eval(subelement+'.'+elementIndex+'._count = 0;'); } if (elementIndexes[i+1] == eval(subelement+'.'+elementIndex+'._count')) { eval(subelement+'.'+elementIndex+'._count++;'); } if (elementIndexes[i+1] > eval(subelement+'.'+elementIndex+'._count')) { errorCode = "201"; } What am I missing here? The SCO is a working SCO that passed ADL Test Suite and is successfully storing the objectives and interacitons on another SCORM LMS. Comments associated with the post: Comment 1: My guess is that the switch to underscore helps in the storing of the data in the db. If that is the case, that is allowed as SCORM just deals with the element names in the api. Once it's on the lms side in the db the lms can do whatever it wants in relation to naming as it's abstracted from the course. So the reports your working on are not covered by the SCORM standard so the names are allowed to be changed. Comment 2: The reason I want to figure out why the data is being changed is because the default report code in mod/scorm/report.php in version 1.9.7 anyway is looking for .. $interactionid = 'cmi.interactions.'.$i.'.id'; so the underscore results in this report code failing to group the data. As I scan the forum clearly all have this issue since lots of posts show the element names with the '_" and the report output does not include the interactions heading as shown in the code excerpt below. report.php line 345 // Print Interactions data $table = new stdClass(); $table->head = array(get_string('identifier','scorm'), get_string('type','scorm'), get_string('result','scorm'), get_string('student_response','scorm')); $table->align = array('center', 'center', 'center', 'center'); $table->wrap = array('nowrap', 'nowrap', 'nowrap', 'nowrap'); $table->width = '100%'; $table->size = array('*', '*', '*', '*', '*'); $existinteraction = false; $i = 0; $interactionid = 'cmi.interactions.'.$i.'.id'; while (isset($trackdata->$interactionid)) { $existinteraction = true; $printedelements[]=$interactionid; $elements = array($interactionid, 'cmi.interactions.'.$i.'.type', 'cmi.interactions.'.$i.'.result', 'cmi.interactions.'.$i.'.learner_response'); $row = array(); foreach ($elements as $element) { if (isset($trackdata->$element)) { $row[] = s($trackdata->$element); $printedelements[]=$element; } else { $row[] = ' '; } } $table->data[] = $row; $i++; $interactionid = 'cmi.interactions.'.$i.'.id'; } if ($existinteraction) { echo '

'.get_string('interactions','scorm').'

'; print_table($table); } Comment 3: The code you refer to in the first post has been there since the very first version of the SCORM module was included in Moodle core (almost 4 years) I'm only guessing here but it might have been done to make the data from SCORM 1.2 and 2004 all look the same - SCORM 2004 uses _ in some places where scorm 1.2 uses . It probably makes more sense to fix the reports to display the right data rather than changing the way the data is stored. So - if the reports aren't displaying the right information, feel free to create a bug in the tracker with a suggested fix. Label:

Forum Post: 
Post title: What is wrong in this SCORM +FLASH  delivering index file?
Post description: I have made quite a few changes but I keep seeing the "Get Flash Player" link and no content. Any idea why this is happening. HTML attached
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Hi Sara, I notice you are using the pipwerks API wrapper so I will go with that. I would suggest moving all of you SCORM files into one directory before zipping. I noticed you have moved the SCORM_API_wrapper into a directory called js (according to your code), start by making your directory structure flat and reflect this in your HTML. The Flash Engine does not generate the best SCORM HTML. A simplified version could look like this: <!DOCTYPE html PUBLIC "-//W3C//DTD XHTML 1.0 Transitional//EN" " http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd "> <html xmlns=" http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml "> <head> <title>Training4Diversity - Sexual Orientation</title>
Comment 2: Hi Wade, Thanks for quick reply. I realised that the problem was with objectnames and the whole thing being case-sensitive. The corrected code is attached. I will also go through your suggestion to understand the way of implementing this as I am new to swf object based implementation.
Comment 3: DO we need to do anything special to be able to deliver flash(SCORM) cotent across proxy. Our customer mentioned he could see the entire site very well but this flash is not displying instead show a cross mark like missing img. Sorry for least info but this much is what I am with so far. Any thoughts?
Comment 4: Hi Sarah, To display the Flash Object (.swf file) there should be no proxy (cross domain ) issues. Just "point your embed object code (HTML based) and it should display. I do this all the time to "beautify" my main Moodle index when my courses are password protected. However to return information from Flash to Moodle (in php/ sql by say calling Flashes External Interface Class or using a URLVariable.POST Method) then cross domain policies do apply. I believe the Pipwerks SCORM package sets cookies via JavaScript and then uses Moodles PHP to pull down the SCORM variables (I could be corrected on this as it has been a while since I have used it). I am not sure it was designed to work cross domain without modifications. Regardless, to use Flash with SCORM variables cross domain you would need to set COOKIES, POST information or embed ?GET code at then end of your .html URL and then write some PHP code in Moodle to retrieve that information. Each of these options also has its own security considerations. Hope that helps. Wade
Comment 5: Moodle also does a Flash version check before displaying all Flash objects - make sure your customer is running Flash 10 or higher, for more info see: http://moodle.org/mod/forum/discuss.php?d=139119

So, I'm wondering, if it's not a temp internet file or cookie that's storing the result, what is it?  It would be better if I could tell users 'just delete this object/file' and it will reset itself, rather than clearing their entire history, stored ids, stored passwords, and so on.  If anyone has an answer, please let me know. Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Hi Boris, how are you deleting the users attempts? - the latest 1.9Stable and 2.x releases let you delete attempts on the responses page: http://docs.moodle.org/en/SCORM_FAQ#Clear_an_Attempt If you are using that page and the attempts still seem to exist it might come from a cookie that your SCORM package creates - not much we can do about this in Moodle - you would need to open your SCORM package in the authoring tool you used to create it and tell it not to store attempt data in a cookie.
Comment 2: Yes, I delete them from the responses page. I'm not sure there's a way to stop it from using cookies or whatever it's using.  The program I use is 'Quiz Creator' (Wondershare), and I haven't seen any settings like that, but I'll check again.

Post description: Should I embed images within my SCORM compliant package or should I have these images reside in some external folder on the internet? What are the advantages and disadvantages to the two approaches? Thanks for your insights
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Hi Art, It depends on the size of your images, and how you're building your SCORM package. It also depends how you plan to roll out the SCORM content. I'd be likely to want to package everything, just for the sake of simplicity. If the external folder ever goes away, then the package referencing it might lose its functional integrity. That said, you want your images to be Web-ready, of appropriate size, etc. If you need to load a huge image file, for some reason, then there's a good reason to consider locating it elsewhere. Usually people are loading external files when they have a very large FLV that needs to be streamed from a streaming server , that sort of thing. But you'd have to have one hell of an image to cause a similar problem. ;) Best of luck, A
