Forum Post: 
Post title: How to get AICC url after enabling?
Post description: Hello, I am trying to get the AICC url for some courses to be used in another LMS. I have enabled 'direct AICC url' but I am not sure where to get that url. I also may have a misunderstanding of how the AICC url works or if it will even do what I want it to do. The version of moodle is 3.10 Thanks
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Moodle allows you to add external content packages that use the AICC format inside your courses - typically these are provided by organisations that sell off-the-shelf content packages - eg health and safety/compliance courses, standalone training etc. Usually they will provide you with a mini-zip file to add into your Moodle site using the SCORM activity. The zip file basically contains an AICC config file which includes the full url to the external package. Moodle's Direct aicc URL feature just allows you to put in the url to the external provider's content package, rather than using the AICC zip file. I suspect... what you are asking for, is a way for your Moodle content to be linked to from the other LMS you mention... if that's the case, and the external LMS supports the LTI standard, then you probably want to use LTI to do this. If they don't support LTI, you should post more information here on what you're trying to do and someone may have other ideas for you to consider.
Comment 2: Thanks for your reply Dan, that really clarifies things. A client wants to have our content linked onto their LMS like as you wrote. From what I know their LMS does not support the LTI standard. The reason why I was asking about the AICC URL was because their team asked me for it, now I realize it may not be what we need. We are trying to set up SSO maybe that could work as an alternative? Some more ideas would be greatly appreciated! Thanks

Forum Post: 
Post title: Moodle not recording SCORM (2004) interactions
Post description: Moodle 3.11.3; SCORM 2004; Storyline 360 (latest). The situation can arise where Moodle does not log the interactions from the SCORM package. On real courses this can result in a learner passing the course but that not being recorded on the LMS. We have tracked instances where learners have provided evidence of passing the course (screenshot of success slide) but neither the final scores nor status was recorded in Moodle - 1st attempt score were and in some cases part of the 2nd attempt is recorded too. The issue seems to only occur if the assessment is not passed on 1st attempt. SCORM is setup to allow 2 attempts. I created a simple test quiz in Storyline 360, based on a real assessment but with fewer questions. I enabled API debugging. The API debug consistently shows all the interactions (answers) being recorded but Moodle interactions report (and user activity logs) don't. For example, failing the assessment twice, closing the module, refreshing the page and going back in from the start may result in only some or none of the answers being recorded in Moodle, despite the API debug activity logs showing them all. In this situation, the server access logs also confirm that there's no posting of the SCORM data but there are periodic calls (30 seconds) to POST /lib/ ajax /service.php?sesskey=[session]&info=core_session_touch HTTP/1.0. So something is still happening. Nothing obvious in the browser console. Anyone have any clues why this can happen and more importantly, what can be done to fix it? P.S. This seems to be similar to this but that topic is locked without a clear resolution: https://moodle.org/mod/forum/discuss.php?d=417245
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: According to this link https://docs.moodle.org/311/en/SCORM_FAQ#Supported_Versions SCORM 2004 is not supported in Moodle. Parts of the API have been implemented, but others such as Navigation and Sequencing have not. Development on native SCORM 2004 support in Moodle has stopped. If you require a fully certified SCORM 2004 Player in Moodle, Rustici Software have a Moodle plugin which connects to their commercial SCORM Cloud service turning Moodle into a fully compliant SCORM 2004 LMS.
Comment 2: Thanks. We only switched to 2004 recently to get the two status returns as course was looking for wrong completion status and we didn't want to lose the learner data. Turned out that replacing the SCORM lost the completion status anyhow so that had to be manually restored by recreating the results in the database . Anyhow switched back to 2.1 and see the same behaviour, indicating it's not a SCORM version issue. I also raised this on Articulate forum so rather than repeat latest status here, see this comment: https://community.articulate.com/discussions/articulate-storyline/issue-with-scorm-randomly-stopping-communicating-with-lms-moodle#reply-781915 Looks like something is going wrong between receiving an interaction and processing it. In the test case presented, it was not a major issue as the final passed status was processed and course completed. However in the real-world we have seen instances where the completion status is not recorded hence learners that passed on 2nd attempt aren't recorded as so in the LMS.

Post title: Return from SCORM to the main 'topic outline'
Post description: Hi, I've got a question about using a SCORM package in Moodle and I wonder if someone could advise what the best solution would be. I've uploaded a SCORM package to Moodle. From the Topics Outline view (the main course view) I click on my SCORM package link. It takes me to a new Moodle screen where I can have a text description of the course and there is an "Enter" button at the bottom. Click the Enter button and the SCORM package opens in a completely new separate window. When you have finished the SCORM course or if you close the window, you are returned to Moodle. The Moodle screen you are returned to just has the name of the SCORM package to the left. The rest of the screen is blank. There are no obvious buttons to return you to the Topics Outline (the logical place you'd expect to be returned to). The only way to get back gracefully seems to be to click on the breadcrumbs. Realistically it is likely a user will either click the Back button on the browser or they will close the Moodle window thinking that the Topics Outline window will be behind it. Of course it isn't and they will have to restart Moodle - rather annoying! After starting the SCORM package, on returning from it to Moodle, how can the user be returned directly to the Topics Outline page? Any help would be appreciated as it's currently not very user friendly. Michael

Post title: SCORM API is not implemented - no values saved or available
Post description: Moodle 1.9.3 When adding a SCORM 1.2 content and running it, no values will be saved and no saved values can be found. Debugging the resulting document, a dummyapi.js is included. moodle/mod/resource/type/ims/dummyapi.js Only the necessary methods are declared but not implemented. So methods like LMSGetValue just return an empty string. There seems to be an implementation in moodle/mod/scorm/datamodels/scorm_12.js.php
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: 1st - SCORM uses JS - make sure you browser supports it and has it enabled. 2nd - make sure there aren't any JS errors in your SCORM object that are interferring with the JS of the SCORM API 3rd - if you're still having issues, provide a copy of your scorm object in the SCORM repository so we can test it, see if we can give further guidance.
Comment 2: Dan, thanks for your answer. I have the same problem in both Firefox and IE and both have JS enabled. As I've said, the API adapter IS found, but it's the dummy I pointed to in my first post which has acutally no implementation for the defined methods. If there would be an JS error I would see it in my error console and the whole application would not run and wouldn't communicate with the SCORM API. It communicates with the SCORM API but that doesn't give me any values as it's just that dummy. I've uploaded a small test application which can be found here: http://moodle.org/mod/data/view.php?d=50&rid=1945 The same issue happens on a moodle system of one of our customers. Not sure which version that is. What really puzzles me is that no one else seems to have that problem. So there must be something wrong in the way I add the SCORM application. Thanks a lot for your assistance. Daniel
Comment 3: I've now created a very simple test with only a SCORM wrapper and a simple HTML document offering a couple of testing methods. http://moodle.org/mod/data/view.php?d=50&rid=1946 See the description for the module for more details about how you may use it. Here you see the same problem. Only the dummyapi.js file gets included. I've tested the same file successfully on other systems. You may easily see this using firebug too. Daniel (Does really nobody else has that problem? Absolutely confusing.)
Comment 4: Same result with all demo courses in the "Scorm Repository" I've tested (5 different courses). The one from Ostyn doesn't even show anything except the frame structure. http://moodle.org/mod/data/view.php?d=50&rid=1654 Daniel
Comment 5: I've found my mistake. I've always added it as "IMS Content Package" where I need to add it as "Learning Package". This is really confusing. Thanks for reading. Daniel
Comment 6: oops! - if I'd looked closer at your post above I would have seen that! - yes - IMS content package is different from SCORM - you need to use the Activity "SCORM" type not the resource "IMS Content Package" good to hear you got it sorted by yourself!

Forum Post: 
Post title: Course marks itself complete as soon as it's opened
Post description: Hi, I'm using moodle 2.1.1+. We have a few courses (scorm 1.2) that right after they launch they get marked as complete. If the user keeps going until the  end the score is saved in the db. But instead if the user exists the course and comes back later .. the score is not saved. It seems like it;s a problem with the package and we're talking to the vendor. The problem is that they are moving extremely slowly. Is there anything that I could try in the meantime ? A hack of some sort(be it in the db, php code ... or something else) ... maybe someone encountered something similar at some point . Any thoughts are appreciated. Thank you
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Hi John, One thing you can do that will help you out a lot in getting what you need from the vendor is to enable scorm debugging and obtain an API log for a complete session for one of the SCORM packages in question. http://docs.moodle.org/23/en/SCORM_FAQ#Debugging http://docs.moodle.org/23/en/SCORM_FAQ#What_does_the_debugging_log_mean.3F One common issue with SCORM content is that data is seldom sent through the API. Ideally, upon launch, cmi.core.lesson_status is set to "incomplete," not "complete." Then some data (usually including cmi.core.lesson_location, and possibly updates to cmi.core.score.raw) is sent through the API every time the learner advances a traditional "page." Some SCORM packages send all reporting data at the very end of the activity. This may be the case for your problematic packages, based on your description. If you can easily hack the SCORM package, then a few things you may want to try to do is 1) update cmi.core.lesson_location every time the learner accesses a page 2) update cmi.core.score.raw (or cmi.core.lesson_status) on exit (using a onPageUnload() or other JavaScript event). This will be easier to do if the content is mostly HTML and JavaScript. It'll be a bit harder if it's HTML that loads a SWF. It really depends on the library being used, and whether or not you can easily hook into it. Best of luck!
Comment 2: Hi, I'm curious to know if your package includes raw, normalized and mastery score settings. I ask because SCORM specs can mark lessons as complete/incomplete depending on these settings and they can be a bit tricky. May be totally unrelated but I'm just generally thinking of the communication between package settings. LMS function and SCORM specs... without knowing what tool you're using or the LMS.

Post title: Passing 100% Score to LMS
Post description: Hi, I have a Scorm 2004 course that is essentially a review course...students step through the course, reading the provided info, and continue through to the last page of the course. What I'd like to do is the following: When the student reaches the final page and exits the course, have the course pass a completed status and a score of 100%. Is this possible?
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: There is the Force completed setting. That is only available to 1.2 standard packages. It can also be done in 2004 from within the SCORM package. But we can't really tell you how to do it unless we know how you're making your SCORM content.
Comment 2: I actually have the completed status passing through, but not the 100%. Comment 3: If completed status is being reported then I believe you just need to change grading method to Learning objects and it will result in a 100% in the grade book. The JavaScript or ActionScript that needs to be used to set the value depends on what namespaces are being used in the library that establishes the API. But the value that should be set is cmi.score.raw.

Forum Post: 
Post title: How can I use the external Scorm package from the different server ?
Post description: I have some curious about the Scorm and need some help.Actually, I have tried to find the solution and found  reply in my problem-related question via discussion board but I can't figure it out much.Firstly, Let me introduce my plan . My Moodle installation plan is a bit complicate because it has to use in various sites that are located in difference provinces by accessing within the Intranet.As I notice,it takes long time for different site users to access the content if it's located in the Moodle's server . As my opinion (not too IT professional ) , I have planned that I will set up the center for one physical server to install the Moodle and in other sites will be use file sharing to upload the Scorm content.I've already try this scenario by uploading those Scorm contents in each site and let some users who stay in each site testing the time for loading the content.As a result , it was work.Users could access the content by less time consuming.By the way,the biggest obstacle is that I don't know how to use the external Scorm content that have already uploaded on file sharing in different sites in Moodle.How I can handle with it if my scenario is not work for. Do you have any idea or better solution that can be solved the problem of long time consuming when we stream the content in different sites? Any clarifying information would be appreciated.Don't hesitate to ask.
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: In addition , I've just found this issue ( as shown below) . To conclude , as my understanding it said that I can't track the information or activity if I use external Scorm since there are some problem about the communication. Is that true ? Do I misunderstand ? "External Package type External package type is disabled by default on new installations – it is not a great method of linking to packages as under certain circumstances your packages will not pass back any grade or tracking information to Moodle. If enabled and selected it provides a text field to paste a URL to a remote imsmanifest. xml (in an unzipped remote SCORM package) – this allows SCORM content to be hosted outside your Moodle site and the content is played from the external location and is not unpacked/copied into Moodle storage. This also means that if you update the SCORM package then the latest content will always be loaded (unless you update your core imsmanifest.xml file as this file is copied into Moodle) – be very careful updating your imsmanifest.xml file; if your SCO identifiers change then tracking information for any removed SCO identifiers for any previous user attempts will be cleared from the Moodle database . For the external package type to work – your SCORM content MUST be located under the same url as your Moodle site – If the base url is different from your Moodle url then built in web browser security will block cross- domain communication and no grades/tracking information will be passed back to Moodle. Adobe Flash and modern browsers (ever since IE 6) prevent cross-domain communication. If you really need your packages to sit outside Moodle on a different URL you should look at other options for hosting your content. To enable the External package type go to: Admin > Plugins > Activity modules > SCORM package tick the box for “Enable external package type” "
Comment 2: Hi, external content work as expected but tracking, unless your Moodle instance and the external content run both under the "domain" of your Moodle instance e.g. if your Moodle instance is accessed via http://hostname/moodle and your external content is hosted in http://hostname/shared everything will be fine otherwise you'll miss the tracking features of SCORM. It's not a Moodle issue but a limit in the SCORM Specs called " SCORM Cross-Domain Issue ": other specs are not affected by this issue e.g. AICC or the emerging eXperience API. HTH , Matteo
Comment 3: Thank you very much Matteo. It's such a useful paper for me right now. I will try.

Post title: Mobile Moodle & SCORM
Post description: Hi Moodle Community, I'm looking for use cases where organizations or vendors have implemented SCORM as part of the mobile learning strategy. If you have a use case please contact me. I'm interested in real success stories and I would like to add you to the list. If you are using SCORM, I could send a few questions if you are interested or set up a time to chat. We will be sharing the results of this research and I will also briefly cover this during my session at the upcoming mLearnCon event ( http://www.mlearncon.com ). So far I have already heard of several use cases where organizations are using SCORM as part of their mobile learning initiative. I'm interested in mobile learning as part of either training or performance-support scenarios. I'm also interested in hearing from mobile vendors about their technical approach to their SCORM implementation. I'm tracking this and communicating with the community on twitter using the hashtag #MobileSCORM ( http://www.twapperkeeper.com/hashtag/MobileSCORM ). Please contact me if you know of a mobile application or mobile learning situation that supports SCORM. I would love to hear from you! +1-850-266-7100 Email: jason.haag.ctr@adlnet[dot]gov

Forum Post: 
Post title: Moodle SCORM to NHS's ESR
Post description: Hello All, First of all I should say that I am a newbie and I am still educating myself on the black arts of Moodle! I work for an NHS hospital in the UK and we are hoping to use Moodle to transmit SCORM to the NHS's staff record service called ESR. I have read see on the documentation part on Moodle.org that " Moodle does not produce SCORM ", however I have spoken to a few of my counterparts at other hospitals and they have said to me that it is possible to transmit SCORM to an outside source from Moodle. Does anyone have any experience of this, and can explain it in layman's terms! 😀 Many thanks, Mark
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Moodle is a "SCORM Player" - so you can upload SCORM packages and get it to play the scorm files and record progress from your users. You need 2 things for this to work. 1) allow your users to authenticate to Moodle - and store in Moodle something specific for that user that is also in your ESR system (employee number/email address or something that ESR "understands" 2) Export completion or grade to your ESR system using one of the existing plugins. But - before then you'll need to install moodle... my experience with organisations in the public health sector is that you are often under-staffed/ IT resources stretched - so it's incredibly important to partner with someone else to provide your Moodle hosting and regular updates to the latest version - someone needs to be patching that site every 2 months (or more often) and scheduling in yearly or bi-yearly major upgrades. Recently modern web browsers (chrome / firefox etc) made a number of changes that "Broke SCORM" in Moodle and we updated Moodle to fix it, but a lot of organisations running their own site (installed by someone who has since left the organisation) and unable to upgrade to the recent supported release is quite high and you'll see a few of these people in the forums complaining about SCORM not working in their sites. I'd highly reccomend you find a local Moodle partner and ask them to help with setting up your Moodle site - they will also be able to help you connect Moodle to your ESR system so you can pull accross your user completions/grades.

Forum Post: 
Post title: repository for reusable and easily updated SCORM files
Post description: Hi all, My goal is to have all the SCORM files in the file picker and have single course template with elearning activities that are always up to date when I replace some of SCORM content with a newer version.  I will import activities from that template to other courses. I am working for a company where we do multiple similar courses. Many courses uses the same SCORM files. One group of people prepare SCORM content and another group manages moodle. We run moodle 4.3 at the moment. As a moodle administrator I am trying to make my life easier on the moodle side and suggested we create a repository to store all our elearnings. I was hoping I could save server space and update elearning activities easily. I have a template course with all the existing elearning activities and use import to course function when making a new course and hand pick the ones I need. So far I tried "file system repository" with alias pointing to scorm's ...manifest. xml file and it somewhat worked, I had to go the elearning activity settings, open the file manager, click big blue update button it did update. Automatic update setting didn't work at all. So this setup is somewhat working, but my issue is that we use docker image on server and currently I have no idea how to set up this properly and people who prepares and updates scorm files won't be happy to have to setup another software and access FTP directly to upload elearnings. Also it seems we would have to keep scorms files extracted, as update button doesn't seem to work with zip files. I left that idea mostly because of FTP. Then I tried to create oneDrive and Microsoft 365 repositories. I faced another issue. It is that microsoft account connected to my moodle account cannot access files that are shared with me. I can see my private files in the file picker, but I cannot see the elearnings directory which is being managed on sharepoint service. Neither onedrive or Microsoft 365 repositories allowed me to access them even I was given owner rights. That's why I mention that we have different teams working on different things so I am fairly limited in what content my account owns and what is shared.
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Have you seen my old blog post? https://danmarsden.com/blog/2013/09/24/managing-scorm-content-in-moodle-2-6/ Most of the techniques mentioned there will still work. also take a look at our Scormremote plugin it doesn't quite operate in the same way you describe but can be used to do something similar: https://moodle.org/plugins/mod_scormremote
Comment 2: Yes I did read it and that was my introduction to repositories a few months ago. Great post, thank you. I will try out scormremote to see it if helps. Thanks again

Forum Post: 
Post title: Moodle 2.6 SCORM settings -- no check box for allow resizing of window
Post description: I am testing our our SCORM packages in 2.6 and I am finding no checkbox in the SCORM settings (Appearance section) for allowing the user to resize the window. Was this omission intentional? If so, I think it's really going to cause problems for our users. Can anyone offer some insight? thanks, Mia
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Hello there. I believe the setting was removed as it was felt to be obsolete - have a look here MDL-32506 but you should still be able to resize the window anyway.
Comment 2: yes - it was removed as the setting doesn't actually do anything in modern browsers - you used to be able to prevent re-sizing in browsers like IE 5/6 but all modern browsers now always allow re-sizing of the window even when told not to using the old method.
Comment 3: I will give it a try in Firefox , but in IE 9 the user cannot resize the player window in a scorm package from Moodle 2.6, but in Moodle 2.5.x, which we also have running, the user can resize the window for the same  package.
Comment 4: Just confirmed that yes, the window does still resize in Firefox, but not in IE 9. This is a show-stopper for us, and we cannot use 2.6 with it working this way. We are a government organization where several browsers are used, including IE 9. It's strange to me that something that was working fine would be removed. I know that support for multiple browsers is a difficult issue, but I really don't think we're going to be the only ones who has a problem with this. Is there any chance this can be put back in very soon?
Comment 5: Another update on this: I have spent most of the morning working with this issue. I did just get a scorm package to allow resizing by changing my publish settings in articulate and republishing. But those are not the publish settings I want to use, for other reasons. It's not feasible for us to regenerate all of our scorm packages to make them work with 2.6. I have not tried regenerating the captivate scorm we have, but we did confirm that the existing scorm that was in the course before upgrade to 2.6 does allow resizing, then when we re- upload the very same package the resizing does not work. I see that there is now a tracker filed for this: https://tracker.moodle.org/browse/MDL-42992
Comment 6: It seems very strange that you have to tell IE to allow the user to resize the browser and that the default is to not allow it. We won't add the setting back as it's not really all that useful but we do need to make sure that IE 9 users can resize their browsers - there's a patch on MDL-42992 and it should make it into core in the next couple of weeks - thanks!
Comment 7: Thanks--appreciate your quick attention to this! We will try it out.

Forum Post: 
Post title: "The page cannot be found" Error when starting a SCORM course
Post description: HI: I wrote several times in this forum about this error and I'm not the only person as I saw. I just checked with the support people who created the commercial SCORM course we bought and they don't what's happening. I tried many thinks from this forum too. I suppose it is some Moodle problem related to some server specific configuration as Moodle with my course on a windows server is running (we did installations on other servers) - just not on mine. I would like to ask Roberto Pinna or someone who knows about moodle and windows servers very well to help me in solving this. Best regards, Markus
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Hi Markus Have u solved this issue. i got the same error. i am using IIS and ms sql . could u please help me? Thank, Sankar .R
Comment 2: Hi I'm having this same problem, but my server is a Linux/ Apache / MySQL configuration. I've tried tons of posted solution, but nothing works so far. I'll keep you posted. Eddie
Comment 3: Hello, I am having this problem. I have moodle installed on IIS. all pages can be opened directly through localhost, but not when uploaded to moodle. They are scorm packages. Virge
Comment 4: If you haven't already, try using one of the SCORM packages in the SCORM Repository . Make sure you are using the SCORM activity and not the IMS Content Package resource when adding the SCORM package. Also, if you are not using the latest version of Moodle, you may want to consider upgrading. If you still get the same error message then the problem is with Moodle. If not, then you need to look at your SCORM package. Depending on the tool you use to create the SCORM package, some of these may not apply, but each of these can cause a problem. The SCORM course must be packaged in a "zip" format and contain all course files as well as the "imsmanifest. xml " file in the root folder of the course. Note: For very large SCORM courses you may need to cheat on the packaging as noted below. The "imsmanifest.xml" file must point to at least one file for launching the first SCO. If the file to be launched is not in the root folder, then a realtive path must be included as part of the launch filename. After uploading the SCORM pacage as a SCORM activity, don't unzip the file, just select "Choose". Moodle will take care of unzipping the files, reading the imsmanifest and launching the file indicated. If the SCORM package is very large in size, the server may not extract all the files from the package. This is a limitation of the PHP zip/unzip function not Moodle. This can lead to blank pages and missing files. Exactly what size? It depends on a number of things. Configuration of server and PHP time limits, number of files in the package, size of files in the package, etc. Verify that the SCORM package is SCORM compliant with the ADL SCORM Conformance Test Suite aapropriate to the version of SCORM being used. You can download the test suites at: http://www.adlnet.gov/downloads/index.aspx

Forum Post: 
Post title: SCORM results vs Gradebook
Post description: The gradebook seems to "update" the grade everytime the student re-enters the module. I would expect that the gradebook only would show a gradein the gradebook, when the SCORM module is marked as "completed", "Failed" or "Passed". And that the gradebook would n ot update a grade as long as the module is "incomplete". Am I missing a setting ór is this just the way it works? and if so, is that the way we want this to work? -- We work with Moodle 3.1.8 and Adobe Storyline 360 My setting in Moodle is: Last completed Attempt 2 attempts Highest attempt
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Is "Force new attempt" set to "yes"? Or does it look like the scorm module is generating a new attempt each time the students enters the module (check the Reports tab and see how many attempts show up for each student)?
Comment 2: Hi Matthew, No I have not set "Force new attempt" to yes, because then it will generate a new attempt everytime a student re-enters the course. I want students being able to stop mid-way a SCORM module and re-enter the SCORM until status: complete, failed or passed. And I have that working with this setting. But what I find strange is that the Moodle gradebook shows a grade while the SCORM status is: incomplete. Because in my case we have multi-quizes in the SCORM, and the grade is being updated everytime they make a quiz question. So I would expect that SCORM activity does not send a grade to the gradebook as long as the status is: Incomplete Especially when I choice "last completed attempt" Or is there a setting in Articulate where you can say that the score is only send back when all quizes are done?
Comment 3: You may need to explore the Articulate side of it. From what I've seen of the modules we use of Articulate, it does update the grade each time, though we use Grading Method: Learning Objects That gives us either a 0 if they did open the module but didn't complete the learning objects, or a 1 if they did. It shows a - in the gradebook if they never opened the module yet.
Comment 4: hi Mathew, thank you. The updating of the grade is a "moodle thing" if it happends with Learning objects as well. I can image it is not that "annoying" when it is a learning objec, but with a graded methode it kinda of is. Gem

Forum Post: 
Post title: I've downloaded ims package from openlearn. I can't  upload it  to My Moodle 'cause of  size
Post description: The package is 5 mb and my moodle has limited file's size (2 mb). There are ither possibilities to donwload. For example, xml -file. But how I can put it to Moodle? As I know there is no such mechanism for Moodle lesson
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Hello Julia, As the package is bigger than the maximum file size set up for Moodle, you need to increase that size. For that, you need to be the administrator of your Moodle site, or pass the administrator the following information: In the php.ini file, which is usually located in the /etc/php5/apache2 folder (this location may vary in your case), you need to increase the value of the variable: ; Maximum allowed size for uploaded files. upload_max_filesize = 2M to 10 MB or even more. If you are going to work with scorm packages, I recommend to set up a value of 80 Mb, for instance.

Forum Post: 
Post title: SCORM authoring tools with annotation tool
Post description: Hello everyone, We recently had learners from one of the schools we manage use the Moodle app on their iPads. One essential feature they need is a way to annotate within the platform. While we can use plugins like Amanote on the web version of Moodle, the app doesn't support this since the learners only access it on their iPads to ensure they can work offline. Currently, we're using iSpring to host and upload our content, which includes some drawing tools for annotations. However, the annotations reset after each session, which isn't ideal. I've been looking for alternatives that would allow us to upload content while enabling persistent annotation but haven't found a suitable solution. Alternatively, if we upload content in PDF format, is there a way to prevent the PDFs from being downloaded? Also, is there a plugin compatible with the Moodle app that allows learners to annotate PDFs? I would greatly appreciate any suggestions you might have. Thank you!
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Hello, Teboho! 😊 Recently, I completed the development of an app called Kopere Mobile (you can check out the repository here: Kopere Mobile ). This app was designed specifically to enhance the offline experience for Moodle users by adding features that better meet the needs of students using mobile devices. In Kopere Mobile, we’re already implementing support for annotation features that can be retained after each session, addressing the limitation of iSpring. It offers a stable base for offline interactions, including essential modules that students can access and annotate without losing progress. The idea is to provide a richer experience for those using Moodle in places where internet access may be limited or non-existent, like on ships or in remote areas—so it would be perfect for your students! As for PDFs and the need to prevent downloads, an important feature we suggest is PDF Protect , also integrated into Kopere Mobile. This functionality allows content access control without letting students download the files, protecting the learning materials directly on the platform. You can upload PDF content with annotation enabled and ensure it’s only accessible within the Moodle App environment. Eduardo Kraus Teacher and programmer
Comment 2: Hi Eduardo, Thank you so much for your response and the information. This app might be exactly what we’ve been searching for. I’ll check it out!

Forum Post: 
Post title: What is SCOes?
Post description: Sorry for being such a DODO but what is SCOes and how does it function in a SCORM Course ?
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: SCORM = Sharable Content Object Reference Model . It's an agreed upon standard for re-using learning "objects" which are self contained but communicate through the communications protocol defined in the SCORM api's. SCO = Shareable Content Object. One of the above. Try google for more info or go to adl.org for more.
Comment 2: Hello. I think generally you can understand an SCORM package as a course, and an SCO as a lesson . Anyway it all depends on the guy who constructs those elements.

Forum Post: 
Post title: SCORM 1.2 - MultiSCO - launch certain SCO
Post description: Hello, i have the following challenge: my requirements: SCORM 1.2 Multi-SCO - Package 4 SCOs course-navigation should not be visible i want to load/initialise a certain SCO with javascript For Example: I want to link from one SCO to another scorm.com - Multi-SCORM Example I am glad for every hint.
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Hi Uwe, i've been using SCORM at work for weeks, i think i can help a little. Point by point: * SCORM 1.2 Multi-SCO - Package * 4 SCOs Perfect, you can include in your package any SCO number as you wish, the only rule of thumb is that in a SCO you shouldn't add a link to the contents of another SCO. It's important to remember that all navigation in SCORM 1.2 must be handled by the LMS. * course-navigation should not be visible You have to configure this in Moodle. SCORM 1.2 specification doesn't include navigation (SCORM 2004 does), so there isn't any way to configure this from inside the package. * i want to load/initialise a certain SCO with javascript Check this link ( http://www.adlnet.gov/wp-content/uploads/2011/11/apiwrappers.zip ). I'm sure these javascript files can help you. You can also read the javascript files in the golf example to get a grasp of how to initialize/finalize a SCO. Check also here ( http://www.adlnet.gov/wp-content/uploads/2011/07/SCORM_1_2_pdf.zip ) for doc named 'Runtime environment', for knowing about all the functions the SCORM API has. I want to link from one SCO to another scorm.com - Multi-SCORM Example There shouldn't be a problem if you make sure it opens in a new window. Remember, you musn't link another SCO (or external site, SCORM packages are self-contained) within a SCO. This site helped me also, if you need more info ( http://www.scormcourse.com/scorm12_course/home.html ) Hope it helps a little.
Comment 2: I want to link from one SCO to another scorm.com - Multi-SCORM Example There shouldn't be a problem if you make sure it opens in a new window. Remember, you musn't link another SCO (or external site, SCORM packages are self-contained) within a SCO. Hi Luis, thanks for the additional links and information. The last point is exactly the problem. I need a function like LMS. scormplayer.launchSCO("scoid") or LMS.scormplayer.setcurrentSCO("scoID") like the way if i would click on a menu-item in the moodle-scorm-player-navigation-menu. Two other LMS had provided such a function, therefore i am wondering why it's not possible in moodle!? this would be a supposed process: LMSInitialize("", "") => 0 LMSGetValue("cmi.core.lesson_status") - not attempted => 0 LMSSetValue("cmi.core.lesson_status", "completed") => 0 Commit("", "") => 0 LMSCommit("AJAXResult", "true") => 0 LMSCommit("result", "true") => 0 LMSFinish("AJAXResult", "true") => 0 LMSFinish("result", "true") => 0 LMSFinish("", "") => 0 User clicks (at index.html) on a a link to the second SCO (site1.html). LMSInitialize("", "") => 0 LMSGetValue("cmi.core.lesson_status") - not attempted => 0 LMSSetValue("cmi.core.lesson_status", "completed") => 0 Commit("", "") => 0 LMSCommit("AJAXResult", "true") => 0 LMSCommit("result", "true") => 0 LMSFinish("AJAXResult", "true") => 0 LMSFinish("result", "true") => 0 LMSFinish("", "") => 0 and so on..... In my opinion it has nothing to do with SCORM 2004 and sequencing and navigation. I only want to launch an SCO from another SCO. But how can i initialise or call the second SCO in Moodle?
Comment 3: Hello Uwe , You could come up with a solution , I am also needing the same thing as you . Thank you
Comment 4: Hello Angela, i haven't found a solution yet and i  would be very grateful to anyone for further hints. How can I register or launch a certain SCO in Moodle without using the menu of the scorm-player from moodle? One approach would be to call the same function, that is called if you click on a menu-item of the scorm-player, but i don't know how...
Comment 5: Even after 1/2 a decade I am searching solution for this problem. What has happened at the end with you moodlers?
Comment 6: I'm not sure what you are trying to achieve by that statement... It is up to the SCORM authoring tool to decide what SCO should be launched first. Moodle just follows the SCORM standard and interprets the imsmanifest. xml file. If you are looking for a way to allow a user to finish one SCORM package and then be passed to another it's something I have thought about in the past but no-one has been interested enough in funding the time for a developer to make the change and share it with the community.

Forum Post: 
Post title: SCORM Tracking Records orphaned
Post description: This issue is perhaps akin to the situation where SCORM tracking records are removed when the manifest IDs don't match. However, we have taken care to make sure the identifiers don't change when uploading a new version of the course.  In this case, when uploading an updated SCORM zip, all of the records in scorm_scoes_track get orphaned.  I believe this happens because the SCO IDs get updated in the scorm_scoes table, but the scoid field in the scorm_scoes_track records doesn't get updated. This results in a bunch of records in scorm_scoes_track that reference a scoid that no longer exists, which causes problems for reporting. Has anyone else seen this behavior?  It doesn't seem to happen every time we do an update, which is perplexing, because I have tried debugging through the code to determine if there might be a bug, but have come up empty. Could it be related to a timeout?
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: I've had this a few times when at work - usually seems to be a time out issue for me. Either get an error or no response and need to cancel the upload . At times the file has uploaded anyway, but seems more to do the our work settings as usually goes fine when I try it from home.
Comment 2: I've  seen it happen when someone was using the SCORM and you update the SCORM package - this is particularly a problem if you are using Moodle 2.5 or earlier with the setting "update every time it's used" The main problem was that we relied on the order of the records too much - in 2.6 we added a new sortorder field to the table so now the ids of the scos in moodle don't change during an update.

Post title: Generating reporters in SCORM
Post description: Hi. I recently installed a test SCORM course on our moodle server , and we were wondering if there is a way to generate a report per question without having to look at each user's results individually? Thank you. (moodle version 2.5.2)
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: WOW! Did I really write reporters? I must have been really tired.
Comment 2: If your SCORM package reports this data to Moodle (not all SCORM packages do this) - you can use the interactions report to see a list of the users with the answers they give to each question - you can also download this report as a csv/excel file and manipulate as required. you can also use the trends report (3rd party add-on which requires install) to see some basic statistics on the answers given
Comment 3: Thank you. I didn't notice the Interactions Report tab before. When I click on the tab, it only adds one extra column for my test course called "Response 0", and it's empty for all accounts, including the ones that have taken the course. I'm not sure I understand what the "Response 0" column is for since nothing is currently in it. The test course we have to work with has a couple true or false and a couple multiple choice questions in it. Should they show up under the interactions report? Lastly, if this is because the SCORM course package is probably not reporting the data to Moodle, is there something that needs to be set up in the SCORM package that does? If so, is there somewhere I can find the settings so that I can send them to the other company who is making the SCORM course and ask them to enable these settings? Thank you in advance for your help.

Forum Post: 
Post title: SCORM and 3D!!!!
Post description: Hello everyone, I'm an electrical student doing my final yr project which involves creating an interactive course for the students in my department. I'm not sure if there is a way to package and upload the SL objects/prims created, into moodle where the students can use. Also I have created a course using the elearning XHTML editor in order to package the content as SCORM 1.2. However, I used a url to link to the objects in second life from the course and I'm wondering if anyone knows if that will make the entire course SCORM compliant, including the SL objects? Thanks in advance, usha
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Well, it really comes down to how you configured it. If in the manifest you defined a resource with an external href then technically your good. An LMS will read the manifest when the user clicks that particular sco/asset in the toc and call the url. If it's an asset then no communication will occur back to the lms via an api. If it's defined as a sco then your SL objects are expected to find and initialize via the api object that the LMS deploys to the dom of the browser. I've seen where some courses have a local html file that is defined in the manifest that has it's own code that calls external assets. Technically that goes against the spirit of SCORM as the goal is to have any assets needed for the course to be defined in the manifest so the course is portable between LMSs. When links are buried in the code it makes it difficult to say set up permissions for a new LMS to access content remotely. Again this is mostly spirit type stuff. An lms will not stop it unless say an IT dept has put a block on certain sites or a proxy is used to trottle access etc.

Forum Post: 
Post title: Replacing SCORM content
Post description: dear ladies and gentlemen, [background] we have Moodle 2.7 running, and there is a SCORM package uploaded for a course and running without problem [problem] somehow teacher found some typos and want to update the SCORM package (same content with text revised) [question] how can we  replace / edit the SCORM package by keeping the same statistics already made by student? i can't find any answer by https://docs.moodle.org/27/en/SCORM_settings please help and advice, many thanks.
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Hi there, I think I have a solution for you. First, make sure you've re-exported the SCORM package using the same SCORM ID numbers. I think these ID numbers should by default remain the same in pretty much any development tool -- I know they do in Captivate. In Moodle, click the Edit link to the right of the SCORM package's name on the course page. On the Edit settings page that appears, drag and drop the updated SCORM package onto the "Package file" window to replace the old SCORM package. As long as the SCORM IDs are the same you should retain the previous student data. HTH , Jon
Comment 2: Hi Jon, thanks for your reply. 1) how can I check / know the SCORM IDs in both package? I am not familiar the authoring tool by teacher so I guess I have to check by myself. 2) If they are different, can I just revise it through Notepad? Many thanks!
Comment 3: 2) If they are different, can I just revise it through Notepad? To that the answer is partially yes, you need to check the cpm.js file, the manifest, and the corresponding tables. Hope that helps
Comment 4: The easy answer to your question is to find out if the original "source" file used to create the published SCORM package was updated (as opposed to an entirely new replacement source file being created). If that was the case, it probably won't matter which development tool was used. I know that Captivate won't arbitrarily change the SCORM IDs as long as you reuse the original file.
Comment 5: Agreed with Jon!!

Post title: SCORM 1.2 student preference problems
Post description: Hello everyone, For those of you who have been unable to get certain scorm 1.2 values, well, you can now rest easy - I fixed the problem.  There's an open ticket on it right now, but this fixes these problems. This would apply if you were unable to get the following scorm values: cmi.student_preference.audio cmi.student_preference.language cmi.student_preference.speed cmi.student_preference.text The problem is simply because in the scorm_12.js file, these values were set with empty default values. The fix simply replaces the empty default value with the value from the database . I've tested it extensively with a LMS test prodder and the values are now being returned properly. You can get the updated file by clicking here ... Unzip the file and drop it in the mode/scorm/datamodel directory and the problem should be fixed... caveat:  use at your own risk, of course. Kim

Forum Post: 
Post title: SCORM files skipping questions
Post description: Hi Guys, Apart from the current SCORM issues of not recording results, we have come across another issue where some questions within a SCORM package seem to be randomly skipped. This seems to be more prevalent on a Macintosh machine, however I have seen it happen on Firefox on Windows. This is using Moodle 2.6+ on Linux. SCORMS are produced using articulate. Has anyone else encountered this, and any ideas? CheersPeter
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: I haven't seen an issue related to questions/interactions - there is a setting in Moodle called "auto-continue" that can do some weird stuff with multi-sco packages.
Comment 2: OK - so we should be disabling this? They are single packages, but it does kind of make sense. Usually they are a video followed by a number of questions, followed by further video etc. I will turn that off and see how it goes. Thanks for the quick response. Kind RegardsPeter
Comment 3: auto-continue should be off by default and only turned on specifically when a particular SCORM package you have needs it - it doesn't work with all SCORM packages.
Comment 4: OK - I have turned it off, but still having this issue. SCORM is created on Articulate Storyline 8, and has a number of sections to go in and answer questions. It is set so that if a question is incorrect, it does not let you continue to the next question unless it is correct. Moodle settings for the SCORM are: Display Package: Current Window Student skip content:First access Display attempt status: Entry page only Disable preview mode: Yes Display course structure on entry: No Display course structure in player: Disabled Grading method: Highest grade Maximum grade: 100 Num of attempts: Unlimited Attempts grading: Highest attempt Force new attempt: Yes Lock after final attempt: Yes Force completed: Yes Auto-continue: No I have had people using firefox and windows with issues of skipping questions - fairly obvious when they get a non 100% score. There are others which are simpler (straight through video and questions) which seem to skip questions as well. We never saw this issue under 2.4.3, however after upgrading to 2.6 have seen it on a regular basis. Any further thoughts? Kind Regards Peter

Forum Post: 
Post title: SCORM Package network share?
Post description: Not sure if this is possible, but here goes... We would like to have 1 intranet server (Windows) with the main role of serving the Moodle 2.0 website and it's courses. We would like to be able to create courses but store the SCORM Packages (.zip) on a separate server in a network share and link them to the courses. We have multiple departments all over the country and everyone trying to pull down the SCORM content would drag the network down, so we would like to keep the SCORM Packages duplicated on seperate servers. We are capable of redirecting requested shares to point to a local server, but I can't seem to create an external link to the SCORM .zip file. It always insits on uploading it to the server. If I can't create links to the SCORM .zip within a course, is it possible to point to a local folder or repository on the web server and have a symlink to a network share? Is it possible in Moodle 1.9? All my efforts have failed so far and I've been unable to find anything in the docs or on the forums, so any help would be appreciated. Thanks.
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Hi Alan, Check out the information here: http://docs.moodle.org/20/en/SCORM_FAQ#SCORM_Administration_Options Specifically Enable external package type and Enable downloaded package type. Note that if you host the package on a separate domain , the browser will not allow scripting between Moodle & the package. So all comm through the API is not available if you do it that way. Have you looked at the repository API http://docs.moodle.org/dev/Repository_API options available via Moodle 2 file picker? Regards, A
Comment 2: Hi Amy, Thanks for replying. I had already checked that first link. The downloaded packge type won't work, as it downloads the package to the Moodle server and that's not what we want. The External Package type is setup and working, but unfortunately it appears to only be HTTP links allowed. We were hoping to use UNC paths (\\server\share\SCORMPackage.zip). As it's all within the local domain, Moodle server and Windows shares are all within the intranet, I was hoping the API would work as expected. I had read a few items about linking to various files, however the files always seemed to be media related (jpgs, video, etc) for embedding in pages. I haven't as yet seen anything mention a link to a SCORM package or using a package via a windows share. I did manage to set up a repository and place a sym link within the directory to a windows share. Through that I managed to select a SCORM package from the windows share on another server, but Moodle then downloaded the package to the Moodle server. I'll have a look at the Repository API and see if I can sort something out through that. Thanks. Regards, Alan

Post title: Closing SCORM Window (Close button [x])
Post description: Our course developers are using Lectora by Trivantis to generate a SCORM package. The package contains all the course work, some are quite long - 4 to 8 hours long. The problem is students are using the Close button for the browser window (upper right corner) instead of the Save and Exit button provided by Lectora. When a student clicks the Close button, their course progress is not saved by the LMS. In an eight hour course, this stings more than a little. I would very much like to get in front of the close (unload) event by using the onBeforeUnload event. I have written JavaScript that works in the SCORM Cloud for all browsers and most recent versions. I have tried altering the titlemgr.html provided by Trivantis, but IE fails to display the message to warn off using the Close button in Moodle; however, in SCORM Cloud this approach works for all browsers and most recent versions. Where do you suggest I place this JavaScript so when a student clicks the Close button, a message displays warning them off and to use the Save and Exit button? I have versions of the JS for DOM and HTML. I have the ability to modify the PHP or JS files in the mod/scorm directory. Thank you in advance.
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Any luck on getting this resolved? We have run into the same issue. If the user closed the window in either save and close or the close button in the browser, it tracks properly, but only in Firefox . In IE and Chrome, the browser close button does not track. Interesting enough I have tried a simple course as well with Captivate. The close button works fine in Firefox and Chrome, but not in IE. Any help would be greatly appreciated.
Comment 2: We are still in the process of resolving the issue with Articluate generated SCORM packages. We have resolved the issue with Trivantis Lectora generated SCORM pacakges by modifying the template used to generate our SCORM packages. After Trivantis reviewed our Lectora template, they saw issues with the timer function, which adds seconds then closes (exits) the course once 360 seconds (6 minutes) has lapsed. In addition, the course in the package was also continually adding to the timer variable. Finally, Trivantis revealed that after the close action, SCORM data was still being transmitted to the LMS. Our Lectora editor created a new variable in the timer function to ensure that the timer stopped adding to the timeout variable once the timeout was called. Previously, there was no ‘stop’ action.
Comment 3: Thanks for the reply Kevin. We have a large course in Lectora that really needs to be fixed. The client is really mad at this point. Is that updated Lectora template available? If so, how can we get it. Thanks again
Comment 4: Hey Kevin, Could you please point us in the direction of the Lectora solution for this problem. We can't seem to be able to find anyone over at Lectora who either is aware of this issue nor knows of a solution.  We currently have a course for a large group of folks that is about 3 1/2 hours long and if they accidentally exit with the windows (x) in IE... its all gone!!! any help would be greatly appreciated! Rob
Comment 5: Managed to find a solution in Lectora that was pretty simple for the next button which is a global button I added a getURL action OnShow and did:  Javascript: LMSCommit() and now it updates page you are on and any other LMS Data everytime you go next. and it is remembered if you accidentally hit the IE Colse (x) button Rob

Post title: Multi-Scorm-Package | moodle 2.2 and Captivate 5.5
Post description: Hello everyone, i want to include a multi-scorm-package in moodle, which i created with Adobe Captivate 5.5. Every single scorm package represents one lesson of my test. After one completed lesson it should automatically jump forward to the next lesson, but if one lesson is incomplete, the user should be able to start at the same point in the next session. My Problem is: After a completed lesson, the next lesson doesn't start automatically and the user has to choose it manually from the navigation-bar next to the Application-Window. Another problem is, that bookmarks are just set when the user is in the last lesson of the test. If the user is in a previous lesson, the test starts in the next lesson on a new session. Those problems still exist, when i check the configurations, which force the test to continue automatically. Do i have to set some other configurations in captivate or moodle? Thanks for your reply.
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Hi Yvonne, give Auto-continue setting a try. Read more about potential issues at http://moodle.org/mod/forum/discuss.php?d=171597#p752601 . HTH , Matteo
Comment 2: To automatically step into the next lesson you need to add a "go to URL " action on the final slide of each lesson in captivate. You can typically use something like this: ../lesson/lesson.swf Hope this helps.

This is to inform you that you’re are going in the right direction and the problem lies with the SCORM package. You’re trying to upload an articulated zip file, but I’m sorry to say that it’s not there in the SCORM platform that Moodle specifically requires. Please make sure that the zip file should contain the file named "imsmanifest. xml ". For better reference, you can visit the link given below:- http://docs.moodle.org/25/en/SCORM_FAQ#Incorrect_file_package_-_missing_imsmanifest.xml_or_AICC_structure : point 14.7 I hope this’ll solve the issue. Please feel free to get back to us for further query. Warm Regards Purnendu DualCube
Comment 2: Ye i think you have the answer there, it is missing that file, as i have uploaded a zip version of Articulate Quizmaker and it worked and has that file, but with the Presenter it doesnt seem to have that file when zipped, how do i include this file in the presenter ? Your help is very useful to me Kind Regards Colin
Comment 3: Hi Colin! It’s so nice to hear from you again. Let’s get back to the problem where you’ve been stuck. Please unzip the Articulate Presenter SCORM package, copy and paste the "imsmanifest.xml" file in the unzipped folder and then again zip the folder using any file compressor software such as winzip, winrar, etc. If you don't have the imsmanifest.xml, then you need to re-publish SCORM packages with SCORM authoring tool Articulate Presenter where the imsmanifest.xml file is in the correct place. The link we’ve provided you have the detailed description of how to create the SCORM package. Please have a look at this: http://docs.moodle.org/25/en/SCORM_FAQ#Incorrect_file_package_-_missing_imsmanifest.xml_or_AICC_structure I hope this’ll be of your help. Looking forward to hearing from you. Keep on Moodling! Cheers! Purnendu DualCube

Forum Post: 
Post title: Moodle upgrade from 2.4 to 2.5
Post description: I am working on a project using Moodle 2.4. We have done lot of customization for which we have added several custom tables and also additional fields in the existing Moodle tables. In addition, there are lot of design changes as well. My client wants to upgrade Moodle 2.4 to 2.5. What is the best way to do this? What are the challenges that we are going to faces during this process, especially for a site with lot of customization already done? Please offer your suggestions! Thanks in advance.
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Are you your changes implemented as plug-ins? If so, upgrading should not be a problem, but you will have to read the release notes carefully, and test all your plug-ins to verify they are compatible with Moodle 2.5. If you have just hacked Moodle core code, then you have a mess. You need to learn from that and re-work your changes as plugins.
Comment 2: Hi Tim, Thanks for your reply. We have not used any plug-ins. Let me elaborate about my application a little bit here. We have combined several custom php web pages with some of the Moodle's features like uploading course content, viewing scorm content, generating reports, etc. We took Moodle's MySQL database and made necessary customization (addition of fields or tables) for the features built in the website. What does really happen during upgrades? Does it affect the database (or) other files (or) all of them? Information on this may help us to understand how to go about upgrade... Please let me know if you need any other details from me? Thanks again, SK
Comment 3: When you do an in-place upgrade (warning: good backups), the database and moodledata folder are adjusted to the new specifications (tables/fields/files/folders addd/dropped/adjusted). The upgrade should not affect any tables/fields that you added to the database yourself. A better way can be to clone your database and moodledata folder and use the copies to create the new version of Moodle. Moodle code is usually placed in a new folder parallel to the old code. You can then compare the php files that were edited by you and modify the new version accordingly. It is more work than using git -based merge, which is also possible to do, but safer since you can first evaluate the new functionality and decide how to transfer a given add-on feature.

Post title: Scorm 1.2 with integrated test doesn't work in Moodle 4.1 and 4.5
Post description: Dear All, After migrating to Moodle 4.1 and later to 4.5 we realised that courses in SCORM 1.2, which have the integrated test, are not being tracked correctly on Moodle. With SCORM 2004 4th generation it seems to work but we have courses developed by third party providers so it is not a solution. Has anyone found a solution for this issue? Thank you, M
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Same here. We've tried different possibilities but nothing seems working. Have anyone solved the issue? @community Thank you!
Comment 2: I believe if "Force new attempt" is not set to "No" in Settings > Attempts management, this will prevent the activity from entering review mode, and thus all subsequent attempts will be recorded.

Post title: Scorm package with Captivate 5.5 on Moodle 2.1
Post description: As I indicated in the title, I have created a scorm package with Captivate 5.5. And we are testing Moodle 2.1as LMS. When I try to upload the zip file, I see a loading message. But it does stuck there and does not go through the next step. I reduced the file size, and retry it, but I got still the same loading window. If that is the case, how can I figure out which part cause the problem? I read someone mentions Wireshark. How does it work? Sami
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Ensure that you have setup SCORM reporting in captivate 5.5 - Edit, Preferences, Quiz, Reporting, "Enable reporting for this project", Standard: SCORM. I had a similar problem and found out that the reporting was not setup correctly in captivate. Also ensure that you are using scorm 1.2 and not 2004 because Moodle doesn't support 2004 as far as I understand. Also, consider upgrading to 2.2 http://docs.moodle.org/22/en/Upgrading

Post title: Moodle 1.8 + Captivate 2.0 = Still problems
Post description: Hi Everyone, I am using captivate 2.0 with moodle 1.8 with no luck. I seem to be having the same old problems of no grade being passed on. I have tried SCORM 1.2 and 2004. Tried just about every option I could think of with no luck. I tried this knowledge base solution with no luck as well http://www.adobe.com/cfusion/knowledgebase/index.cfm?event=view&id=KC.kb401439&extid=kb401439&dialogID=16624426&iterationID=1&sessionID=4830a1dde26a2f307664&stateID=0+0+16632774&mode=simple Which basically is Edit the SCORM.htm file in a text editor, such as Notepad. Find this line (by default, it is line #27): var g_intAPIOrder = 0; Change the line to this: var g_intAPIOrder = 1; Save the file and republish your project. After making this change, my flash screen doesnt load in the SCORM module on Moodle. It uploads fine, but the content of the swf just never loads. If anyone has any solutions.... Thanks!!! Eric
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Update: This only seems to be an issue when using IE7. I have double checked to make sure JavaScript is on, etc. But nothing seems to work. Which is not good, because alot of users, use IE7 these days. Any ideas????
Comment 2: No idea, but I am using the same constellation (IE7+Captivate2+Moodle1.8) and I can get scoring to work reliably only when I use IE7. I tried Firefox and Opera, Firefox works half and Opera not at all. There are currently about as many IE6 users as there are IE7 users. And depending on where you look Firefox has a share between 10% and 40%. Developers of applicationa working with browsers have to make sure that the applications work fine with both browsers. That is possible only by adhering to W3C standards (and Opera is the currently the only fully standards compliant browser). We do not need any of these " IE only" solutions, especially when even those don't seem to work reliably as in Eric's case.

Forum Post: 
Post title: SCORM HTML5 Course Crashing/Timeout
Post description: We have recently migrated from using Flash to HTML5 scorm courses. All of the courses have not had issues except for one. This particular course is about 90 questions long, each question having an associated question pool. When a user tries to take the test, it initially load fine, but it eventually chokes up when loading the next question. The browser displays a 503 http error (service unavailable) when this happens and it can not finish loading the page. At this point, the user is forced to close the window that the course is in and they have to re-login into Moodle. My hunch is that the cause for this is that HTML5 breaks up the data transfer between Moodle and the Scorm course into individual HTTP requests. Due to the amount of data Scorm is trying to exchange, it hits some kind of limit in either PHP or IIS that restarts the current session / application pool (which is why the user gets logged off) Interested if anyone has had a similar experience or if anyone has suggestions on how to limit scorm requests. Other info:   Moodle version 3.1+ on IIS hosted on a dedicated Windows server with plenty of resources.
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: I'd suggest testing the SCORM file on SCORM Cloud or another instance of Moodle (maybe Moodle Cloud ) to see if it's something limited to just your system. Also, anything in the error logs of PHP?
Comment 2: I was told that the course was tested in Scorm Cloud and had the same results. PHP didn't have anything in the logs. I noticed on the response for the 503 error, it says its unable to write to database . That could either be the issue, or a symptom of the service being interrupted. Database is MS SQL 2014 and resides on the same instance as the webserver.
Comment 3: If the course does not work in SCORM Cloud, then I'd approach the vendor of the software that was used to create the SCORM module (Ie: Articulate or Trivantis or whoever). They may have simply not done enough testing with their software package for that large a pool of questions and you are running into some limits there?
Comment 4: Hey Piotr Krok , I am currently facing similar issues with our scorm content on moodle 3.3.2+ with IIS and php7.1.11. How did you solve the issue?

Forum Post: 
Post title: All SCROM course fail to load - FlashPlayer
Post description: I'm farily new to Moodle and have been working on a VERY annoying issue for over a week. I have searched numerous forums and can't really locate an answer to my problem, possibly because I may not understand what the problem really is. We have had a successful Moodle installation running for about 6 months as a test for course distribution in SCORM format. Up until sometime in the recent past, everything was working fine - everyone involed was thrilled. At some point in the last 1-2 months, everyting went awry and now no courses will actually load... unless you uninstall the Adobe Flash Player COMPLETELY from your system and use an HTML5 Highly compliant browser (Like Safari), in which case everything is still beautiful. The best I can figure is that some update from Adobe of the last several months has introduced an issue that allows the initial load of the framework of a course, but the course just sits and spins eternally from that point forward. We have re-exported, updated Moodle to 2.4.1, and updated the course production software (Articulate Storyline), played with every export option we can think of and have pretty much destroyed the world and completely rebuilt everything. Nothing works. The only thing I wish could happen, but that our hosting will not allow, is a full server reboot. So, anyone else ever see this issue? It's platform and system wide (Win, Mac, Explorer, Safari, Chrome, Firefox , etc.) We're at a total loss. Thanks in advance to anyone that has a clue what might be happening.
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: On our hosting platform this issue is most commonly associated with zlib compression. Classic presentation is that the base HTML file and SWF are loaded into the SCORM player, but the SWF is not able to load any audio or video assets, and therefore stalls. It sounds very similar to what you're describing. You can check your zlib compression settings as an admin by loading up the Server > phpinfo page. But zlib compression would need to be disabled by a server admin.
Comment 2: Yep, that looks to have helped. It's odd that this has just occurred in a previously working environment. Thanks for the clarification on where the stall occurs... which explained why it felt like a Flash issue.

Post title: Flash - Moodle and access to mdl_user table
Post description: Hi all, I make an flash scorm application to use with Moodle. I'll be able to retreive some value from Moodle like LMSGetValue, cmi.core.student_id etc. But how can access to mdl_user from Flash? Help please Eric
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: To pull the current Moodle user, just use .GetValue("cmi.learner_name"); This should give you the current logged in student's name via a slightly different technique. I don't believe SCORM will allow you to directly access mdl_user. Instead you need to use the standard SCORM commands rather than Moodle specific settings. Within Flash, I then do the following to pull out the name in a more useable format - this is because you sometimes find that the LMS stores the data in less user friendly format. To pull the name correctly I use this Actionscript code: // SCORM - grab learner name
Comment 2: Hi Andrew, First, THANKS for your feedback... I understand what you tell me about the .GetValue, but I have made a table similar to mdl_user and I want to set/get some custom value in it like avatar, progression, medals, percent etc... How can I do that? Thanks Eric
Comment 3: You will have to go outside of SCORM to get that info. Write a PHP script to extract that info. Place it in the public_html/mod/ directory, and make calls to the PHP script from Flash. You might want to look at these projects by Matt Bury: http://code.google.com/p/moodle-swf/ Good luck, A

Forum Post: 
Post title: What is the right SCORM folder?
Post description: Immediately after I upload a new SCORM I see a new folder in /moddata/scorm. But after a while I don't know anymore which folder corresponds to which SCORM package. Is there a way to know it without having to look somewhere in the DB? (maybe by looking at some link created in Moodle?). Thanks
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: I think when u mouse over the link to the course there is an id that is displayed on the taskbar of the browser after ?i= which should be same as the folder from which it is being pulled. Alternately you can click the link and this should display the id in the url.
Comment 2: Why to do you need to know where Moodle puts your SCORM package? Such knowledge can be dangerous. If you want to modify a package, you should modify it on your local machine and then upload it again. Don't try to modify Moodle's moddata copy. Sorry in advance if I misunderstood your intention.
Comment 3: Yes John, that's exactly what I want to do: modify the SCORM package right in its place. But don't worry: this is only done for didactic reasons. I want to introduce my students to simple HTML modifications and I'd like to show them how they can modify a SCORM package (that they are creating with PowerPoint, this also to introduce them to another concept of IT: programming) without having to modify the powerpoint presentation, convert it again to SCORM and the upload it again to Moodle. It doesn't matter if they will end by destroying the SCORM. That will teach them how careful they must be with "manual" HTML. I looked at several URL but I cannot see any reference to the SCORM folder. Or at least I think I saw it for just one instant, but I couldn't find it anymore. So, please, help me in easily finding the URL name.
Comment 4: The SCORM package that you upload is unzipped by Moodle in the moodledata directory that you specified when you installed Moodle. Within the moodledata directory, there is a directory with a numeric id for each course (this is the "course files" area of the course). Within that directory there is a moddata directory containing directories for the various Moodle activities . If the course has one or more SCORM activities, you will see a directory named scorm. Within that directory, you will see more numbered directories. These correspond to the numeric id's assigned by Moodle in the database . Within each of those directories, you'll see the unzipped package. Of course you (as teacher) can navigate to the package using Moodle's files interface (Administration -> Files). Naturally your students cannot do this unless you give them the capability, which is possible (but probably not wise) in Moodle 1.7. If you or your students have shell access to the machine, you can also navigate to the SCORM directory using the OS command line. On my linux system, for example, 'cd /var/moodledata/10/moddata/scorm/9' gets me to one of my SCORM packages. Modifying a SCORM package in place within Moodle is dangerous. It is infinitely more dangerous if you allow students to do it! That consideration alone should dissuade you from doing it. Furthermore, I don't see the didactic value of this exercise. I would make this exercise an upload Assignment which instructs students to create a SCORM package using the RELOAD editor. They create the package, preview it, make some more changes, preview it again, etc., until it meets the requirements you set out in the Assignment. Students submit the finished zipped SCORM package to the Assignment. Then YOU load their packages into Moodle. That way students can see what other students have done. For real didactic value, make it a Workshop.
Comment 5: Hi John, I guess you answered my question by saying that the id/package association is kept in the DB. So, if I correctly understand it, this association is not visible anywherelse in Moodle. As for the task, I'm teaching my students e-learning. Each of them has its own separate Moodle course that she manages as a teacher. So they have their own folders and packages. Hence there is no harm in allowing them to play with the scorm package, as it is an organized set of HTML/ javascript / xml /etc files that they are going to fully understand. If they damage a SCORM package, they are going to redo some work to fix it (or reload it). They are also producing SCORMs using EXE-learning and testing them with RELOAD. But e-learning means fast reaction when a change is needed. So, as I like to teach in a problem/solution way, I wanted to "convince" them that knowing HTML can be worth it, in a very straightforward way. And allowing them to perform simple modifications to a SCORM package is an idea that I liked a lot. I guess I will have to teach them how to do it for now only on the last uploaded package (i.e. the last folder in their scorm folder). When I'll move to management of MySQL DBs I will show them how to know which package is where. I hoped there was a simpler way to know it. But, from a Moodle point of view, I understand that it is not necessary at all. Thanks for your help Stefano
