Post title: dataFromFlash Javascript error
Post description: I have output a SCORM 1.2 file from Captivate 4, loaded as an activity into Moodle 1.9.1, and the grades aren't recorded while using Firefox , but they do in IE . Firefox does throw this error when the LMS is initializing: Error: dataFromFlash is not defined Source File: javascript :dataFromFlash('LMSInitialize',%20'',%20"",%20'initialized_bln'); Line: 1 Clearly the quotes are screwed up on this call and this may be the root of the problem, however, I have no idea where this is being called from. Any ideas? - R
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Hi Rob, Unzip the package and look through your .html and .js files to find the javascript function titled "dataFromFlash." Either your swf or your html page that contains the swf is calling this function in order to initialize.
Comment 2: Thanks for the reply Amy. I actually did search the files and found the dataFromFlash function, but not where it is being called from. My gut feeling is that it is some Actionscript->Javascript call from Captivate. Ultimately, I am just trying to get SCORM projects out of Captivate, into Moodle, and have the grades recorded to Moodle. It's this last step that is presenting the biggest problem. Do you have any experience using Captivate with Moodle successfully? - R
Comment 3: The Flash is certainly making an externalInterface for FSCommand call to the JS function. You are right about that. That's why I suggested that you override it by calling the function on load from the HTML wrapper. SCORM is a sketchy standard, and our developers are doing the best they can with it. Right now Moodle will do very well recording lesson_status, session_time, and score_raw. You should be fine if you report a single grade from your sco and you don't depart from the 0-100 point scale. Obviously, you have no control over what's coming from Captivate, however. So I can't really be of much more help to you than that. You can always use the SCORM debugger to track what API functions the sco is calling, however. If you have Flash, you could also import the Captivate project file into Flash and view the function calls that way. And you can talk to Captivate support to find out how their scos behave, and what API functions they call at what time. I don't use Captivate to build eLearning. But many of our customers do. I am the one that tweaks their swf/html/js/ xml when their Captivate export isn't doing what they want. This happens much less often for Captivate than it does for Articulate, that's for sure. What I usually tell people is to use a Moodle technology to deliver the assessment, and use a technology like Captivate to build interactivity, and just embed it in a Moodle page. That way non-technical users don't have to struggle with SCORM. I myself prefer to stick with lesson_status and not mess with setting scores from a sco. Hopefully there's some information in here you can use, Rob. Good luck. A
Comment 4: *** UPDATE *** I never got to the bottom of my dataFromFlash problem, HOWEVER, I did finally get Moodle to accept the scores from Firefox. Since I have seen this in the issue discussed past without a clue as to the final resolution, I am posting the settings with which I was finally able to succeed. I hope this helps someone else avoid the aggravation that i have endured the last 2 1/2 days! This currently only updates the grading. Not sure about tracking progress from within the Flash file: QUIZ REPORTING PREFERENCES Standard: SCORM Manifest... version: 1.2 Report Status: Complete/Incomplete Report to LMS: Percent Choose Rerport Data: Quiz Results and Slide Views Reporting Level: Interactions & Score LMS Customization Settings: Never Send Resume Data Escape Vars & Session ID PROJECT PUBLISH PREFERENCES ActionScript Version: AS2 I think the ActionScript version may be the culprit in this scenario. In one module, the grades would not record until I made that switch. Curiouser and curiouser. If I learn more, I will post. - R

Forum Post: 
Post title: Error when uploading SCORM package
Post description: When we try to upload SCORM pkg, we get an error saying "Incorrect Module" Please help and tell what could be the possible reason for this error
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Hi - can you provide screenshots of the problem. Are you using the latest 1.9.3 weekly build? Cheers, Piers Harding.
Comment 2: I cannot provide a screenshot because I never took one. For your information, we are using 1.9.2 version of moodle. The errors which we get are random, intermittent and when we go back to upload again, they work properly. What I can say is that when I create SCORM packages, I do it using a tool called Articulate. In Articulate, I have the option to publish for Web or for LMS. Since these are not scoring modules, a couple of times I forgot to package for LMS and packaged for Web instead. The web packages do not contain a manifest file. There were a couple of times that Moodle flagged that for me and told me it could not upload because the manifest file was not found. However, there were also times that it uploaded my web file package successfully and it played fine. Not sure if it's related but it is certainly another discrepancy in moodle 1.9.2 What I will do is next time I receive any kind of errors related to SCORM package uploading, I will take screenshot and post it across.
Comment 3: There are two major points of concern here. The first is that you are using 1.9.2, which means that it is very likely that there are 3+ months worth of solid mod/scorm hacking that you don't have. Please upgrade at your earliest convenience. Secondly, the fact that you managed to upload a package without a manifest file, and it still worked, most likely means that you have some form of caching working (browser/web server ), that is distorting the outcome. Where ever there is JavaScript development going on, it is always important to rule out caching issues by clearing your browser cache (clear cache, close browser, start again ....). If after upgrade, these problems still persist, then get in touch with me, and I'll test your package (so long as you can provide me with repeatable steps etc.). Cheers, Piers Harding.

Forum Post: 
Post title: Scorm Reporting
Post description: Hi, I have uploaded a Scorm made with Articulate which has a final assessment on it where the tracking is done.  It is tracked as pass/fail.  Where do I find the information in Moodle who has taken the Scorm and whether they have passed or failed?
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Stuart, You can find this information located under the activities block -> Scorms/Aicc -> View reports and then view the attempt for each student. Remember Pass and Fail will be reported to the grade book as 1 - Pass and 0 - fail ( from Articulate), when the Scorm object is set for a Learning Object when you are reporting off the slides. You can also create a custom scale to show that data to the student, these changes can be made on the front page under Grades ->Scales _ add new scale. Here is the link to the information on creating new scales: http://docs.moodle.org/en/Scales If you are reporting off the quiz I would would just leave the score and then set the pass grade in the grade book to what ever you institution prefers.
Comment 2: Is there a way I can get an overview of who has taken it, and who has passed or failed?
Comment 3: Under that same section Scorms/AICC -> view reports for x attempts. This report will lists who has taken the module an a score but the score will reflect a 1 or 0 not a value of Pass or Fail only Articulate.
Comment 4: You have to hunt for the text answers from the student in the cmi.suspend data viewed.
Comment 5: Thanks for the information. How can we see how the student did on the test on each question so that we can review the exam with the student? In my exam, I created with Articulate, I also had some short answer questions that I would like to see how they were answered. Thanks!

Forum Post: 
Post title: setting up completion reporting with a SCORM course?
Post description: I have a SCORM course and am trying to figure out a way I can determine who is completing the SCORM course. I have multiple quizzes inside this course that give a number grade at the end of the course (ie 85/100). How do I extract the variable number in the SCORM course to be reflected in the reporting module for Moodle? Is it actually possible? And how do I know when a user completes the SCORM course? Any tips and insight on this would be great. Thanks!
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: This usually depends on the authoring software that you use to create the SCORM package. I believe that most authoring software lets you define a criteria of when the student has "completed" the training. Which authoring software are you using to make your SCORM package? For example, here are some helpful links for Articulate Storyline: https://www.articulate.com/support/storyline/when-content-communicates-completion-to-an-lms-304 https://community.articulate.com/discussions/articulate-storyline/completion-and-tracking-storyline-course-in-articulate-online
Comment 2: Appreciate the response. I've gotten the variable numbers to record in the grade report of Moodle. However, I'm having a problem getting the actual course in moodle to say "completed". I've changed the grade settings to Learning Objects but still even if I reach the threshold of the grade (ie. 15/100) the course won't be completed even though I've set the threshold in course completion settings. Any idea why the SCORM package won't say completed in moodle's courses?
Comment 3: Still don't know what you use.  I use lectora and you have to add a variable at the end that changes a status to completed.  I also use captivate and you have to tell it specifically when to say completed (and you have to check the box!). You might not be happy with Learning Objects, especially if you have grades.  I never use it. I spent a chunk of time fighting with it, finally figured out what it did and decided I didn't want to use it.  Now I don't remember what it does, just that I don't use it.  Probably not helpful but there you go. I actually don't usually check the completed box in Moodle, I require a grade...if you've got a grade requirement, make sure your quizzes inside are reporting (I frequently have a condition at the end of my course when there is more than one quiz that if each one is passed, then it marks completed--in Lectora, I haven't done any this detailed in Captivate) and you can even have it total the scores and average across (in the scorm), then you overwrite the final grade with the total average.
Comment 4: Thanks for the response. I'm using ZebraZapps (but I used to use lectora, i've transferred all my apps over to it). It's really strange, so I've actually set up the grade requirement and my quizzes are reporting the correct grade when it is completed. I have users that have 15 or 20 on their score (20 is the max on my courses for the quiz) and it still isn't recording completed. Is there any other setting you have active in Lectora?

Forum Post: 
Post title: Problem with scorm on IE
Post description: Hi! I am using a scorm made in iSpring... I am testing the site in 3 browsers, Firefox , Chrome and IE In Firefox and Chrome i access the scorm and moodle record my grades... In IE it just dont record... I have searched a little bit about that find some workarrounds but nothing seems to work nice... Someone know how can i do this works on IE8/IE9 ?? Hope someone can help me, my company really need this to make our project start to work, Thanks for the attention! Cheers!
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: First make sure you're running the latest stable 2.2 or 2.3 code. if you're using 1.9 - you should upgrade to Moodle 2 to get improved stability. If it's IE9 that is causing you issues and your SCORM packages implement Flash then it's possible this bug is the issue: https://bugbase.adobe.com/index.cfm?event=bug&id=2928139 (fix is to force compatibilty mode for IE9 by adding some meta to your theme header)
Comment 2: Thanks Dan for you help, i have readed a lot of documents and post about that this last hours. I am using moodle 2.2 since the beginning... Nice to know that theres a fix... but the problem is... how can i do that? I read about some of those fixes but i dont know how should i do them... 1) I can put the meta in my header like you said... but i need to put it in the entire site? Or just in the player.php screen, or maybe the mod/scorm/view.php? What is the right meta i have to add to make it work without changing how any other browser see my moodle?? 2) I read here http://moodle.org/mod/forum/discuss.php?d=204155&parent=890553 that i can put this code in .htaccess (i am using a linux server ), this fix will change how any other browser see my moodle?? Thanks for the attention again and REALLLYY thanks for the help! (Sorry about my english, not my nativa language)
Comment 3: I haven't tried the .htaccess method - not sure if it works reliably or not. you need to open the theme you are using and make sure this line is added directly after <head> <meta http-equiv="X-UA-Compatible" content="IE=8" /> It MUST be the first item after <head> as it doesn't work when added after other items You can wrap it in a check to see if the path is mod/scorm if you want and check if IE 9 is the browser but that's up to you.

Post title: SCORM time spent tracking on Lessons
Post description: Dear All, is it possible to track time spent on each lesson of scorm package within a activity ?? Like: Lesson Time Spent lesson1 l00:01:00 minute lesson2 l00:05:00 minute lesson3 l00:02:00 minute
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Hi Jalpa, Do you mean each SCO within a SCORM package? If so, then yes, you set cmi.session_time to the LMS, and the LMS will add up all of the cmi.session_time for a single SCO for a single user into total_time, which is a read only value stored in the LMS. -A

Forum Post: 
Post title: Want to put severl links to same SCORM in same course
Post description: I'm using a SCORM package that works pretty well - it's quite big and during the course of the course I want students to go back to it. To do that I want to link to the same SCORM activity from several lessons. The SCORM object keeps track of the students progress so they can enter it at the right point each time BUT, if I put the SCORM into a lesson with Add activity, each instance of it is seen as entirely new - i.e. while progress is saved in lesson 1, when they click the link in lesson 5 they are back to the start. I'm going to have to put just one link in for the whole course, but it really would be nice to have multiple links in multiple lessons so students can get to the SCORM from where they are in the course - suggestions???? Huggs Marshal
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Hi Marshal, If I am understanding you correctly, then there is a way you can do this. Go to your SCORM activity and copy the URL from the address bar. Go to the Lesson of the course you want to add it to. From the Add Resource list, choose Link to a file or web page Give a Title to your link and paste the URL of your SCORM activity in the URL box For Window, choose Same Window For Keep page navigation visible... choose No. Then Save it That should give you the results you want.
Comment 2: Thanks for that Ron - I thought that would be the work around and it works just fine. Only problem for me is that I wanted to display different instructions at the top of the SCORM page, but I think if I fool around with your idea I should come up with a way of fixing that. Marshal

Post title: Error during: Moodle 2.5.2 AICC Direct URL
Post description: Problem While we were using 2.3 we were dabbling in using the "External AICC URL " and were happy with the results. Content from Kenexa's LCMS 8.2 would be available, using a URL generated using an AICC Export generator, in Moodle 2.3.x. It took a bit of work to sort everything out as there wasn't a lot of documentation available from Kenexa on how to use the AICC Export tools. Now we've upgraded to Moodle 2.5.2 and we're running into some issues that prevent us from creating any new activities that include External AICC URLs. All existing activities that include them work fine. The content loads, the grades are recorded, etc. Details This is the "publish. xml " file that the LCMS uses to create the AICC URL and Export: <publish_configuration> <destination> <id>02</id> <label>Moodle</label> <url>http:// domain /moodle</url> <standard>pens</standard> <transport_location>http://domain/subdomain/evsfiles/exports</transport_location> <transport_userid></transport_userid> <transport_account>yyyyyyy</transport_account> <transport_password>yyyyyyy</transport_password> <system_userid>xxxxxx</system_userid> <system_password>xxxxxx</system_password> </destination> This file hasn't changed any since we got it working the first time, and worked until Moodle was upgraded. This is the error presented when an External AICC URL is added to an activity (Note: "SUBDOMAIN" added to the Set-Cookie line for security reasons): Invalid URL specified. Debug message:

Content-Type: text/html
Content-Length: 117
Date: Tue, 10 Sep 2013 13:30:14 GMT

Made sure all of the basics that I know of were covered, "Enable direct AICC url" checked and "Enable external AICC HACP" checked in the SCORM Package, Plugin settings. In the activity settings, under the appearance options, "Display course structure in player" is disabled (The course structure broke the "player" in version 2.3.x when AICC URLs were loading). All user names used in to produce the External AICC URL are still correct and working. Nothing has changed outside of the Moodle Upgrade and 
database
 tables update that came with it.

Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Hi Eric, do you have configured a proxy in your Moodle settings ? IIRC a change happened in the way Moodle download s resources so it could be possible that that proxy is not allowed to reach the URL you're submitting as External AICC URL . HTH , Matteo
Comment 2: Matteo, Thank you for the information, but no, we are not using a proxy for our moodle. Both the Moodle and the LCMS sit on the same test server currently.
Comment 3: Is there a better sub-forum I could ask this question on? I'm not sure if it is actually a problem with SCORM or AICC but more of a technical nature? Thanks!
Comment 4: Hi Eric, it seems not related to SCORM/AICC but to the inability of Server/PHP/Moodle to download that URL. To verify the statement above, you could try to put that URL in your browser to see if the file will be downloaded, then you could do the same check in the server hosting your Moodle instance by means of wget / curl command to check if the same URL will be downloaded in that context . If yes, then the issue is in Moodle otherwise is outside Moodle and belongs to the network security context: indeed in the debug message you can see that HTTP 403 is returned by a Java service, having a Java session been created by means of a JSESSIONID cookie so it looks like Moodle is calling your LCMS but the URL provided cannot be directly accessed for some reasons. Your setup is particular and it will be difficult to replicate it in a standard Moodle deployment unless we'll isolate the root reason for your unexpected behavior with 2.5.x, giving then the possibility to address the fix of the supposed bug. HTH, Matteo
Comment 5: Matteo, I am unable to launch the AICC URL directly in the browser. This is strange as I was able to before the 2.5 upgrade. Another odd thing, as I mentioned in my original post I am able to launch the AICC URL activities that already exist on the Moodle. I've verified this isn't just some cached version (if that is possible) by modifying the content in the LCMS and refreshing the activity window in Moodle. All of the changes made were visible in Moodle. I decided to install both 2.3 and 2.5.2 fresh, side by side, same Apache2 instance. Both configured the same way. I then modified the LCMS publish xml to point at both instances and created 2 new AICC URLs. The 2.3 version works perfectly in Moodle, but wont launch in the browser. The 2.5 version doesn't launch in either. Could this be an issue with the log in credentials for the LCMS not being handled correctly by Moodle 2.5.2? The LCMS we're using is built on Java, so it could be the log in handler rejecting the LMS's attempt to log in. (Pure speculation, I don't know enough about AICC URL handling to know this for sure.) Thank you!
Comment 6: Hi Eric, what I do not understand from the debug message is if the message comes from having disabled HTTP HEAD at the LCMS side: what I'd expect is " HTTP/1.1 405 Method Not Allowed " and not " HTTP/1.1 403 Forbidden ". That debug message has been introduced with MDL-36641 : I suspect that the check gives a false positive because of HTTP HEAD is not correctly handled by the PENS URL. You could check it by temporarly disabling the "offending" check by adding one line of code as below (the green one) in mod/scorm/locallib.php : function scorm_check_url ($url) { return true; $curl = new curl; HTH, Matteo P.S.: found something but unrelated here, http://stackoverflow.com/questions/17591728/kenexa-lcms-8-2-content-to-moodle-lms-via-aicc-url .
Comment 7: Matteo, That seems to have allowed me to add new AICC URLS to my activities. Should I worry that the HTTP HEAD isn't being handled correctly? Will this introduce any security vulnerabilities? Also, that link is one I submitted about an issue I had before. Thank you for the time you've spent helping me with this!
Comment 8: Hi Eric, no security issues at all: adding that line means that you're skipping the pre-check Moodle does to identify if that URL really exists, to avoid typos and unpredictable errors during the subsequent import which requires you to delete the activity and restart the import as well. HTTP HEAD is the appropriate way to do such a check because the server will return you all the HTTP Headers for that resource: there, you can find the answers (file exists, size, ...) without spending time to download the resource and trash it immediately, as it would occurs using HTTP GET when HTTP HEAD is not supported. That being said: you need to remember that if you'll update Moodle to a next version you'll be in the need of re-adding that line but... see below; I strongly suggest you to write to your Kenexa® LCMS vendor - refering this thread, too - asking for: [Bug] Change the HTTP Status and Reason Phrase returned when using HTTP HEAD against the PENS URL since the appropriate reply must be: HTTP 405 Method Not Allowed . Thanks to this issue we, you and me, were not able to quickly identify what was going on: indeed, HTTP 403 Forbidden means that, given your credentials, you're not authorize to access that resource, which is quite different from the situation described here; [Improvement - I think it's a bug] Provide support for HTTP HEAD calls too since it's a common practice before starting an import like that supported by PENS, to perform some checks including an HTTP HEAD hit to identify if the file really exists and what is the size of that file - on average it will potentially be a long transaction. HTH, Matteo

Forum Post: 
Post title: Exit Title/Close Window button in Lectora.. does nothing in Moodle?
Post description: Hi all, we build our SCORM packages for Moodle using Lectora, and have always added, but hidden the Exit Title/Close Window button that is typically required. If we didn't have it in, we would get the message "You must have an "Exit Title" Action somewhere in an assignable unit for AICC compliance." We had hidden it as it did not actually close the package though. We also set our SCORM packages to open in the same window. For now learners have to use the "Exit Activity" button to exit the SCORM package, but I am curious, why does the "Exit Title" button not do anything? I can include the button in the Lectora titile, and when I click it, the API calls to LMSFinish do work but the window is not closed. SCORM Debugging shows: Mon, 26 Oct 2015 19:53:47 GMT: LMSSetValue("cmi.core.session_time", "00:00:10") => 0 scoid = 10933 Mon, 26 Oct 2015 19:53:47 GMT: Commit("", "") => 0 scoid = 10933 Mon, 26 Oct 2015 19:53:47 GMT: LMSCommit("AJAXResult", "true") => 0 scoid = 10933 Mon, 26 Oct 2015 19:53:47 GMT: LMSCommit("result", "true") => 0 scoid = 10933 Mon, 26 Oct 2015 19:53:47 GMT: LMSCommit("errorCode", "0") => 0 scoid = 10933 Mon, 26 Oct 2015 19:53:47 GMT: LMSFinish("AJAXResult", "true") => 0 scoid = 10933 Mon, 26 Oct 2015 19:53:47 GMT: LMSFinish("result", "true") => 0 scoid = 10933 Mon, 26 Oct 2015 19:53:47 GMT: LMSFinish("", "") => 0 scoid = 10933 If I upload the same SCORM zip file to the Scorm Cloud, clicking the button closes the window properly. Even when I set the SCORM package to open in a new window in Moodle, the close title button does not close the SCORM package window. Was this a delibrate design decision? We would love to have a way for the learner to click the close button in the module itself and "Exit Title/Close Windows" seems to be the thing that was designed for it. It does also seem possible, as I have seen another Moodle instance that uses Storyline SCORM packages, hides the exit activity button and when the person clicks the "Finish" button in the SCORM package itself, it takes them back to the course page.
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Looking a bit more in depth at this, it does seem to be related to the "Auto-Continue" functionality, since in theory the exit title shoudl close the current Assignable Unit, and move on to the next. However we only have one Assignable Unit in our SCORM package. Is it possible to tweak some code to make the SCORM module exit itself when there isn't another assignable unit? It seems I want to do what Joe Wieloch had done here: https://moodle.org/mod/forum/discuss.php?d=86671#p385860 , ie: " if auto-continue is set to true, and LMSFinish() is being called on the last AU, then LMSFinish() would navigate back to the course (like exit activity)," Unfortunately his code tweak was for Moodle 1.9, so I am having a hard time finding the equivalent functions in Moodle 2.8.
Comment 2: Hi all, following up on this. I wonder if anyone else has had success with allowing a SCORM package to close itself and send the signal to Moodle to exit acitivty?
Comment 3: We had a similar problem with Captivate and it is to do with what you are trying to close and the level that the window is in the current browser hierarchy. Varies depending on if you are using new window embedded etc.. but in our case we had to change the function of our close button to call window.parent.close() to get it to actually close the window. Now I don't know if it is the same for Lectora but for Captivate you don't need to call LMSFinish specifically any more it is called as part of a close. I think we have certainly never had any problems in just closing the window and letting it do its stuff.
Comment 4: Thanks Sam, will see if I can try that, though in the working example I've seen, the SCORM package wasn't opened in a new window, it was opened in an existing window. Will experiment a bit once I have the time these holidays.
Comment 5: It will still be a similar thing but I'm not as sure how to do it in the embedded one. Basically it is to do with how moodle places the content in the window and what the authoring tools think they need to call to close that window (frame I think in the embedded case but I might be wrong). They don't seem to quite match up.
Comment 6: Hi, I'm using scorm packages in moodle 2.8 that I created with Lectora v11.2. My (visible) Exit Button just executes Lectoras standard "Exit Title / Close Window" action with no problems. The window is closed (always) and all data is transferred (most of the time). Same if I just close the browser window myself. In Lectora "Publish to scorm" -> "Scorm options" -> "Launch course in separate window from the LMS" is checked. When I open it in the current window in moodle with these settings, the exit button won't do anything. When I uncheck "Launch course..." in Lectora the Exit Button won't work neither in the same nor in a new window. Closing the browser window via the "x" closes the window (of course) but moodle will not redirect me back to the course page. Tim
Comment 7: Thanks Tim, will try this out.. I've been wrestling with whether to open current window or new window for a long while.. popups on the one hand vs people closing the entire window on the other and 'losing the course' because they closed their browser.
Comment 8: Personally I favour new window for a couple of reasons. Gives more area for content, if they just close the content window that should still save progress and easier to close if you just call window.parent.close() rather than the problem you can have with it being embedded and then you have to make sure you close the right level to go back. There are a few settings you can set so it appears on top in nearly full screen so I think that helps users as well sometimes. It is just there they do it and then they close it to go back to the course. Rather than it being part of the page they were already doing. Partly my personal preference as well.
Comment 9: Do you find you get a lot of tickets about popup blocking? Most of our learners take only 1 or 2 courses, so we have a constant influx of people that are new to the system.
Comment 10: Just don't let them skip the content structure page. If they click "Start" to open the course in a new window most popup blockers won't react. Tim
Comment 11: one day I'd like to implement that new window option as a modal window (blocking access to the parent/browser windows underneath) But Tim is correct - the content structure page initiates the pop-up on user action so pop-up blockers don't usually cause issues, where-as if the skip content structure page is used the pop-up is launched after the page has been redirected which is how those nasty traditional pop-up window ads used to load and why pop-up blockers were invented! There might be a way we could hijack the link on the course homepage to directly launch the scorm pop-up rather than the mod/scorm/view.php page but that would need some development effort.
Comment 12: Huh, that's good to know. Thanks Tim and Dan!

Forum Post: 
Post title: LMSSetValue Error and Lectora
Post description: Hi everyone, Quite stuck with an issue I'm having with Lectora 12 and Moodle 2.2. I have built a course (small - 4 MCQs and 4 short answers). The course has 2 chapters - a PC chapter, and a mobile chapter (which is a duplicate of the PC chapter, but mobile-sized). Both chapters share the same variables and retaining answers is on in the aim that users can switch between the mobile and PC versions and it will track where they are up to. On a PC, variables are retained, it can remember where the user is up to, no errors. If part way through the course I switch to my iphone and try to pick up where I left off, it can see where I got up to, and works. BUT, if I go out of the mobile version from there, and back in again, it has lost all the completed questions and it throws the following error: LMSSetValue Error: Some of the persistent data was not able to be stored. To make it even weirder, if I go back to the PC version, it's remembered where I got up to (but on the PC version, not the mobile version) and doesn't throw any errors. I have tried this fix that I saw floating around: CMIString4096 = '^[\\u0000-\\uffff]{0,40960}$'; which helped (as at first it was throwing the persistent data error on mobile ALL the time, not just the second time), but hasn't entirely fixed the problem. I've tried both SCORM 1.2 and 2004 and it doesn't seem to make a difference. Any ideas?
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Hi Sarah, I've no enough experience with different mobile devices but it sounds like an issue between your device and the SCORM API engine implementation in Moodle. If the two content versions shares the same kind of data - here I guess interactions - I cannot understand the reason why you need to expand the size of CMIString4096 unless linked to an issue to support some regexps at your mobile device side. Have you tried with a different mobile device or using a newer Moodle version e.g. http://demo.moodle.net/ (for a better mobile friendly ecosystem)? HTH , Matteo

Forum Post: 
Post title: Moodle quiz to scorm
Post description: Using Moodle 1.8 We have a few thousand questions in question banks We have now got 2 more LMS in our company and we decided that all questions should now be made into scorm quizzes which can run in all 3 LMS Problem: about 40,000 questions are locked in our moodle. How to export them so as to create scorm packages. Constraint: We'd prefer a free tool or at least a low cost one since this will be a one time activity for us. Thanks S
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Hello Dr. S, Usually the point of using the Moodle question bank is that questions can be shared and mixed and matched across quizzes, or drawn in at random into a quiz from a large collection. Be aware that if you repackage the questions into SCORM you'll lose all of that. A SCORM content package is equivalent to a single quiz for a single assessment purpose, not a single quiz question, and not a general, all-purpose package that can be tailored to the context at hand by a layperson. It is possible to export quiz questions into various formats, and if I were you I'd probably go with the Moodle xml export format, then build a custom SCORM player to present the questions in that xml to the learner. *But* once again you'll run into how to tailor that question set to the learner. You're going to have to manipulate that XML file for each separate quiz you want to deliver with those questions. Are you sure it's not possible to import the question bank as such into the other LMSs? Even if it requires some custom coding, it will probably give you more flexibility in using the questions in different contexts, down the road. Might be worth investigating. Also, you might want to look at upgrading. We're now at Moodle 2.0.3+ and Moodle 1.9.12+. Regards, Amy

Post title: No course completions for users outside of the US
Post description: Hi, I'm running into a very weird situation.  My company is currently using Moodle version 3.7.1 as their LMS.  We have users all over the world that use the system.  I've assigned them 11 courses created in Storyline 3 and 2 using Lectora.  Users are seeing the same results using either Chrome or Internet Explorer. Users that are based in the US are able to get a completion with no problem.  Users that are outside of the US will only get a completion with 1 of the 13 courses. All courses will show when the user opens the course and then closes the course.  A raw score is not getting submitted for the users outside of the US.  I've attached two API logs.  One will show a completed course for a user in the US and the other no completion for someone outside of the US. Please any suggestions would be greatly appreciated.
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: just linking to your post in the articulate forums here as well: https://community.articulate.com/discussions/articulate-storyline/users-outside-of-the-us-unable-to-get-course-completions As mentioned there - you are using an old version of Moodle that does not have all the known SCORM issues applied - particularly some around Chrome 80 which could describe the issues you are experiencing - we also have this bug open which describes some other issues still remaining with chrome 80 support: https://tracker.moodle.org/browse/MDL-68896
Comment 2: Thanks Dan for your information in both places. I'll pass this along to the proper people and hopefully a decision will be made for updating the Moodle platform.

Post title: Scorm in Greek -
Post description: We are loading some Greek language scorms into Moodle 1.5.4. The actual pages are fine, but the course contents come out in characters that are not Greek.  They were encoded as UTF8.  When we change the encoding in the browser to UTF8, the course contents look correct, but then all the Greek controls are not displayed properly, because they have been encoded with Greek Windows.  If we try to upload a scorm with Greek windows encoding, we get an error. The only way to get round this is to change the "thischarset" in the moodle.php file to UTF-8, and then replace every Greek term in the file with the UTF8 version.  As the only way we've found to do this is by copy and paste from Word into Notepad, this will take rather a long time. Has anyone else done this already, or is there another solution? Thanks Geoff Dische

Post title: Do users have to have Flaher player to see scorm content?
Post description: I have a basic question. We have Moodle 2.1 and I have created a scorm content using Captivet 5.5 In order to see this content, do our users have to have appropriate flash player on their machine? If so, is there any way we can avoid it by installing the right flash player in our server etc??? If someone asks this question already, can someone guide me to the answer? Sami
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: most captivate packages generate Flash content - so to view this your users web browsers must have flash installed in their browsers - you can't do this for them on your server. Newer versions of Captivate allow you to export HTML5 packages instead of using flash - but only modern browsers support HTML5 and they are also likely to be the ones that have flash installed anyway.
Comment 2: Thank you so much for the clarification, Dan. I really appreciate your clear answer. Sami

Post title: SCORM multiple user overload
Post description: Hello, I am eLearning developer for a land-based college. We use moodle version 3.3.2+ (Build: 20170928) I have developed some eLearning resources for the college's induction period. They are SCORM packages developed in Articulate Storyline. They are not large modules - the largest is 45mb and they have been fully tested on desktops, tablets, phones etc. and function correctly as an individual user in moodle. We have started to experience serious issues when the student uptake has increased on these courses. This can happen with approx. 50 users. What usually happens is the courses start as they should and then 15-20 mins into the session they start to freeze. This is usually represented by the spinning flash loader. Some users get the '500 - internal server error'. Usually if they close the scorm package and re-open they can continue from where they left off. Does anyone have experience of this or possible fixes - please note my knowledge of servers is limited so please keep in layman's terms. Many thanks, Pete
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: it sounds like you are reaching the limit of your server capacity - SCORM is inherently fragile and can be a bit hard on your web server, sending multiple requests back with data etc. You should take a look at performance tuning your server or allocating it more resources. First - make sure you are running PHP 7 - then you might want to have your sysadmin team look through: https://docs.moodle.org/en/Performance_recommendations The hardware and performance forum here is also very good. Alternatively you could look at engaging a Moodle Partner to help you with performance tuning or might want to consider hosting your Moodle site with a Moodle partner familiar with SCORM and high use sites. (disclosure - I work for a Moodle Partner)

Post title: SCORM Activity grade
Post description: Good day, i uploaded a course with 4 SCO's. Each SCO contains 1 page with a flash object that is marked as a final page. The course is uploaded as a scorm activity. In the module menu, it shows the 4 SCO with a check mark if completed and an orange circle if incomplete. To the right side of the sco title, says "Grade:0". Is there any way to set this grade to 100 even if there is no test/ assessment? The certificate opens fine after the 4 sco's are complete. Just need to change that grade:0. I've been looking at the file "scofunctions.js". This contains all the scorm related codes. I've noticed a cmi.core.score.max = 100 and tried inserting in the completed function and no luck updating the grade on moodle. I've tested a sample course with a start test button. 1 question then a pass/fail certificate. This course sets moodle to complete (with green check mark) and a "grade:100". What piece of code or setting on moodle do i need to do to make the first course complete with grade:100 without using an assessment? I am using Outstart Trainer 11 and using moodle 1.9.7 . Any help would be greatly appreciated.
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: I was able to solve this problem.... i edited "cmi.core.score.raw" and set it to 100.

Post title: Lectora Scorm module and display size
Post description: We are in the process of evaluating Moodle and preexisting SCORM (Lectora) modules.  Moodle 1.9.4 The problem we are having is with the size of the display.  We get slide bars for sideways and up and down.  I need to identify where the problem lies: 1) Is it the Moodle settings. 2) Is it in the SCORM module.  Here is the info I was able to discover: The course specs you actually need to be asking about is relative to Lectora, rather than Captivate, since what you are seeing is Captivate content (927 x 672) "wrapped," or embedded, in a Lectora container. Lectora is the framework, and provides the SCORM capability that is communicating with the LMS - and the project is published at 1010 x 715. We use Lectora 8, Or is it a combination of both. The website is http://www.eastbattle.com/moodle user: admin  pwd:  wbt The course is EDMD... Thanks in advance.
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Sounds like your problem is the screen size of your package. We have the same issue--because many of our users have smaller screens than the developers, the developer sees the package present with no problem but users have to scroll around to see all of it and complain piteously. We've solved this two ways--none of the Lectora/Captivate modules are bigger than about 730 x 550 and they are set to open in a new window. Then your moodle settings should be slightly larger and also set to open in a new window. I was suspicious of the whole open in a new window thing at first but it works very nicely and actually improves the user's capabilities. But pop-up blockers MUST be turned off...Hope this helps!

Forum Post: 
Post title: Using PHP in SCORM Module
Post description: I have been able to create a small SCORM package using HTML, javascripts and images and have been able to get them to run in Moodle. However, if I introduce a PHP section to pass data, Moodle displays it as text and not a webpage. Is it posssible to run PHP scripts in a SCORM package? Chris Eccles
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Hi Chris, if you want to use PHP in a SCORM package you need use external php server . In package manifest you must define the the 'href' attribute of tag 'resource' as an external link (ex. http://www.pinco.org/scorm/bobo.php ); Then you can "pack" the package also only the imsmanifest. xml file and upload it in Moodle. In this way you can execute php script outside the Moodle context . Bobo
Comment 2: Hi, i don't suppose you could spell out your solution for a newbie? Thanks
Comment 3: Hi , i want to use php in a scorm , can u help me the external link (ex. http://www.pinco.org/scorm/bobo.php ); not work Haidy
Comment 4: Are there still big limitations of using PHP in SCORM? I need to implement some code that will interact with MySQL . Can I implement this via SCORM or I should develop (or extend) the module?
Comment 5: Technically, I wouldn't include server side scripts in  a SCORM package.  To be compliant the SCO has to be able to run in any ADL specificed SCORM player. HTML, FLASH, Javascript , and Java applets are fine but what if the SCORM player is built in JSP or Cold Fusion? Your SCO would break and it would cease to be SCORM compliant.
Comment 6: Best regards! I have the same problem and I could not solve it. Can somebody help me? moodle php script code and displays them as not running. any idea how to solve this problem? Thank you

Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Hello, Nuttanicha, SCORM is an acronym for Shrable Content Object Reference Model, a suit of standards, managed by ADL SCORM , and is an amalgmation of many standrads in the learning space. What is importane is that when we author our learning contents following some international standards, these are interoperable and reusable in many situations with standards compliant Learning Management Systems (LMS) such as Moodle. The easiest way to get started is to obtain a free download of eXe 0.4 . Installation is very easy and the WYSIWYG interface lets you work in your browser and save your work as SCORM. That's it. Your SCORM module is ready to be uploaded to Moodle. Now in Moodle, you just have to upload the .zip file. All the best with your project! Brijesh

Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Which is odd because NO version of Moodle supports SCORM 2004....
Comment 2: as Howard mentions Moodle doesn't support SCORM 2004 at the moment - if you can use SCORM 1.2 you should. The error you are getting is logged as MDL-24475 - it's related to the feature in SCORM 2004 called "sequencing and navigation" - this is the biggest component of SCORM 2004 that Moodle doesn't support. We have a couple of GSOC students working on SCORM over the next few months - if you have a SCORM object that reproduces this error that you're able to share, please attach it to the bug listed above.

Post title: Edit SCORM package new ID?
Post description: Is there ever an instance where editing a scorm package would cause Moodle to assign a new scormid to the package? I have inherited a Moodle instance where there are scorm packages with different ID's but same name. This is a problem with reporting. The moodle version is 2.2. Thanks, Mike
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Hi Michael, can you elaborate your question? You can publish the same Learning Package several times even into the same Course and for Moodle they will always be different things with the advantage, in 2.x, to be stored once to preserve disk space: tracking data will be coupled with the Activity instance regardless the Learning Package being the same. A way to preserve tracking data in a unique place is to use a Resource URL to point to the SCORM Course whenever you need to give access to that SCORM Package. HTH , Matteo
Comment 2: Thank you for the reply. What I'm trying to determine is if there is any reason that Moodle would automatically change a scormid when a user is editing a scorm package. Thanks, Mike
Comment 3: Hi Michael, never heard of it: what is your exact Moodle version (you can read it at the bottom of the Site administration ► Notifications page)? Have you already try to create a new course and replicate the supposed behaviour by adding and then updating a SCORM Package? Matteo

Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Tyler I have use the following workflow: • Create the repository as you; • Place the scorm package not zipped inside that folder; • Load the manifest as an alias from there; Every time I need to update the content I just change drag and drop the files thru ftp and that´s it, my content is always updated without any headache. I´ve start doing that because importing the package as a ZIP or create an alias of the ZIP package it was too taking a long long time. Make me as useful, glad I could help you.

Comment 3: Tyler you are asking me?
Comment 4: I have heard that there are some performance issues when updating scorm packages - I have a feeling it might occur when there is a large amount of tracking data for previous submissions - I haven't had a chance to track the issue down and we don't have a tracker issue open for it at the moment. If you could create a tracker issue and some test data that results in a long update that would be helpful. thanks,
Comment 5: Dan, Not sure if this might be related, but we found that with new SCORM course creations that it does take more time than expected, up to 2 minutes for a new course.  For us, it caused a timeout on a server that was configured with php_fpm, resulting in a white screen or a server too busy message.  However, the process was still running in the background and would complete. After uninstalling php_fpm on the server the timeout went away and SCORM courses would complete the install without a white screen or error message.  In place of php_fpm we have installed APC and have not seen the same problem, so attributed it to a compatibility problem between Moodle and php_fpm.  Thought I would share in case it helps.

Post title: Moodle 2.1: What does "Warning: PHP Zlib compression has been enabled on this site, some users may experience issues loading SCORM objects in certain web browsers" mean?
Post description: Getting the above message uploading SCORM zips on 2.1. I'm not sure it's terribly informative. What does it actually mean and why might I be getting it. Other Moodle instances on the same box do not appear to be getting the message (although we haven't fully investigated yet).
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Hi Howard, We have a bit of documentation on that issue here: http://docs.moodle.org/20/en/SCORM_FAQ#Zlib_warning_when_I_add.2Fupdate_SCORM_objects_in_my_course There are some sites I know of that have hacks to disable zlib compression *only* for SCORM, and this gets around the problem (though the warning is still shown when you're adding the activity). Regards, Amy
Comment 2: Odd... I'm sure we've got zlib compression on everywhere but I've never seen this message before. So... is it suggesting that I turn off the compression setting? It doesn't say what the 'issues' might be (nor does the FAQ).
Comment 3: Hi Howard, This issue is/was the most common: http://tracker.moodle.org/browse/MDL-20588
Comment 4: OK thanks.... I've seen problems with IE6 and almost everything. If this perhaps is just an IE6 error is there any grounds for reviewing this message in 2.0/2.1? It's an instant support request when it appears - especially as the compression setting seems harmless in newer browsers (unless you know different - of course).
Comment 5: I've only seen this issue with IE 6 but from memory it was a real pain to track down. I think there's probably grounds to remove the message esp as we don't officially support IE 6 in 2.0 anymore and the code to disable for IE 6 is still there - I haven't seen anyone else complaining about it since. - create a bug and I'll push through a fix in the next couple of weeks to dump the message.
Comment 6: Cheers.... MDL-28535

Post title: Regular Expressions
Post description: I'm using moodle 1.6 and SCORM 1.2. When finishing a course I got a message "Invalid data format". I checked my SCORM course with ADL Test Suite without getting errors or warnings. Next, I debuged where the error comes from, it is cmi.interactions.n.id with the following data type: CMIIdentifier The format CMIIdentifier specifies a alpha-numeric string without internal spaces. Some of my id's have an hypher in it, that is not allowed in moodle. In another documentations it is declared as alpha-numeric string inclusive . and hypher without spaces. I think, that the regular expression for CMIIdentifier should be the following: CMIIdentifier = '^\\w[\\w|\\-]{1,255}$'; Could there anyone confirm that I am right?
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: The ultimate reference are the SCORM 1.2 Runtime Environment book and the SCORM Conformance Requirements document. Anything else is guesswork.
Comment 2: I'm absolutely with you. The SCORM Conformance Requirements document says the following: CMIIdentifier: • Value shall contain an alphanumeric group of characters • Value shall contain no white space • Value shall contain no unprintable characters
Comment 3: In this way we must add many others characters like tilde,point,coma,quote, double quote and so on. I think that we can add just hyphen and tilde that is also used by some editors (as you can see in this post http://moodle.org/mod/forum/discuss.php?d=52996 ) I fix it in moodle 1.6.1 latest stable. Cheers, Bobo.

Post title: A simple multiple HTML pages SCO in moodle
Post description: Hi Folks I am following the Click2Learn SCORM document which seems pretty comprehensive. In the 6 th Chapter there is an example of building a Multiple-Page SCO which I have cut and pate and checked line by line & which appears to me to be an extremely simple and robust example of attempting this kind of process. The Scormed course is attached as bib.zip. The document can be viewed ar www.icywater.com/learningpool/scotm2.pdf I scormed the course using Myles 1.2 scorm software which I am certain means that it is 100% 1.2 SCORMed. The document introduces this example with some instructive comments: "Nothing in the SCORM specification prohibits you from using more than one HTML file in a SCO, and from navigating from page to page within the SCO. Indeed, in many cases a single page just cannot adequately deliver the desired learning experience. "However, there is a basic problem with using multiple HTML pages to make up a SCO. As you go from page to page, no state information is retained. For example, if page1.html called LMSInitialize, when you went to page2.html nothing persisted to remember that LMSInitialize has already been called. Since the SCO must remember at least the state of the communication session with the API, a method must be devised to remember this information. If such a method exists, it also enables the SCO to keep track of other important information, like the status of learning objectives, or what the sequence of pages should be. "We will not consider here the case where you would change assets displayed within a standing HMTL page. There is no problem there since the page itself remains loaded." I have loaded this example to Moodle v1.8 and through the alerts in the code it appears that at the very first attempt for the code to reference the API from within the SCO the system returns that the API is null … and as far as I can see there is absolutely no communication between the course & the LMS because of this failure at the very first attempt to communicate with the LMS. However, I also notice that if I press F5 on the moodle page the course was launched from I can see that moodle thinks that the course has been partially-viewed. For this to be recorded does this mean that the Initialization of this SCO could have been done within moodle so that when the courses main html page tried to find the API it fails because the SCO was initilaised already through moodle? This does not appear to be happening in moodle version 1.5 ... Does any of this sound likely?  At this stade I'm beginning to doubt my own eyes ... Cheers Alan

Post title: Unable to run our content
Post description: I am a developer for a software company that creates E-Learning products. One of those products is an authoring tool. The content created with the authoring tool is played through a .NET Rich Client Object. Basically, this is a dll that is referenced on a web page via an <OBJECT> tag. Much like activeX but not at all the same (the object syntax is very different). .NET Rich Client Objects will only ever run on a web page using an HTTP path, they will simply not load if the path is a UNC (this is done for security reasons). And here lies my problem. I am able to upload and import our SCORM packages without any problems in Moodle however, when I attempt to launch the content it all goes wrong because IE will not load the player object. If I move the content into the htdocs area of the Apache server and launch the content via a direct URL it runs fine. From what I can gather, the problem lies with the whole ‘file.php – send_file – readfile_chunked’ mechanism being used by Moodle. I get the impression that the data written back to the browser as a result of the readfile_chunked routine is interpreted by IE as being a file path rather than a valid HTTP path and so therefore refuses to render my player. My question is this: is there a way of A. Forcing Moodle to place my content into a folder that can have an http path to it and B. Force Moodle to launch my content based on the path sent in the imsmanifest file rather than via the file.php method? Any help you can provide would be greatly appreciated.

Forum Post: 
Post title: SCORM in Moodle / Object Reuse in Moodle
Post description: Hi, I'm new to Moodle and SCORM , just want to know how useful SCORM in Moodle is, example, how Moodle can practicially use SCORM? An example is how to reuse the learning object in a SCORM and put it in another course? Can I do it in current Moodle? Another example, in my course material, I input "past tense, English, level 1" in my SCORM material, can the tutor search by using keyword, like "past tense, English, level 1" and find all SCORM material that is tagged as these keyword? If so, it would be useful as he can find the related information and suggest to students who need to study this area, what's your guy opinion towards this? Thanks
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: I also expect it can work in these level but seems not
Comment 2: object re-use is not something that's well supported in Moodle 1.9 SCORM objects are also hard to "re-use" - you can point to an externally hosted zip or manifest file, however if the manifest/unzipped package is hosted on a different site the SCORM Javascript API will fail. Moodle 2.0 has a new repository api that would allow you to have an external "repository" of Scorm objects (only zip files if on a different domain ) and you could re-use this object in many different courses as necessary. Unfortunately Tags are not supported on modules in 1.9 either - the global search might work on description/title of the scorm, but I don't think it searches the content inside a SCORM object.\ hope that helps.

I did not change any settings on the activity. When I saved the activity, I got an error that said "Error writing to database " with the following debug information: Debug info: Column 'identifier' cannot be null INSERT INTO mdl_scorm_scoes (identifier,scorm,organization,title,parent,launch,scormtype,sortorder) VALUES(?,?,?,?,?,?,?,?) [array ( 0 => NULL, 1 => '6', 2 => '', 3 => NULL, 4 => '/', 5 => '', 6 => '', 7 => 1, )] Error code: dmlwriteexception Stack trace: line 489 of /lib/dml/moodle_database.php: dml_write_exception thrown line 1331 of /lib/dml/my sql i_native_moodle_database.php: call to moodle_database->query_end() line 1377 of /lib/dml/mysqli_native_moodle_database.php: call to mysqli_native_moodle_database->insert_record_raw() line 293 of /mod/scorm/datamodels/aicclib.php: call to mysqli_native_moodle_database->insert_record() line 306 of /mod/scorm/locallib.php: call to scorm_parse_aicc() line 168 of /mod/scorm/lib.php: call to scorm_parse() line 122 of /course/modlib.php: call to scorm_add_instance() line 154 of /course/modedit.php: call to add_moduleinfo() I am running Moodle 3.7.4. My AICC package is attached.
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Have you looked at what is in the package? Not all AICC and SCORM packages are built the same way. There could be things missing. generally, I think it looks for a manifest if the manifest is inside a folder and not at the top level, it could prevent proper loading (I've actually seen this happen).
Comment 2: The package includes course.au, course.crs, course.cst, and couse.des; they are all in the top-level and there are no other folders within it. I did some research this morning and found that AICC packages only have 4 mandatory files, which are all included in my package. There are also 3 optional files, which my package does not include. None of the requirements list needing a manifest file. https://docs.moodle.org/25/en/SCORM_FAQ#AICC_Package_Contents
Comment 3: I finally figured it out with help from this post: https://moodle.org/mod/forum/discuss.php?d=416647 I had to Enable Direct AICC URL and Enable External AICC HACP in the SCORM plugin settings. Then on course's SCORM activity settings, I changed the package to be type of "External AICC URL", then used the URL that was in course.au file in the URL field. There is no need to upload the package that just has the 4 files.

Post title: Total score problem
Post description: Hi When we permit multiple attempts what happens when a user log's in is that the raw score gets cleared but the other interaction scores remain unaltered. Is there someway we can report to the grade section the total score from the previous attempt? The raw score seems to become zero but the previous attempt interaction id's and the weighting remains unaltered. Any ideas please this can decide the future of the moodle implementation for us... Regards Uday
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Hi Uday If you want to get raw score from multiple attempts you should change function scorm_grade_user() in the locallib.php in scorm module. Because $attempt = scorm_get_last_attempt($current->scorm, $userid); will only get the score from last attempt. So you should insert a for loop from 1-->$attempt to get all raw score. Best regards. Pham Minh Duc
Comment 2: Hi Pham Minh Duc Thanks so much for taking the time to point out the location where i can get the raw score for multiple attempts but what i find is that though the user has taken multiple attempts his raw score is only a single field and what is happening is that it is becoming zero. Is there any other work around from where i can get the score from scorm or should i write manual loop such that I can take a look at the student response and expected response and then compute the score? Best Regards uday

Forum Post: 
Post title: Scorm imsmanifest.xml access under Moodle 2.0
Post description: Has something changed with how Scorms are accessed under 2.0 compared to 1.9? We have hundreds of instances of a scorm package being accessed across a site, so we placed the expanded packages in the moodledata/1 folder and accessed the imsmanifest. xml file for each occurrence of the scorm package within each course. I just ported one of our site to a Moodle 2.0 build and the packages would not play. When I looked at the edit mode for the scotrm activities , there appears to be no way to manually enter or edit the url in the scorm activity edit mode. Does direct access to the imsmanifest file no longer work? How do you point to a common imsmanifest.xml file for multiple occurrences of the same Scorm package? If the above is not possible, this is a serious limitation of Moodle 2.0 with respect to hard drive space consumed, updating of scorm packages, and activity rewrites to accommodate this limitation.
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: I would try using the local file repository method rather than pointing them to the front page files area. I think you may find that the SCROM module is always going to try and copy its files into the activity now though, due to the new files interface... But I stand to be corrected on that point by someone with more knowledge of such things! Jon
Comment 2: Thanks for the info, Jon .... I'm hoping that Dan or other Scorm architects can clarify this. This is my first real look at Moodle 2.0 and this issue has me concerned. I see big issues if these expanded zip files (as per my initial post) start replicating themselves all over the server setup. Even re-pointing them to a repository might be a bit of work, unless I can do a global search and replace (keeping the current structure in place). larry
Comment 3: Hi Larry, don't panic! the ability is still there, but disabled by default. It's disabled by default as the new file API in Moodle stores files according to the SHA1 hash of their content. This means each file with particular contents is stored once, irrespective of how many times it is included in different places, even if it is referred to by different names. So - if the reason you are keeping them in a "central" location is to decrease disk space then you don't need to do this anymore. But - there are several other reasons why you might want to do this so we've allowed people to enable the feature. Go to admin > plugins > Activity Modules > Scorm package and find the settings: * Enable external package * Enable downloaded package * Enable IMS package type once these are enabled you can select the type of file to use in a new SCORM here's an explanation of the different types * Uploaded package - Enables a SCORM package to be chosen via the file picker * External SCORM manifest - Enables an imsmanifest.xml URL to be specified. Note: If the URL has a different domain name than your site, then "Downloaded package" is a better option, since otherwise grades are not saved. * Downloaded package - Enables a package URL to be specified. The package will be unzipped and saved locally, and updated when the external SCORM package is updated. * Local IMS content repository - Enables a package to be selected from within an IMS repository';

Post title: Student can't resume where they left off - Mac and Firefox user
Post description: Hello, I have a client that is using a Mac with Firefox . He is having a problem in that he can't resume the modules he is leaving in our Moodle 2.0.4 setup. The SCORM 1.2 packages are created using Articulate. Has anybody else run into a similar issue? I need a little direction... Many thanks, Dave
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Hey Dave, I'm assuming other users with other browsers don't experience any problems? does the client experience the same problems in other browsers? Would it be possible to have him take the Scorm, with debuggin on? In Moodle 2.0.3. I believe it's possible to turn on debugging for one user only, using the username in the API debug capture mask. See the settings at the bottom of Site administration / Plugins / Activity modules / SCORM package (allowapidebug and apidebugmask).
Comment 2: Hello Sytske, Nobody else seems to have the problem at the moment.  I have tested it with my PC and FF and it seems ok.  Our Moodle host has tried with his Mac and FF and it worked ok as well. I am a total rookie at the debug thing...I will have to take a look.  SCARY! Thanks, Dave
Comment 3: Dave, Make sure your user is starting a new attempt. If your user has already completed an attempt, and rather than starting a new attempt he keeps opening the same old attempt, then some authorware packages will see that he has lesson_status of passed, failed, or completed, and will not do the bookmarking. Regards, A
Comment 4: Hello Amy, If I blow out their attempt, they are right back where they started by having to start at the beginning...or is it that I don't quite understand your take? Thanks for the help! Dave
Comment 5: You're not understanding me. I'm not telling you to delete attempts, I'm explaining how authorware content sometimes works. I'm telling you that depending on what authorware you have used, your learner may have already completed the attempt, and therefore the content does not do the bookmarking, since the learner has already completed the attempt. Moodle has options for number of attempts allowed. M2 can also force a new attempt. Look at the learner's data and see if he has more than 1 attempt in the reports. See what the lesson_status is for those attempts. Rule out the possibility that he's just opening the same completed attempt over and over.
Comment 6: Hello Amy, Thanks for getting back to me.  I will dig a little bit and see what I find. I appreciate your efforts in helping me sort this out -Dave

Forum Post: 
Post title: Storyline SCORM 1.2 SCOs Exit Course/LMSFinish Issue in Linux Moodle 2.4
Post description: I am having an issue with Storyline SCORM 1.2 SCOs that were working fine in a Moodle 2.2 Windows implementation, but are now hitting a problem in a Moodle 2.4 installation on Linux. In doing some debugging work, I think I've identified where the issue is occurring and how it differs from the Windows installation. The issue occurs only when clicking the "Next" button in our course, where we have attached an "Exit Course" trigger. In the Storyline SCO debug window, a sequence of SCORM functions are called. The sequence looks like this: 1159: - In SCORM_Finish strExitType=SUSPEND, blnStatusWasSet=true 1160: - In SCORM_ClearErrorInfo 1161: - Setting Exit 1162: - In SCORM_TranslatgeExitTypeToSCORM strExitType-SUSPEND 1163: - Returning suspend 1164: - SCORM_CallLMSSetValue strElement=cmi.core.exit, strValue=suspend 1165: - In SCORM_GrabAPI 1166: - SCORM_GrabAPI, returning 1167: - Calling LMSSetValue 1168: - strResult=true 1169: - Returning true 1170: - Calling Commit 1171: - In SCORM_CallLMSCommit Now here is where the problem begins. In Windows Moodle 2.2, after calling LMSFinish, you see the following: strResult=true Returning True Returning True These lines are missing in Linux Moodle 2.2, which stem from the function SCORM_CallLMSFinish() defined in SCORMFunctions.js in the /lms folder in the published package. By looking at the API Debug window in Moodle, I see that LMSFinish is called, and then the API object shuts down. So the line "strResult = SCORM_objAPI.LMSFinish("");" from SCORM_CallLMSFinish() does not execute, since no API object exists. So even though I click "Next", which executes the "Exit Course" trigger, the Storyline content just stays as is. When I click the "Next" button AGAIN, I see the "Goodbye.html" file displayed, more functions execute in the debug window, but there is still no API object. So I can then exit the SCO by clicking on the link provided in the Moodle Interface, which brings me back to the course menu. But when I try to re-enter the SCO, it just hangs (I assume because it did not shut down properly. Everything else seems to be working fine (Quizzes passing values, suspend data, completion of the SCO, etc.), but there is some issue with the "Exit Course/LMSFinish" functions in the SCO.  I tested the SCO on the ADL Test Suite 1.2.7. Any advice on how to proceed would be appreciated. I am wondering if some of the functions within the Exit Course sequence of events in the SCO could be moved up so this shutdown of the API object does not cause a problem.  Not sure if this is a fix that should be implemented on the Moodle/Mod/SCORM side or the Storyline side. I have a sample SCO that illustrates the problem at http://www.isodynamic.com/clients/moodle/Test_SCO_v01.zip .  Pasted below is the SCORM API Activity Log from this sample SCO. Thanks! Forum Post: 
Post title: SCORM Pop-up
Post description: Is there anyway to allow students to open more than one SCORM window at a time? With the default settings, the activity closes as soon as the student navigates back? Or is there something in the SCORM system itself that prevents this? Any help is much appreciated! Thanks
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Hi Leslie, The window from which a SCORM object opens is managing the API for that specific session, which includes all communications from Moodle to the SCO, and the other way around. Learners can have 2 SCOs open at once, but they will have to originate from different browser windows. -A
Comment 2: Is there any possible way to get around this? My biggest concern is not that the student might not be able to open 2 SCO, but that if they navigate away from the page, it clsoes the SCORM box. Also, how would I go about customizing the look of the SCORM page so that it shows the course listing instead of a big empty white box?
Comment 3: Is there any possible way to get around this? My biggest concern is not that the student might not be able to open 2 SCO, but that if they navigate away from the page, it clsoes the SCORM box. Yes, if you do some research into the SCORM player, you will see that this is now SCORM works. If the API is lost, you cannot log data back to the LMS. http://docs.moodle.org/en/Development:SCORM_schema Also, how would I go about customizing the look of the SCORM page so that it shows the course listing instead of a big empty white box? If you read the SCORM documentation, you will see that some changes can be made to the presentation of the screen from which the SCORM content is displayed (or opened in a new window) without customization. Changes beyond that would require a change to the SCORM module, or at the very least a custom theme. http://docs.moodle.org/en/Adding/editing_a_SCORM http://docs.moodle.org/en/SCORM_FAQ -A
Comment 4: I'm currently experimenting with having the activity link open to a new window and have the SCORM within the window then like that. I'll post my progress.

Forum Post: 
Post title: Captivate 4 & Moodle
Post description: Hi all - I am a bit of a newbie in terms of both Moodle & Captivate, I have initially designed a single course in moodle  but did not get the functionality that I was looking for so have developed the same course using captivate 4 - The area that I need to clarify before ploughing on relentlessly is the quiz & survey side and how these will interact. In the course I want to include a survey, if I do this in Captivate will this transfer as written in Captivate and maintain the same functionality in terms of grading etc as if it was written through Moodle. The same question would then apply to the test that i put in Captivate - Would this also operate correctly. I have read through some of the Scorm information but have become slightly confused so any guidance in basic terms would be appreciated Cheers John
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: John, Keep in mind that ultimatly SCORM has been made as a tool for programmers, not educators, and so If you do not have a strong computer programming background you may find it difficult to delve too deeply into it. I have 10+ years software engineering experience and still find it pretty daunting to develope a fully SCORM compliant application. If you are a programmer, the resources at ADL will be helpful to you. If you are not, the help documents that come with Captivate will probably be your best bet. Also, SCORM 2004 is not yet completely implemented in Moodle, so there should be an option in captivate to use SCORM 1.2. If you can get this, you should get the same results in moodle/captivate. -Jeff
Comment 2: Thanks Jeff - I have have viewed some files in Captivate and on there forums which lead me down that similar road you have indicated - I will try a couple of tests and if (Or should that be when!!) iget stuck I will check back in Thanks again John

Forum Post: 
Post title: Regrade a scorm activity attempt
Post description: I have an Articulate scorm package as a scorm activity in a Moodle course that includes some graded questions. The results of those questions are written to the Moodle gradebook when a student goes through the activity. So far so good. Except for one user. For some reason the grade for that user was not written to the gradebook when he completed the activity. If I open the submitted results for that scorm activity on /mod/scorm/report.php?id=111 the user appears on that scorm activity report - but with a grade of 0 . If I drill down into the log for the attempt on /mod/scorm/report.php?b=111&user=12345&attempt=1 I can see all the track details for that scorm activity attempt, example: 
```text
cmi.core.exit suspend 


cmi.interactions_0.correct_responses_0.pattern Jack_and_Jill_went_up_the_hill


cmi.interactions_0.id Scene2_Slide2_MultiChoice_0_0 


cmi.interactions_0.objectives_0.id TCF 


cmi.interactions_0.result wrong 


cmi.interactions_0.student_response To_ensure_that_their_bucket_was_full_and_aligned_to_consumer_trends 


cmi.interactions_0.time 19:11:24 


cmi.interactions_0.type choice 


cmi.interactions_0.weighting 1 


cmi.interactions_1.id Scene2_Slide2_MultiChoice_0_1 


cmi.interactions_1.result correct 


cmi.interactions_1.student_response We_can_build_our_strategy_and_impact_the_culture_of_our_organisation_through_this_programme 


cmi.interactions_1.time 19:11:57
```
 Using that info I can work out that the student did answer all the questions in the attempt and he should have received a valid grade. However the "General data" section in that "Track details" page (/mod/scorm/report.php) shows the 'Raw score', 'Min score' and 'Max score' fields as blank. And the 'Status' is 'Incomplete". Example: Track details General data Element Value Raw
score Min
score Max
score Status Incomplete Time 2
hours 30 minutes 40.39 seconds The 'Time' is "2 hours 30 minutes 40.39 seconds", so from this data I can clearly see that the student did complete the activity. But I'm unable to determine why Moodle gave the attempt a grade of 0 (when most of the student responses were actually correct). Lots of other students have successfully completed the activity without experiencing this problem. The simplest thing is to do a manual grade override in the gradebook to give the student the credit, but that's the last resort. Instead, is there some way to "regrade" that SCORM attempt? In other words, is there some way that I can recover the scorm attempt by getting the scorm module to re-calculate the result again and push it to the gradebook? In the Quiz module I would simply "regrade" the quiz attempt. Is there a way to "regrade" a scorm activity attempt? Thanks
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: > Is there a way to "regrade" a scorm activity attempt? No. (unless you just hack the db to make some changes or write your own script to insert stuff into the db) I'd suspect that this situation might have occurred if the SCORM package overwrote the existing raw_score/completion status when the student re-entered the SCORM attempt again. Often when returning to an existing attempt the SCORM pacakge will overwrite the score. The "force new attempt" setting can help to prevent this.
