Forum Post: 
Post title: How to resume a course / lesson ?
Post description: Morning All, A quick background to what we are using: We are designing our custom courseware in Adobe Captivate and publishing into Moodle with SCORM . Also our Moodle site is hosted by an external supply. Im also unsure which version of Moodle we are using. Im looking into that right now. So before moving onto the Moodle platform we was using Checkpoint 3. Within Checkpoint users have been able to start a course, exit the system and then resume this course at a later date. Since moving to Moodle we have been unable to get this feature to work. Can anyone shine some light on this issue? Thanks Stewart
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Hi Stewart, and welcome to Moodle. There are a lot of factors involved in an issue like this. Be sure to post your moodle version as soon as possible. Assuming that the correct information is being passed through the API to Moodle, your users should have quit and resume available to them. Can you give a more concrete description of what the user does and what results from the interface? Also take a look at the advanced SCORM settings available to you, and be sure you don't have a setting wrong: http://docs.moodle.org/22/en/SCORM_settings#Other_settings You can post a screencap of your settings for the activity to this forum for us to look at, if you like. Be sure the advanced settings are shown. Normally in Captivate resume will not be available if in the previous session the activity was given cmi.core.lesson_status of "passed" or "completed". You might want to run the content through debugging and see if that's the case. Usually the SCORM content only does this when the end of the content is reached, or a certain score is achieved, but that setting would be in the content, and not in Moodle. But I am not a Captivate expert, either. I'm speaking of conventions, and not your specific content, which I have not seen or tested.
Comment 2: Hi Amy, Thanks for the reply. I will be honest im very new to Moodle and Captivate so some points you have made have gone well over my head. When we was using Checkpoint Version 3 we didnt have to worry about any settings as the hosting company took care of this. So all these setings are quite new. The hosting company have told me we are using Moodle V1.9. I have included a screencap of the settings from Moodle.
Comment 3: Opps forgot to add the screencap from Captivate.

Forum Post: 
Post title: deleting records in mdl_scorm_scoes in 1.96
Post description: We have recently noticed a change we don’t understand in our SCORM module. If an admin is in course/modedit.php to update an existing SCO the system appears to delete all records in mdl_scorm_scoes for the existing SCO and creates a new set of records plus it changes the scoid value for all existing records in mdl_scorm_scoes_track from the old values to the values for the new mdl_scorm_scoes records. We compare this with an older version of the SCORM module where the system merely updates values in the existing record in mdl_scorm_scoes only. Perhaps we are missing something but we think that the older method is a better approach so in our version of the SCORM 1.96 module we have changed in mod/scorm/datamodels/scormlib.php from the current code: // Insert the new SCO, and retain the link between the old and new for later adjustment $id = insert_record('scorm_scoes',$newitem); if (!empty($olditems) && ($olditemid = scorm_array_search('identifier',$newitem->identifier,$olditems))) { $olditems[$olditemid]->newid = $id; } To the earlier version of this activity: $id = 0; if (!empty($olditems) && ($olditemid = scorm_array_search('identifier',$newitem->identifier,$olditems))) { $newitem->id = $olditemid; $id = update_record('scorm_scoes',$newitem); unset($olditems[$olditemid]); delete_records('scorm_scoes_data','scoid',$olditemid); } else { $id = insert_record('scorm_scoes',$newitem); } We are interested to know if we are missing something here and whether there is a reason why the incrementing of the scoe number in each update is done deliberately in SCORM 1.96 to achieve something that we can’t quite grasp. If not we would like to share our ‘fix’ to this issue with the community … and ask what the implications may be for SCORM 1.9.8. Many thanks Jon ( Edited by Dan Marsden removed Word formatting- original submission Tuesday, 6 April 2010, 10:44 PM )
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Hi Jon, I'm pretty sure the changes you mean are made by the fix for MDL-13904 - it's performed deliberately as the SCORM package may have changed during the update. It's hard to see why this causing an issue for you? - are you accessing the DB directly to pull data out and getting unexpected results? - maybe you should check out MDL-21555 which contains some great improvements to the reporting interface in SCORM

Post title: IMS specifications in moodle?
Post description: Hi, I would like to know which the ims specifications implemented in the moodle 1.4.2, as well as the ones that in future will be thought for subsequent versions. examples: Ims content package. Yes/No? Ims Metadata ? Ims QTI? Ims Learn Design? Ims LIP ? others? Thanks, paulo
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Paulo, As far as I know none of the IMS specifications are implemented in moodle but at least IMS QTI, for the import and export of quizes, is in the pipeline. For content packaging SCORM seems to be the standard of choice, and the one that is being implemented here. Tim
Comment 2: Thanks Tim for your explanation. Now and after reading several papers, I continue without knowing if Moodle is or is not an LMS!? paulo
Comment 3: Dear Paulo, Yes, it very definately is a LMS. If you look on the comparisons and advocacy forum then you will find people arguing that Moodle is perhaps the best LMS. In any event it is well up there. Incidentally, sometimes Greg of ATutor claims that his system (not bad) is a "LCMS" (learning content management system) rather than 'just' a Learning Management Sytem, because of the alledged compliance with the sort of Learning content standards that you mentioned in your last post. But, in my view the distinction is hokey, and Moodle does support SCORM anyway. So, you can add a C in there too if you want. Moodle is a LMS and a LCMS too. Tim
Comment 4: Ok Tim, thanks for your explanation. I will continue reading this fabulous papers of these forums for, later, to "abuse" of your good will. Paulo

Post description: I have an Articulate Storyline file that is published to SCORM 1.2. I am trying to test completing the course in two phases as it is long. If I complete the first section, and the first exam, exit the activity, and then re-enter the activity and finish the course, it does not register as completed. So, the only way I can get the course to register as completed is by completing all of it in one shot. It is a single activity course format. Can anyone help?
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Having two exams in the module may be messing with something. I know the Articulate completion settings are more granular than Captivate but less than Lectora (which are the two primary SCORM publishes I use(d)..that matter)...you might check and see how they are working and see if you can tweek them. If it requires a specific grade and completing everything, it is possible the first grade submission is triggering 'completion' (as in not) but Moodle is reopening in review mode and review mode may not open where you leave off (I don't know that I've paid attention to that). I'm guessing here. In Moodle settings, if review mode is on...try turning it off. Don't force completion.

Post title: modedit.php update error
Post description: Attempts to update an existing SCORM course call http://<myWebSite>/course/modedit.php?update=1&return=0 and the 'Updating SCORM/AICC' form is displayed and appears to work fine.  This results from the final lines of code in modedit.php $mform->display(); print_footer($course); But when saving the updates (either 'return to course' or 'display') the server attempts to load http://<myWebSite>/course/modedit.php (i.e. the same path & page but without the parameters), but fails with an HTTP 500 Internal Server Error and the suggestion that 'The website has a programming error'.  On return to the editing page, any changes are seen to have failed. I'm running Moodle 1.9.10 in IIS7 with MySQL 5.1.53 and PHP 5.3.4 Any help/clues/suggestions welcome.
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: first you'll need to disable the IIS 7 error handling so that it shows you the real error from moodle - quick google found this instruction: - Open your site and double click the “Error Pages” icon - In the actions panel on the right hand side, click “Edit Feature Settings…” - Click on the radio button saying “Detailed errors for local requests and custom error… etc.” but there might be other stuff you need to do as well - it's been a while since I've had to do it.
Comment 2: Thanks, Dan.  Unfortunately the result is pretty nebulous, and hardly related to PHP: Technical Information (for support personnel) Go to Microsoft Product Support Services and perform a title search for the words HTTP and 500 . Open IIS Help , which is accessible in IIS Manager (inetmgr), and search for topics titled Web Site Administration , and About Custom Error Messages . In the IIS Software Development Kit (SDK) or at the MSDN Online Library , search for topics titled Debugging ASP Scripts , Debugging Components , and Debugging ISAPI Extensions and Filters . I'll think about the "other stuff"... there are 6,420 results for "http 500 error how to fix" in MS Support Services.  Maybe I'll just install Apache !
Comment 3: have a look through the windows forum on this site - I'm sure there are some posts somewhere describing how to disable the IIS 7 errors and show the Moodle ones instead - I think there are a few people who have blogged about it too - if you can't find anything I'll see if I can dig out the links,
Comment 4: Thanks, Dan, but the only thing I found is a rec to turn off the browser friendly error messages, which results in a blank browser window.  php.ini is set to write errors to a file, but nothing is created.  modedit.php takes just over 30 seconds befor failing, and the parameterless modedit.php URL appears in the address bar immediately before failing.  (By parameterless, I mean its a full URL, but no ? and GET parameters.) So I'm guessing that the library script that does all save work is timing out.
Comment 5: blank page is good - it means IIS isn't getting in the way of reporting - try turning debugging on (admin > server > debugging) - elevate the debugging level and turn display errors on ...but I'm wondering if you're working with a massive scorm zip file? - the PHP zip handling is pretty bad for 1.9 so it could be timing out while trying to extract the zip - see: http://docs.moodle.org/en/SCORM_FAQ#Unzip_issues although - setting up external zip binaries on windows servers isn't always easy - it may be a better idea for you to extract the scorm object into a folder in your course files area, then point the SCORM module at the imsmanifest. xml in the unzipped folder
Comment 6: That sounds like a good call, there, Dan - the course is a comprehensive one and the zip file is 238MB.  Is it possible to insert a set_time_limit() somewhere to deal with this analysis? Otherwise I'll check through the FAQ procedure in the new year. Meanwhile, thanks for your help and best wishes for Christmas and the New Year
Comment 7: that's definately going to run into the zip issue - I wouldn't bother trying any analysis as a 238MB file isn't going to be handled very well by the PHP zip stuff in 1.9 - you need to either use an external zip binary (do a google search for how to get this to work for Moodle under windows) - or extract the zip as I mention above and link to the imsmanifest.xml file instead.
Comment 8: Thanks for your help, Dan
Comment 9: If you have direct access to the db then check the mdl_course table.  I seem to remember getting frustrated by this and then finding that there was a spurious extra row in this table causing the error when the modified data was being saved and I just deleted the offending item.  Duplicate entry.
Comment 10: Thanks, Ebenezr - but no such luck for a simple solution.  Would that it were!  But good to have this on record incase someone sometime has the same problem.
Comment 11: Hi, I met the same problem "invalid operation" when i tried to upload a scorm. I thought it was due to the memory storage was full. I deleted some files but it made no use. Please help me. Thanks.

Post title: uploading scorm package
Post description: hi when i add a scorm package it appears to do it correctly and brings me in so i can see the course structure on the left but when i click on one of the links it attempts to open the page (which is asp) outside of the browser in code rather than in the product this package came from Janison toolbox (written in asp) and i am attempting to test it importing into Moodle - the xml file and everything appears to be in the zip folder and it appears to import okay but just doesnt show any content without going open which then opens the page in frontpage or notepad in code view
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Is your web server configured to run ASP pages? Standard apache web server does not run ASP pages.
Comment 2: it is running under IIS that will run asp but i will double and triple check!
Comment 3: nope no cigar asp works fine on the server - it just appears to be these scorm packages any ideas anyone? or is there a way i can take the scorm package from janison - play with it in another product and bring it into Moodle?
Comment 4: In a scorm package you can't use asp, php or any other server side scripting languages. If you want use dynamical pages you need to define them as external resources in the manifest files. This resources can be stored on the same server with moodle but in a public webserver directory in order to permits webserver to elaborate scripts. Moodle store all the uploaded files in a particular directory "moodledata" that normally is not a public webserver directory. You must also know that, for security, the files in that directory will never elaborate so moodle pass to the browser the source of the script. This is the reason of why when you access to your scorm package your browser open dreamweaver or some other application that manage asp files. I hope this can help you. Cheers, Bobo. PS: to set external link to resources in the manifest you must set href attribute of tag resource to something like http://yourserver.com/scorm/resource/directory/yourfile.asp
Comment 5: Hi, Do you have some administrator priviliges for your IIS server?

Forum Post: 
Post title: Arguments For Flash Files
Post description: First off - bringing SCORM support to Moodle is a nice piece of work and I've no doubt it will benefit Moodle and all its users without end. I run the website, http://www.xquestion.com , which allows users to convert tests and assessments from QTI (Question and Test Interoperability Specification) directly into SCORM modules. I downloaded the 1.2.1 release and added the SCORM module to see how XQuestion output would run in Moodle. The sample SCORM package is available at http://www.xquestion.com/Examples.html I successfully imported the package, but there were other problems. I tracked them down on the server and following problem occurs. The following file is requested, /moodle/file.php/2/moddata/scorm/SCORMKD4kYcp8/test.swf?forwardURL=finish.html%3FSCORE%3D%24que_score%24%26MINSCORE%3D0.0%26MAXSCORE%3D100.0 and, while the test.swf is present in the correct location, it is returning Sorry, but the file you are looking for was not found (/home/clans/moodledata/2/moddata/scorm/SCORMKD4kYcp8/test.swf?forwardURL=finish.html?SCORE=$que_score$&MINSCORE=0.0&MAXSCORE=100.0) I think that file.php is not allowing for the fact that files can be called with arguments in this way and is looking to match the whole string rather than the portion before the '?'. This is often the case with flash files, but can be true also of .html files ( javascript can access these variables). I don't think this is related to the problem that has been discussed here regarding Apache 2 and replacing the ? with / - that's not a problem (I'm using Apache 1) and it is serving other files from within the package okay - just not the flash file with arguments. Anyway, i've done a little perl and php and would be happy to lend a hand to do a fix if it is agreed that this is the problem. I'd like to be supportive of Moodle efforts to add SCORM and I'll keep an eye on this forum to help with any SCORM issues.
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Hi Alex, you are right with file.php . If  you update moodle or at least file.php from cvs that should work. Bye, Bernard
Comment 2: Many thanks Bernard, I've just downloaded the latest file.php from Sourceforge and I'm happy to report that it is working well. Alex.

Post title: How do I author a SCORM module
Post description: I want to be able to author my own SCORM modules easily. I cannot find any simple to use tools to create SCO's, add the javascript api_wrapper and create the manifest.. I have created a small unit which consists of 4 web pages and a small Flash quiz. I have used the L5 SCORM producer to create the SCO's and the manifest and I have found some javascript APi files but when I test it in the Reload Scorm Player it does not seem to track anything. Does anyone know the steps which should be taken to create a small SCORM package. I am can cope with editing HTML and javascript, so I'm not a total novice, but I am when it comes to SCORM. Are there any open source tools to create SCO's from webpages etc? Steve Longley
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Hey Steve, The SCORM Runtime Wrapper Extension for Dreamweaver will add minimal javascript code to turn a single page into a SCO.  It just finds the API, calls LMSInitialize onLoad and LMSFinish onUnload, and optionally sets the lesson status.  I see you've discovered the L5 SCORM producer.  It can be helpful if you want to quickly create a SCORM package within Dreamweaver, but it is pretty limited and I, too, had some problems getting it to work.  There is also the ManifestMaker Extension for Dreamweaver that will create a mainfest file from the contents of your DReameaver site, but it is also quite limited.  Why don't you use the Reload SCORM Editor, since you appear to be using the player?  It is the best free tool I have found for creating SCORM packages.  Unfortunately, I don't know of any good free tools (be glad to hear of any) to help you create learning interactions in your SCOs beyond the ultra minimal ones that the Dreamweaver SCORM Runtime Wrapper lets you do.  However, Claude Ostyn has created an excellent tutorial on hand coding SCORM interaction called "Cooking Up a SCORM "( http://academiaelearning.com/contenido/scorm/cooking/i_cookbook.htm ).  I'd try that. Hope that helps. Rob
Comment 2: In case you prefer the dreamweaver route to SCORM one site that I am familiar with is http://www.spainwex.com/elsewex The elearning site in Spaisih and there is a hyperlink to moodle.  If any one is kind enough to translate the html page and post in this forum it will be helpful.  The english site is http://www.spainwex.com/elsewex/english/demo.htm I worked for some time in this open source Windows /ASP/Ms SQL environment  and the testing site is available at http://www.elearning.edu/forel/forum/forum.asp use admin and pswd admin Since I have not done any further work in this area I may not be a good resource person.  Any one with ASP skills will be able to do the SCORM compliant dreamweaver product. Prof.V.Nagarajan.
Comment 3: I have tried to author a scorm package using Reload, but when I do and I test it in the player it tells me the files in the organisation are assets but all the sample ones I use it tells me that each one is a SCO. What am I doing wrong. Steve

Comment 6: http://www.techsmith.com The Camtasia Studio outputs SCORM compliant packages very easily. They have a 30 day free trial which is fully functional. You can't go wrong. Good Luck drs

Comment 11: Hi! I create the content in Camtasia, and the scorm package made by Reload Editor. if I upload in Moodle and check the package, the moodle dont count the time to attempt this package. Only sign to Status Completed and the Time is 00:00:00. What do I wrong? And sorry my english, I hope clear, what is my problem.
Comment 12: Hii I have all the html codes with me but what I want is that, I want to convert that html code to scorm compliance so that it could upload in moodle.. can anyone help me regarding this.. Please I need an urgent reply I would be really grateful if you could help me.. Thanks
Comment 13: Hello Smit, First, establish that you need SCORM, and that putting your HTML content into a Moodle lesson module, for example, won't do the trick. The lesson will track learner progress, and you can put SWF-based or JS-based interactivity right into the HTML area fields of the lesson pages. If you do need SCORM, then have a look at this: http://docs.moodle.org/en/SCORM_FAQ#What_version_of_SCORM_is_supported.3F I would recommend JavaScript wrapper by Philip Hutchison. All you have to do is add the appropriate calls from your HTML pages to the wrapper functions which communicate with the LMS. One advantage of Philip's wrapper is that it works with 2004 or 1.2, so if you ever change over, you won't have to rewrite your wrapper. http://pipwerks.com/laboratory/scorm/api-wrapper-javascript/ Also access the sample SCORM 1.2 packages from ADL here. The simple packages will show you how to package your content and your JS wrapper: http://docs.moodle.org/en/SCORM_FAQ#Is_there_a_definitive_source_for_SCORM_information.3F Every authorware product will have its ticks and issues. If you need SCORM, and you've already got the HTML content, then the best approach is to just author the SCORM interaction into that content. The ADL SCORM documentation, unwieldy as it is, can be very helpful (why can't they put that in a wiki?). Best of luck, Amy
Comment 14: Hi Smit Try Courselabs from www.courselab.com It's Russian Freeware that builds a Scorm compliant course. You would take each page and insert it into a course. It's very easy once you work the basics out.
Comment 15: From: http://docs.moodle.org/en/Tools_for_creating_SCORM_content#Courselab CourseLab version 2.4 has a few bugs. First is with audio. Sometimes (for some reason not known to CourseLab) the audio will restart, creating an echo effect. You will need to un-check the "autostart" mark of the Video object (vidoe object is used to insert audio too)and then define an action on some event that fits the case (for example on the slide's afterdisplay event) choose METHOD (yourvideoobject, PLAY. this will play the audio after the slide is displayed. Another issue is with FireFox browsers displaying graphics with CourseLab. It is stated in user's manual that some objects utilize Explorer-specific features and author should avoid using them, if he wants to use the course in multi-browser environment. These are: Gradient Box and all AutoShapes. AutoShapes are VML-objects and VML (Vector Markup Language) is not supported by FireFox. SVG (Scalable Vector Graphics - another vector format) could be the good alternative, but there are still problems with displaying inline SVG-objects in both Gecko-family and IE . (from CourseLab Support) If these FireFox/Image display problems are not an issue then be sure to install the latest browser plug-ins. If you present content to non-IE users, do not use this authoring package. There are some problems with Moodle configuration see http://moodle.org/mod/forum/discuss.php?d=96338#p425335
Comment 16: True. However, if you are in a hurry and need a free alternative or a relatively simple way of generating SCORM compliant packages, then CourseLab does this as long as you stick to very basic HTML and the standards. Generally the majority of courses can be written within these parameters. I don't think I've come across any tool that will deliver to requirements perfectly. Frustration is certainly the most frequent outcome. Often, innovative designs and ideas get dumped because there is simply no way to get them to work in the time available. If it isn't the authoring package displaying garbage, it's the LMS not tracking progress or completion status. It ends up being multiple choice with powerpoint slides!
Comment 17: We offer low-cost authoring tools ($99 to $149) to create SCORM-based courses and tests. Our tools come with documented source code so you can modify the tools to meet specific needs. We also make Manifest Maker , the free extension for Dreamweaver that creates SCORM manifest files.

Forum Post: 
Post title: Scorm (Attempt not Registered Message)
Post description: Hello, I am having an issue with my students. Some of their scorm attempts are not registering in moodle. Is there any possibility to make a message to appear informing the students if their attempts and score have registered or not after they finish the scorm quiz? Thanks a lot for the help.
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: You can put a check in place to ensure the user is still connected to the database and display an alert message if they are not.  We've done this for some of our modules using the pipwerks SCORM API wrapper. As far as I know, a dropped connection would be the only reason attempts would be missed intermittently.
Comment 2: What Moodle version are you running? - the SCORM player in Moodle 2 is more reliable than the one in 1.9 - and it's better in 2.3 than it is in 2.0. Moodle 2 has a setting to disable access to SCORM when JS is not enabled in the users browser - make sure that's enabled in admin > plugins > activities > SCORM You could also use the setting "display attempt status" to show students their progress in SCORM - it will give a summary of their attempts on the initial view page and on their My Moodle page.

Post title: File Not Found for first load of scorm lesson
Post description: I have a scorm package with a ton of lessons. On some machines, when a scorm lesson is loaded for the first time, it gives "Error: No file found at ...'file/location/file.swf'. (of course replace file/location/file.swf with whatever the file maybe. If I reload the page, the lesson loads just fine. I thought it was just the SWF file wasn't loading quickly enough and on reload it would then load a cached copy, so I inserted a few seconds for delay into the loadSCO.php file, but still got the same issue. I have checked the logs, but I am not seeing any errors at all there. In fact, other than the file not found, I get no issues/logs/errors at all. I am running Internet Explorer 11. Moodle 2.6.11 with PHP 5.3.8. I have another laptop with the exact same setup but that one works just fine with no issues. Any suggestions would be greatly appreciated.
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Hi Shawn, did you set the debug at DEVELOPER level and, besides looking at the error logs, even track the connection via the Dev Tools of your browser to understand if the server replies with a real HTTP 404 ? MDL-47404 already addressed a particular issue with SWF loading other SWF files so you need to collect more info to better describe your issue and give others a way to replicate it. HTH , Matteo
Comment 2: yeah - sounds like a server-level issue, are you using any caching plugins? - make sure you don't have 2 opcache style plugins enabled - like php opcache and APC - do you have multiple web-servers in a cluster and only one of them has up-to-date moodledata?

Post title: OR prerequisite not working?
Post description: Hi, I have a problem to make the OR prerequisite work in the scorm module. Let's say my scorm package consists of 3 SCO's, sco1, sco2 and sco3. In order to reach sco3 you need to "pass" sco1 OR sco2. so i put in my prerequisites for sco3 : sco1="passed" | sco2="passed". in my imsmanifest: <item identifier="sco3" isvisible="true" identifierref="Res005"> <title>sco3</title> <adlcp:prerequisites type="aicc_script">sco1="passed" | sco2="passed"</adlcp:prerequisites></item> In the moodle database he extracts it correctly, but when i open the course and launch the sco's, i need to have both sco1 and sco2 at "passed" before i can go to sco3 in stead of having just one of the two at "passed". Also when i try this with "Or" in stead of | it doesnt work. Can anyone help me with this problem i have? Thx in advance!
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Hello Wouter, I cannot help you with your problem, but you can help yourself by voting for the bug that I registered: http://tracker.moodle.org/browse/MDL-11188 BTW , have you considered becoming a member of Ned-Moove ( http://www.ned-moove.be )? Maybe Vision would like to be a "donateur"? Kind regards, Hans de Zwart
Comment 2: I'm pretty sure the 'pipe' ( | ) is an OR condition, so the statement would read aloud as prerequisites type sco1="passed" OR sco2="passed" - change the pipe to && and it should work.
Comment 3: I apologize, speed-reading kills. You WANT the OR function not the AND. I'm sorry. The OR function I think, is a double pipe || in php.
